Manager's immediate direction, and shall indirectly supervise the performance
of all Village employees and contractors. The Manager shall direct, supervise
and coordinate the administration of all departments, offices and agencies of
the Village, except as otherwise provided by law.
      2.   Enforcement Of Laws: The Manager shall provide for the enforcement
of laws and ordinances within the Village.
      3.   Reports And Communications: The Manager shall make such reports as
the Corporate Authorities may request concerning the operations of the Village,
and shall provide recommendations for reporting where appropriate.
      4.   Procurement And Contracting: The Manager shall be responsible for
procurement of commodities and services for all Village departments and
employees, shall promulgate rules for procurement to be considered for adoption
by the Corporate Authorities, and shall endeavor to comply with all adopted or
otherwise mandatory purchasing policies, laws or ordinances.
      5.   Personnel Rules And Regulations: The Manager shall propose to the
Corporate Authorities such personnel rules and regulations as shall be
necessary or appropriate for the management of Village personnel and resources,
and shall have the authority to implement such policies, rules and regulations
(that are not inconsistent with Board-adopted rules or regulations) as shall be
necessary or advisable for the safe, efficient of effective operation and
governance of Village operations.
      6.   Employment And Disciplinary Actions: Notwithstanding the provisions
of any Village policy or employment handbook, the Manager shall have the
authority to hire, appoint, terminate, suspend, place on paid or unpaid
administrative leave, conduct any required or advisable hearings, or take other
disciplinary action with regard to any Village employee, or to create, modify
or amend job titles and descriptions for any Village employee, as shall be
appropriate under the circumstances. Actions relating to hiring and termination
shall occur only after advising the Village Board.
      7.   Purchasing Authority: The Manager shall have purchasing authority
for contracts and expenses not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000). With
the concurrence of the Village President and Finance Director, the Manager
shall have purchasing authority for contracts and expenses not to exceed ten
thousand dollars ($10,000). In the event that a true emergency exists which
requires the expenditure of additional funds, in a circumstance where the
expenditure is unavoidable and delay until a village board meeting is
impractical (e.g., the failure of a lift station pump requiring immediate
repair to maintain sanitary sewer service for the village), the Manager may
authorize an expenditure of up to twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) with the
concurrence of the Village President. All such purchases shall be within then-
presently budgeted sums.
      8.   Finance And Budgeting: In collaboration with the Finance Director,
the Manager shall make such recommendations and reports to the Corporate
Authorities as shall be advisable from time to time, and shall review the
Village's proposed budgets, tax levies, consolidated annual financial reports
and other similar financial or transactional documents for the purpose of
making recommendations to the Corporate Authorities. The Manager shall be
responsible for presentation of the Budget to the Corporate Authorities, and
for securing their feedback and approval.
      9.   Collective Bargaining: The Manager shall be responsible for the
organization and conduct of the Village's collective bargaining processes, and
for presentation of proposed collective bargaining agreements for consideration
by the Corporate Authorities.
      10.   Policies And Regulations: The Manager shall make recommendations to
the Corporate Authorities for the consideration of adoption of policies,
resolutions, ordinances or other regulations as shall be advisable from time to
time, and shall have the authority to implement such policies, rules and
regulations (that are not inconsistent with Board-adopted rules or regulations)
as shall be necessary or advisable for the safe, efficient of effective
operation and governance of Village operations.
      11.   Waiver Of Fees: The Manager shall have the authority to waive
otherwise applicable Village fees, without limitation, for any Village-
initiated project (e.g. building permit fees otherwise applicable to Village
construction). The Manager shall also have the authority to waive fees, charges
or other obligations up to the limit of spending authority as outlined in (C)
(7) above, but shall report all such waivers to the Village Board at the time
of the waiver.
      12.   Resolution Of Claims: The Manager shall have the authority to
settle, resolve or compromise claims where the Village's cost (e.g. deductible,
retention or direct cost) does not exceed the Purchasing Authority contemplated
in (C)(7) above.
      13.   Preparation Of Agenda: The Manager shall oversee the preparation of
the agenda for meetings of the Corporate Authorities, and shall initially
determine which items are listed for consideration on the consent agenda. The
Village President may also require the inclusion of any item on the agendas of
the Corporate Authorities by request, and the Village Board may require the
inclusion of any item on the agendas of the Corporate Authorities by passing a
motion at a meeting, under new business, to request inclusion of the item on a
future agenda.
      14.   Disposal Of Personal Property: The Manager is authorized to dispose
of all personal property that is not property of the Village (i.e., found
items, evidence previously seized, or other similar items not purchased with
village proceeds) in accordance with applicable laws, without any requirement
of prior approval by the village board. With regard to personal property of the
village of Pingree Grove (i.e., items purchased or procured by the village),
such items may be disposed of pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-76-4, through sale of property, conversion into useful
form, or trade-in of such property, following Board approval of any such action
with respect to identified property.
      15.   Delegation Of Authority: The Manager may delegate authority
provided herein to any other Village employee when necessary in the performance
of the Village's operations from time to time. In addition, the Manager may
appoint an Acting Village Manager from among the Village's Department Heads, to
exercise the powers contained herein during any time of absence, unavailability
or illness of the Manager.
      16.   Additional Responsibilities: The Manager shall perform such other
duties as may be assigned by the President or Village Board from time to time.
(Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-3: RESPONSIBILITIES OF ALL DEPARTMENT HEADS:
   A.   Administration And Coordination: Department heads shall direct,
supervise, and coordinate all activities within their department, in accordance
with the directives of the corporate authorities and the approved budget.
Department heads shall also direct and supervise the actions of all employees
within their departments, with all authority being subject to the oversight and
direction of the Manager.
   B.   Discipline Of Employees: Department heads shall have the authority to
discipline employees up to and including issuance of a verbal or written
warning, and including the authority to suspend employees, with pay. Department
heads shall also have the authority to refer employees to the Manager for
further discipline, or to exercise any authority conferred upon them by the
Manager relating to discipline or employment.
   C.   Commodities And Services: Department heads shall be responsible for the
purchase of commodities and services within their respective departments,
subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   Within any applicable budget restrictions;
      2.   Within applicable spending authority;
      3.   Pursuant to the provisions of the then current purchasing policies
of the village; and
      4.   Pursuant to any applicable laws or regulations (e.g., competitive
bidding requirements).
   D.   Contracts: Department heads shall have the authority to enter into
contracts and to bind the village on any agreement or change order, subject to
the following restrictions:
      1.   Any expenditure must be within the then approved budget for the
village.
      2.   Any expenditure must comply with all applicable laws, ordinances or
regulations.
      3.   Any department head acting individually shall have spending
authority up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   E.   Seasonal, Part Time Employees: Department heads shall have the
independent authority to interview, select and hire seasonal, part-time
employees to be employed by the village, without requiring the approval of the
board, provided that the costs of such employees are included within the then
current budget, and provided that the costs incurred do not exceed budgeted
amounts. In the event that costs are anticipated to exceed budgeted amounts at
any time, the department head affected shall notify the board and either reduce
staffing (so as to not exceed the budgeted amounts) or shall request a budget
amendment prior to exceeding budgeted amounts.
   F.   Acting Department Heads: During times of unavailability or illness, a
department head may appoint an acting department head with the consent of the
Manager.
   G.   Other Duties: The department heads shall attend Village Board meetings
and shall perform such other duties as may be assigned from time to time, along
with those duties outlined in any position specific ordinance, code, rule or
regulation. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-4: FINANCE DIRECTOR:
   A.   The Finance Director shall serve as the primary financial officer of
the Village and shall have responsibility and supervision over all employees
assigned to the Finance Department.
   B.   Responsibilities: The Finance Director shall have the following
responsibilities:
      1.   Exercise and perform all financial powers and duties of Finance
Director, Treasurer, Collector or Comptroller pursuant to Village Code, policy
or Illinois law.
      2.   Maintain custody of monies belonging to the Village and ensure that
all funds are properly deposited or invested in accordance with applicable laws
and regulations.
      3.   Maintain the Village's financial records in accordance with Village
ordinances, state or federal regulations, and generally accepted municipal
financial management and accounting practices.
      4.   Pay all warrants, bills or orders properly presented with checks
drawn upon proper funds signed by the President and countersigned by the
Village Manager or Finance Director.
      5.   Ensure the proper, efficient and effective receipt and disbursement
of all Village funds, maintain proper, efficient and effective systems for
accounts receivable (and pursue collection of the same), accounts payable,
payroll, financial reporting, internal financial, administrative and accounting
controls and financial records, and otherwise maintain the Village's financial
systems and perform such activities as are necessary or required by applicable
law, regulation or policy.
      6.   Make such recommendations to the Corporate Authorities and/or
Manager as the Director believes appropriate or advantageous for the Village to
consider for adoption.
      7.   Where the activities of other departments impact upon the Village's
finances or result in the generation of expenses, handling of Village funds, or
generation of accounts receivable, assist the Manager in establishing
appropriate rules and protocols, and immediately notify the Manager of any
deviation from such established rules and protocols.
      8.   Notify the Corporate Authorities and Manager of any material
financial irregularities discovered in or relating to the Village's finances.
      9.   Maintain the Village's Human Resources records and coordinate
employee onboarding, payroll, benefits (including health, dental and related
insurance policies) and related human resources functions.
      10.   Acting individually or with the Manager, serve as signatory and
account representative for the Village on financial, investment, retirement
fund or other similar accounts and also serve as Illinois Municipal Retirement
Fund authorized agent.
      11.   Serve as budget officer for the Village, pursuant to Illinois law
and applicable codes, ordinances and policies.
      12.   Coordinate the approach and utilization of the Village's auditors,
and make recommendations regarding the selection and appropriate utilization of
the same. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-5: CHIEF OF POLICE:
The Chief of Police shall perform those duties and obligations as outlined in
this Chapter, as required by law, or as provided for in Section
6-1-4. (Ord. 2019-O- 18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-6: PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
The Public Works Director shall provide for compliance with all applicable laws
and regulations, and in particular shall comply with the regulations governing
the operation and maintenance of the village's public utilities. The public
works director shall also make recommendations to the village board regarding
establishment of policies, funding and reserves for the construction and
maintenance of the village's buildings, capital infrastructure and equipment.
The public works director shall be responsible for the safe, efficient and
professional operation and maintenance of all village public works operations,
including, but not limited to, water, wastewater, street and park operations.
(Ord. 2019-O-18, 6- 3-2019)
1-10-7: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The Village Attorney shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State
of Illinois, and shall serve as the Village's primary legal advisor. The
Village Attorney may also serve as Village Prosecutor. The Village may, from
time to time with the authorization of the Board, retain additional counsel for
specified projects. The Village may also, without requirement of separate
authorization from the Board, utilize legal counsel provided for by virtue of
the Village's insurance, security or bonds, with such counsel being acceptable
to the Manager. The Village Attorney shall be authorized to represent the
Village in any legal proceeding. With regard to cases that the Attorney
prosecutes, the Attorney shall be authorized to execute prosecutorial
discretion in the prosecution or resolution of any case. The Attorney shall be
further authorized to resolve any ordinance violation prosecution by virtue of
a compliance agreement or settlement agreement on terms appropriate under the
circumstances. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3- 2019)
1-10-8: VILLAGE ENGINEER:
The Village Engineer shall be an individual or firm licensed to practice civil
engineering in the State of Illinois, and shall serve as the Village's primary
engineering advisor. The Engineer shall serve the Village by virtue of a
written agreement approved by the Village Board, on terms and conditions
acceptable to the Board, and shall perform those services required by such
agreement or by any additional agreement or amendment thereto, or as requested
by the Village and within the authority of the party requesting. The Engineer
shall regularly advise the Village Board regarding the status of all work being
performed thereby, shall exercise that authority conferred by applicable
Village Codes, and shall work under the direction and supervision of the
Village Manager. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6- 3-2019)
1-10-9: CHIEF BUILDING OFFICIAL:
The Chief Building Official shall be an individual or firm with appropriate
credentials to serve in said capacity. The Chief Building Official shall serve
the Village by virtue of a written agreement approved by the Village Board, on
terms and conditions acceptable to the Board, and shall perform those services
required by such agreement or by any additional agreement or amendment thereto,
or as requested by the Village and within the authority of the party
requesting. The Official shall regularly advise the Village Board regarding the
status of all work being performed thereby, shall exercise that authority
conferred by applicable Village Codes, and shall work under the direction and
supervision of the Village Manager. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-10: VILLAGE PLANNER:
The Village Planner shall be an individual or firm with appropriate credentials
to serve in said capacity. The Planner shall serve the Village by virtue of a
written agreement approved by the Village Board, on terms and conditions
acceptable to the Board, and shall perform those services required by such
agreement or by any additional agreement or amendment thereto, or as requested
by the Village and within the authority of the party requesting. The Planner
shall regularly advise the Village Board regarding the status of all work being
performed thereby, shall exercise that authority conferred by applicable
Village Codes, and shall work under the direction and supervision of the
Village Manager. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6- 3-2019)
1-10-11: OTHER CONTRACTUAL SERVICES:
The Village may retain one or more parties to perform additional contractual
services on its behalf from time to time, and such parties shall perform in
accordance with the terms of their respective agreement(s). Nothing contained
herein shall limit the authority of the Village to approve such additional
agreements. (Ord. 2019-O-18, 6-3-2019)
1-10-12: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR:
The Community Development Director shall serve as the building and zoning
officer for the Village. The Community Development Director shall also make
recommendations to the Village Board regarding the establishment of policies,
funding, and planning initiatives for the Village. The Community Development
director shall be responsible for the efficient and professional operation of
the Village's building and zoning services, and facilitation of the Village's
residential and commercial development. The Community Development Director
shall work under the direction and supervision of the Village Manager.
(Ord. 2023-O-23, 11-20-2023)
CHAPTER 11
CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-11-1: Creation Of A System Of Administrative Adjudication
1-11-2: Establishment Of Code Hearing Unit
1-11-3: Definitions
1-11-4: Requirements Of Hearing Officers
1-11-5: Proceedings For Adjudicatory Proceedings
1-11-6: Hearing; Evidence
1-11-7: Findings, Decision And Order
1-11-8:Review Under Administrative Review Law
1-11-9: Judgment On Findings, Decision And Order
1-11-10: Towing Vehicles
1-11-1: CREATION OF A SYSTEM OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
   The Village of Pingree Grove pursuant to Article I, Division 2.1 of the
Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., hereby establishes a system
of administrative adjudication, subject to the limitations of this Chapter,
that provides due process of law, including notice and an opportunity for a
hearing for all affected persons. In the event a conflict between this Chapter
and Article 1, Division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code exists, then the
Illinois Municipal Code shall prevail.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF CODE HEARING UNIT:
   A.   There is hereby established a Code Hearing Unit within the Village that
is responsible for conducting adjudicatory hearings, exercising the powers
conferred in this Chapter and in the manner set out in this Chapter.
   B.   The Code Hearing Unit shall have jurisdiction to adjudicate all alleged
violations of the Code, except for: (i) proceedings not within the statutory
authority of the Village; (ii) any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a
similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of
vehicles; and, (iii) any reportable offense under Section 6-204 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
   C.   The establishment of the Code Hearing Unit does not preclude the
Village from using other methods to enforce the provisions of its Code.
   D.   The Code Hearing Unit shall consist of one or more Hearing Officers, as
that term is defined herein, and such other agents or employees assigned to
assist the Hearing Officer by the Village.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
For this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context
clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
ADJUDICATORY HEARINGS: Any hearing called by the Code Hearing Unit pursuant to
this Chapter.
CODE: The Village of Pingree Grove's Code of Ordinances.
CODE HEARING UNIT: Is defined in Section
1-11-2, herein.
COMPLAINT: A written pleading, filed with the Code Hearing Unit by an
authorized official of the Village, which alleges a violation of the Code.
FINAL ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER: Is defined in Section
1-11-7, herein.
HEARING OFFICER: An agent of the Village whose duty it is to:
   1.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the existence of
an alleged violation of the Code;
   2.   Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the adjudicatory hearing, upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
   3.   Preserve and authenticate the record of the adjudicatory hearing and
all exhibits and evidence introduced at the adjudicatory hearing;
   4.   Issue a determination, based on the evidence presented at the
adjudicatory hearing, of whether or not a violation of the Code exists; and
   5.   Impose penalties consistent with applicable provisions of the Code and
assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except,
however, that in no event shall the Hearing Officer have authority to (i)
impose a penalty of incarceration; or, (ii) impose a fine either in excess of
$50,000, or such other amount not to exceed the maximum amount established by
the Mandatory Arbitration System as prescribed by the Rules of the Illinois
Supreme Court from time to time for the judicial circuit in which the Village
is located. Any such fine imposed under this Chapter shall be exclusive of
costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with the Code and
shall not be applicable to cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed
and collected by the Village.
NON-EMERGENCY SITUATION: Any situation that does not reasonably constitute a
threat to the public interest, safety, or welfare.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-4: REQUIREMENTS OF HEARING OFFICERS:
   A.   Any attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for at
least three (3) years may be a Hearing Officer, provided that he or she
complies with the provisions of this Section.
   B.   Prior to conducting adjudicatory hearings, Hearing Officers shall have
successfully completed a formal training program which includes the following:
      1.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings
which they will conduct;
      2.   Orientation to each subject area of the Code violations that they
will adjudicate;
      3.   Observation of administrative hearings; and
      4.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders.
   C.   A person who has served as a judge in Illinois is not required to
fulfill the requirements of subsection (B), herein.
   D.   Any person seeking to be appointed as a Hearing Officer for the Village
must present evidence of his or her compliance with this Section to the
corporate authorities, in such form as deemed appropriate by the corporate
authorities.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-5: PROCEEDINGS FOR ADJUDICATORY PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   The filing of the Complaint shall serve to institute proceedings before
the Code Hearing Unit.
   B.   Parties shall be served with process in a manner reasonably calculated
to give actual notice. For the purposes of this Chapter, "a manner reasonably
calculated to give actual notice" shall mean, as appropriate, personal service
of process upon a party, its employee, or its agent; service by first-class
mail at a party's address; or notice that is posted upon the property where the
alleged Code violation is found when the party is the owner or manager of the
property. If the Village requires the party to respond to the Complaint within
a specified amount of time, the Village shall file a reply with the Code
Hearing Unit within the same amount of time afforded to the party responding to
the Complaint.
   C.   Parties shall be given notice of any adjudicatory hearing. Said notice
must, at a minimum, include: (i) the type and nature of the Code violation to
be adjudicated; (ii) the date and location of the adjudicatory hearing; (iii)
the legal authority and jurisdiction under which the adjudicatory hearing is to
be held; and, (iv) the penalties for failure to appear at the adjudicatory
hearing.
   D.   Parties shall be provided with an opportunity for an adjudicatory
hearing during which they may be represented by counsel, present witnesses and
cross-examine opposing witnesses. Parties may request the Hearing Officer to
issue subpoenas to direct the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses,
as well as the production of relevant documents.
   E.   Adjudicatory hearings shall be scheduled with reasonable promptness,
provided that for adjudicatory hearings scheduled in all non-emergency
situations, if requested by the defendant, the defendant shall have at least
fifteen (15) days after service of process to prepare for an adjudicatory
hearing. If service is provided by mail, the fifteen (15) day period shall
begin to run on the day that the notice is deposited in the mail.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-6: HEARING; EVIDENCE:
   The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not be applied in an
adjudicatory hearing under this Chapter. The Hearing Officer may accept any
evidence, including hearsay, if it is of a type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-7: FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
   A.   At the conclusion of the adjudicatory hearing, the Hearing Officer
shall make a determination (the "Final Administrative Decision"), based on the
evidence presented at the adjudicatory hearing, of whether or not a violation
of the Code exists. The Final Administrative Decision shall be in writing and
shall include a written finding of fact, decision and order including the fine,
penalty or action with which the defendant must comply.
   B.   A copy of the Final Administrative Decision shall be served on the
Parties within five days after issuance. The Final Administrative Decision
shall be served in a manner allowed by Section 1
1-11-5(B), unless the parties agree to an alternative form of service.
   C.   Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall
be in the same manner as set forth in the Code.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-8: REVIEW UNDER ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW LAW:
   Any Final Administrative Decision by a Code Hearing Unit, that a Code
violation does or does not exist, shall constitute a final determination for
purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois
Administrative Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-9: JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
   A.   Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction, or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the
failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois Administrative
Review Law are a debt due and owing the Village and may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a Final Administrative
Decision of a Code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent
jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and order of the Hearing Officer may be
enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent
jurisdiction.
   C.   In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a Code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a Code violation, any expenses incurred by a Village to
enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court
costs and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are
fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a Hearing Officer, shall be a
debt due and owing the Village and may be collected in accordance with
applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a Hearing Officer pursuant
to this subsection, the Village shall provide notice to the defendant that
states that the defendant shall appear at a hearing before the Hearing Officer
to determine whether the defendant has failed to comply with the judgment. The
notice shall set the date for such a hearing, which shall not be less than
seven days from the date that notice is served. If notice is served by mail,
the seven-day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was
deposited in the mail.
   D.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by Article XII of the Code
of Civil Procedure, 735 ILCS 5/12-101 et seq., or by the Uniform Commercial
Code, 810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or
personal estate, or both, of the defendant in the amount of any debt due and
owing the Village under this Chapter. The lien may be enforced in the same
manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent
jurisdiction.
   E.   A Hearing Officer may set aside any judgment entered by default and set
a new hearing date, upon petition filed within twenty one (21) days after the
issuance of the order of default, if the Hearing Officer determines that the
defendant's failure to appear at the adjudicatory hearing was for cause or at
any time if the defendant establishes that the Village did not provide proper
service of process. If any judgment is set aside pursuant to this subsection,
the Hearing Officer shall have the authority to enter an order extinguishing
any lien that has been recorded for any debt due and owing the Village as a
result of the vacated default judgment.
   F.   If a Defendant is determined to be liable in a judgment issued by a
Hearing Officer, such Defendant shall pay to the Village an administrative
hearing fee of up to fifty dollars ($50.00), in addition to any other amounts
owed to the Village as penalties for ordinance violations.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
1-11-10: TOWING VEHICLES:
   A.   Authority To Tow: The Police Department and all members thereof are
hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by
commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in any
place where such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks
the use of a fire hydrant or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any
emergency vehicle, any vehicle parked in a handicapped parking space without
the display of an appropriate State issued handicapped license plate or
placard, or any vehicle which has been parked in any public street or other
public place in violation of any Village or State Statute or ordinance, or is
parked in a no parking zone which has been posted "No Parking-Tow Away Zone".
The provisions of this Section shall authorize the towing and impounding of
vehicles, within the Village of Pingree Grove. This Section shall not impair
the authority provided under any other applicable Village Ordinance or
Regulation, but rather shall be read to provide additional authority to
authorized Village employees, to have vehicles towed and impounded.
   B.   Certain Grounds For Towing: Village of Pingree Grove Police Officers,
Code Enforcement Officers and their authorized designees shall be authorized to
have a vehicle towed and impounded as authorized under any other applicable
Village Ordinance or Regulation, and also under the following conditions:
      1.   A vehicle is involved in a traffic stop or is otherwise stopped
during or as a component of the investigation of a potential traffic or
criminal violation, which investigation results in the arrest of the driver of
the vehicle.
      2.   A vehicle is illegally parked upon or is illegally trespassing upon
property owned by the Village of Pingree Grove, other than a roadway or public
right of way.
      3.   A vehicle is reasonably believed to have been the scene of a crime
or is reasonably believed to have or contain evidence of a crime or other
unlawful activity.
      4.   A vehicle is subject to being seized or towed under any applicable
federal, state or local ordinance, statute, code or regulation.
      5.   A vehicle is subject to being towed and impounded based upon the
accrual of a sufficient number of parking tickets, and issuance of appropriate
notices, under applicable Village Ordinance.
      6.   A vehicle is parked in a location that presents an immediate and
unwarranted threat to public health, welfare or safety, including but not
limited to:
         a.   Vehicles parked in front of fire hydrants, fire doors, fire
lanes, or other similar locations.
         b.   Vehicles parked in a location so as to block ingress or egress
from any Fire Protection District, Police Department or Public Works Department
building or parking lot.
         c.   Vehicles parked in a location so as to block ingress or egress
from any hospital, urgent care center or other emergency medical facility.
         d.   Vehicles parked within a roadway (other than within a designated
parking zone).
         e.   Vehicles on or in dangerously close proximity to railroad tracks.
         f.   Vehicles that are on or in close proximity to a public right of
way, that have become immobilized due to mechanical difficulty, weather
conditions, or for any other cause.
         g.   Vehicles in such other location that is determined, by the
Village agent or employee ordering the towing, to be unsafe or unlawful, in
their absolute and sole discretion.
         h.   Vehicles which are otherwise eligible for towing under applicable
federal, state or local laws.
      7.   A vehicle is illegally parked on private property for which the
Village has a valid traffic enforcement agreement that permits towing without
property owner notification or consent or is illegally parked on private
property and the property owner consents to the tow.
      8.   Vehicles that are hazardous in the determination of a Village police
officer. The Village of Pingree Grove has formally determined that there are
certain characteristics which are among the types of concerns that create
traffic hazards and impede traffic on streets within the Village. A vehicle
with one or more of these characteristics is thus deemed to be a hazardous
vehicle subject to immediate towing. The characteristics that create a
hazardous vehicle include, but are not limited to:
         a.   Vehicles with broken windows;
         b.   Vehicles with obvious safety hazards;
         c.   Vehicles that are leaking any fuel or fluids onto the roadway;
         d.   Vehicles parked on private property and leaking fluids in a
fashion that endangers any environmentally sensitive area, storm sewer or other
property;
         e.   Vehicles missing any equipment required by law for legal
operation on the roadway; vehicles without properly displayed license plates
and valid registration;
         f.   Vehicles with missing or flat tires; and
         g.   Vehicles that are clearly inoperable or incapable of being moved
under their own power.
   C.   Towing And Impoundment: Any Village agent or employee authorized to
order the towing of a vehicle under this Section may utilize a towing
contractor who maintains a towing agreement with the Village. Any vehicle towed
or impounded under this Section shall be retained by the party towing the
vehicle until: i) all outstanding fines, penalties, fees, interest, or other
charges whatsoever have been paid to the Village and the party towing the
vehicle, in full; ii) the vehicle is ordered to be released from impound by the
an Administrative Hearing Officer having authority over the matter; iii) the
vehicle is ordered to be released from impound by a Court having jurisdiction
over the matter; or, iv) the vehicle is ordered to be released from impound by
the Police Chief, or their designee.
      1.   Towing Rotation And Agreement: The Police Chief shall be authorized
to enter into one or more towing agreements with properly licensed and equipped
private towing companies, to provide for the towing of vehicles in accordance
with this Section or any other applicable code, ordinance, statute or
regulation. Such agreements shall be entered into on terms and conditions
acceptable to the Police Chief. Any party that provides towing services to the
Village under such an agreement shall comply with the Agreement in full, and
shall be responsible to the Village for any costs or expenses incurred, or
fines and penalties lost, as a result of the improper release of a vehicle from
impoundment. The Chief of Police is and shall be authorized to maintain a tow
rotation list for towing services to be utilized by the Police Department and
other Village departments, when it is necessary to tow any vehicle within the
Village or within the jurisdictional area covered by the Police Department or
any other Village department. The Police Chief shall review the tow rotation on
a periodic basis. The Police Chief may suspend or remove any company from the
tow rotation in his sole and absolute discretion, based upon the performance of
the company, compliance with the Qualifications established by the Chief, or
other factors he deems appropriate. Any such removal may be appealed to the
Village Board by submitting a written request for the same within five (5) days
of the issuance of the Police Chiefs notice of suspension or removal. Inclusion
on the tow rotation list is not a property right and there is no expectation of
continuing service generated by inclusion on the list; the Village reserves the
right to suspend or remove a towing service from the tow rotation at any time,
for any reason.
   D.   Interference With Towing: It shall be unlawful to interfere with any
towing company engaged in lawful towing activities, within the Village of
Pingree Grove, or to engage in disorderly conduct or other unlawful behavior in
an attempt to prevent the towing of a vehicle that is eligible for towing. It
shall further be unlawful to improperly stop payment or attempt to reverse
charges on any form of payment provided to a towing company which has lawfully
towed a vehicle. A violation of this Section is punishable by a fine of not
less than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00), unless the violation is
interfering with lawful towing activities initiated by the Village (i.e.
Village ordered towing or towing from public property), in which case the
minimum fine shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   E.   Storage And Redemption; Costs:
      1.   Vehicles so towed away shall be stored on any Village property or in
a public garage or parking lot and shall be restored to the owner or operator
thereof after payment of the expenses incurred by the Village in removing and
storing such vehicles.
      2.   Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-207, and other
provisions of this title, any vehicle impounded or caused to be towed or
removed by the Village shall not be released to the owner, lienholder, or other
person until all towing and storage charges have been paid. There shall be
assessed a towing charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00) in addition to any
and all other fines and penalties herein provided. In the event that such
owner, lienholder or other person seeks to challenge any fine or charge imposed
under this section
1-11-10, such owner, lienholder or other person shall file a complaint setting
forth in reasonable detail and basis explaining the challenge of such fine or
charge with the Code Hearing Unit and an adjudicatory hearing shall be
scheduled and conducted in accordance with section
1-11-5, Proceedings for Adjudicatory hearing.
(Ord. 2025-O-05, 4-7-2025)
TITLE 2
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Membership; Appointment; Qualifications
2-1-2: Term Of Office
2-1-3: Officers
2-1-4: Meetings And Quorum
2-1-5: Powers And Duties
2-1-6: Compensation
2-1-1: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS:
The planning and zoning commission (commission) shall consist of seven (7)
members who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the
board of trustees. All members shall be residents of the village. Such members
shall have qualifications as determined by the mayor. Any vacancies occurring
in the commission shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired portion of
the term remaining. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
2-1-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
   A.   Initial Term Of Office: For the members initially appointed to the
planning and zoning commission, three (3) shall have a term of office of three
(3) years; two (2) shall have a term of office of two (2) years; and two (2)
shall have a term of office of one year. In addition, such initially appointed
members shall serve for the period of time between their appointment and the
first Monday in June; the calculation of their term of office shall be based
upon a termination date of the first Monday in June of the year of termination
of their term of office. For initial appointments, the mayor shall determine
which appointees serve for which term.
   B.   Subsequent Terms: Following the initial term of office for appointed
members of the planning and zoning commission, all members shall each be
appointed for a term of three (3) years. The terms of all members shall expire
on the first Monday in June in the last year of their respective terms,
regardless of the actual date of their appointment. Members whose terms have
expired may continue to serve until a successor is appointed.
   C.   Publication: The village shall take such actions as shall be necessary
to maintain records and publicize the terms of the planning and zoning
commission members, including, but not limited to, publicizing such records on
the village's website. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
2-1-3: OFFICERS:
The mayor shall, at the time of appointment of planning and zoning commission
members, designate one member to serve as chairman. Said chairman shall serve
until his term of office expires, or until a successor chairman is designated
by the mayor. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
2-1-4: MEETINGS AND QUORUM:
The commission shall meet at such times as it may determine. Special meetings
may be called by the mayor, the chair or by any four (4) members of the
commission. A majority of the commission members then holding office shall
constitute a quorum. Final action shall be taken upon measures before the
commission with a concurrence of a majority of the members present, provided a
quorum is present. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
2-1-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The commission shall have the following duties and powers:
   A.   Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive plan
for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village. Such
plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts,
each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part
thereof, of the village. This plan may include reasonable requirements with
reference to streets, alleys, public grounds, and other improvements
hereinafter specified. The plan, as recommended by the commission and as
thereafter adopted, may be made applicable, by the terms thereof, to land
situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than one
and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any
municipality. Such plan may be implemented by ordinances to implement the
provisions of subsections B through M of this section.
   B.   Establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for
resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in
respect to public improvements as herein defined.
   C.   Establish reasonable requirements governing the location, width,
course, and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public
service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks,
playgrounds, school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes,
stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage
collection and treatment.
   D.   Designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the
recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation.
   E.   Recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive
plan.
   F.   Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities plans for specific
improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan.
   G.   Give aid to the municipal officials charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of these projects, and generally, to promote the realization of the
official comprehensive plan.
   H.   Advise the board of trustees, other boards and commissions,
neighborhood organizations, developers, and the general public regarding
policies, standards and ordinances associated with planning and development
matters.
   I.   Hold public hearings and meetings, as appropriate, and make findings
and recommendations to the board of trustees concerning annexations, text and
map amendments to the zoning ordinance, planned developments, conditional and
special uses, variations which are associated with a map amendment, and
subdivisions.
   J.   Hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or
determination made by the building commissioner under this code, and thus serve
as building code board of appeals as required from time to time.
   K.   Hear and make recommendations to the board regarding proposed zoning
variations.
   L.   Hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is required
to pass under any code of the village or statute of the state of Illinois,
either as a planning and zoning commission, or as a building code board of
appeals or zoning board of appeals.
   M.   Have other powers and duties concerning planning and development
matters as may be assigned from time to time by the board of trustees. The
planning and zoning commission may utilize the services of village staff and
consultants as shall be determined to be appropriate by the village board,
mayor, or village administrator. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
2-1-6: COMPENSATION:
Members of the planning and zoning commission shall be compensated for such
service to the village at the rate of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for each
meeting so attended. (Ord. 2012-08, 5-7-2012)
CHAPTER 2
PARK ADVISORY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-2-1: Establishment
2-2-2: Membership
2-2-3: Powers And Duties
2-2-4: Funding And Undertakings
2-2-5: Volunteers
2-2-6: Reporting And Record Keeping
2-2-7: Compensation
2-2-8: Vacancies
2-2-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
It is hereby established a standing committee which shall be known as the Park
Advisory Committee ("committee") for the purpose of planning, reviewing and
guiding improvements in the Village of Pingree Grove parks. The committee shall
make its findings and recommendations to the Village Board. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-
23-2017)
2-2-2: MEMBERSHIP:
The membership of the committee shall be composed of 2 - 7 members who shall be
residents of Pingree Grove. The members shall be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Village Board. One of the members
shall be appointed Chairperson by the Village President with the advice and
consent of the Village Board.
The members shall be appointed to definite terms as determined by the Village
President. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-23-2017)
2-2-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Park Advisory Committee shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To serve as a steering committee to guide and oversee planning studies
that directly and exclusively relate to Village parks, primarily including the
proposed park adjacent to the Heritage District.
   B.   To implement, oversee and monitor the strategies and goals that are
described in the approved plans for such parks.
   C.   To advise the Village Board on matters that impact the parks including:
environment and physical image; arts, culture, heritage and entertainment;
marketing and business development; media and community relations; safety;
housing; neighborhood and community development; transportation and parking.
   D.   To investigate matters related to the development and progress of the
parks and make recommendations to the Village Board on such matters.
   E.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, no member of the committee shall have
any authority to take any action on his or her own; all actions of the
committee shall be taken only by a majority vote of a quorum of the committee.
Further, the committee's role shall be advisory in nature, and the Village is
not delegating any of its statutory authority to the committee. (Ord. 2017-O-
02, 2-23-2017)
   F.   The committee shall have the authority to solicit and raise funds for
official purposes of the Village, relating to the acquisition, construction or
maintenance of Village parks and related facilities ("park purposes"). All
funds so raised by the committee, whether by grant, donation or other form of
fundraising, shall be segregated for park purposes and shall not be utilized
for any other purposes. The Finance Director shall be authorized and directed
to ascertain a method of properly securing such funds accordingly. Expenditure
of such funds shall require a positive recommendation from the committee and
approval of the Village Board. (Ord. 2018-O-12, 6-4-2018)
2-2-4: FUNDING AND UNDERTAKINGS:
The committee shall not have the authority to execute any contract, agreement
or undertaking, nor the power to incur any debts or liabilities on behalf of
the Village, except with the express, written approval of the Corporate
Authorities of the Village. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-23-2017)
2-2-5: VOLUNTEERS:
The committee is authorized to enlist the volunteer services of such other
members of the community who will assist in advancing the goals and objectives
of the Village as described in adopted plans with the recognition that broad
community involvement will assure broad community support. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-
23-2017)
2-2-6: REPORTING AND RECORD KEEPING:
The committee shall comply in all respects with the Open Meetings Act 1  and
shall keep comprehensive minutes of all meetings which describe clearly and
completely each and every subject discussed at said meeting and any action
taken by the committee. Copies of said minutes shall be provided to the Village
Clerk together with any support data, documents and attachments. The committee
shall meet as necessary to fulfill its duties and responsibilities. The
committee shall select, from among its members, a Secretary to generate and
keep appropriate minutes and to liaison with the Village Clerk to ensure
compliance with the Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-23-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2-2-7: COMPENSATION:
Members shall not be compensated for their service on the committee. (Ord.
2017-O-02, 2-23-2017)
2-2-8: VACANCIES:
If a vacancy occurs on the committee, said vacancy may be filled by the
appointment of a member by the Village President with the advice and consent of
the Village Board. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-23-2017)
CHAPTER 3
COMMUNITY EVENTS COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-3-1: Established; Purpose
2-3-2: Membership; Appointment; Terms Of Office
2-3-3: Vacancies In Office
2-3-4: Powers And Duties
2-3-5: Funding And Undertakings
2-3-6: Volunteers
2-3-7: Meetings And Records
2-3-8: Compensation
2-3-1: ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE:
There is hereby established a standing committee which shall be known as the
community events committee ("committee") for the purpose of scheduling,
planning, organizing, fundraising for and overseeing community events that
shall be open to the enjoyment of all village residents and the general public.
(Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
2-3-2: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE:
The committee shall be composed of members who shall be residents of the
village. The members shall be appointed by the village president, with the
advice and consent of the village board. One of the members shall be appointed
chairperson by the village president, with the advice and consent of the
village board. Members shall be appointed to terms of office as shall be
required to provide for revolving three (3) year terms, with a roughly
equivalent number of persons' terms expiring each year. The total membership of
the committee shall be determined based upon the then current number of
appointees to the committee, and the number of then current appointees shall
also be utilized to determine quorum requirements.
Each member shall serve until his or her respective successor is appointed and
qualifies. Each term of office shall commence on May 1. Upon expiration of a
member's term, successors shall be appointed for three (3) year terms by the
village president, with the advice and consent of the village board. (Ord.
2016-O-09, 5-2-2016)
2-3-3: VACANCIES IN OFFICE:
If a vacancy occurs on the committee, said vacancy may be filled by the
appointment of a member by the village president, with the advice and consent
of the village board. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
2-3-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The community events committee shall have the following powers and
duties:
      1.   To schedule, plan and organize events that will be open to the
enjoyment of all village residents and the general public.
      2.   To raise funding through a variety of legal and appropriate means
including sponsorship, solicitations of donations, sales and raffles conducted
in accordance with village ordinances.
         a.   Funds raised through the committee's efforts shall be deposited
into a designated account managed by the finance director and maintained
separate and apart from public funds. The finance director and committee
chairperson shall be signatories on the account.
         b.   All fundraising efforts shall be conducted in accordance with
state and local ordinances.
      3.   To solicit and negotiate proposals and contracts to engage acts or
activities which will be a component to an organized community event. The
committee shall have no authority to bind the village in any way.
      4.   To coordinate the use of village parks, amenities and resources and
staff support with the village manager. Express consent of the village manager
shall be required before any village staff are assigned or utilized to assist
with any event.
      5.   To authorize the release of funds from the designated account
described in subsection A2 of this section for approved purposes related to the
scheduling, planning, organizing and engagement of community events. All
purchases shall be subject to the established purchasing policies of the
village and to the following:
         a.   Purchases or contracts over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) must
be approved by the village manager or finance director (which approval shall
not be unreasonably withheld).
         b.   Any purchases made using the village tax exemption shall be
approved in advance by the village manager or finance director (which approval
shall not be unreasonably withheld).
         c.   Purchases of alcohol, tobacco or other products which, by law,
are regulated by the age of the user shall be prohibited.
         d.   A corresponding receipt, bill of sale, contract or other purchase
documentation shall be submitted to the finance director within a reasonable
time after the purchase has been made.
   B.   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, no member of
the committee shall have any authority to take any action on his or her own.
All actions of the committee shall be taken only by a majority vote of a quorum
of the committee. Further, the committee's role shall be limited to the powers
and duties described herein and as may be extended from time to time by the
village board, and the village is not delegating any of its statutory authority
to the committee. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
2-3-5: FUNDING AND UNDERTAKINGS:
The committee shall not have the authority to execute any contract, agreement
or undertaking, nor the power to incur any debts or liabilities on behalf of
the village, except with the express, written approval of the corporate
authorities of the village or, if within the authority of the village manager,
with the express permission of the village manager. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
2-3-6: VOLUNTEERS:
The committee is authorized to enlist the volunteer services of such other
members of the community who will assist in advancing the goals and objectives
of the community events committee. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
2-3-7: MEETINGS AND RECORDS:
The committee shall comply in all respects with the open meetings act 1  and
shall keep comprehensive minutes of all meetings which describe clearly and
completely each and every subject discussed at said meeting and any action
taken by the committee. Copies of said minutes shall be provided to the village
clerk, together with any support data, documents and attachments. The committee
shall meet as necessary to fulfill its duties and responsibilities. The
committee shall select, from among its members, a secretary to generate and
keep appropriate minutes and to liaison with the village clerk to ensure
compliance with the open meetings act. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2-3-8: COMPENSATION:
Members shall not be compensated for their service on the committee. Members
are eligible to receive approved travel, training and per diem reimbursements
in accordance with the village personnel policies and procedures only with
advanced approval from the village manager. (Ord. 2010-08, 4-19-2010)
CHAPTER 4
COMMUNITY GARDEN ADVISORY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-4-1: Established; Purpose
2-4-2: Membership; Appointment; Terms Of Office
2-4-3: Powers And Duties
2-4-4: Funding And Undertakings
2-4-5: Volunteers
2-4-6: Meetings And Records
2-4-7: Compensation
2-4-8: Vacancies
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE:
It is hereby established a standing committee which shall be known as the
community garden advisory committee ("committee") for the purpose of planning,
reviewing and suggesting methods of establishing, operating and maintaining a
set of community gardens in the village of Pingree Grove. The committee shall
make its findings and recommendations to the village board. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-
2011)
2-4-2: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE:
The membership of the committee shall be composed of seven (7) members who
shall be residents of Pingree Grove. The members shall be appointed by the
village president with the advice and consent of the village board. One of the
seven (7) members may be appointed chairperson by the village president with
the advice and consent of the village board.
Of the seven (7) members appointed, three (3) shall have an initial term of
office of three (3) years, two (2) shall have an initial term of office of two
(2) years, and two (2) shall have an initial term of office of one year.
Thereafter, each term of office shall be three (3) years. Each member shall
serve until his or her respective successor is appointed and qualifies. Each
term of office shall commence on July 1.
Upon expiration of a member's term, successors shall be appointed for three (3)
year terms by the village president, with the advice and consent of the village
board.
The village president may, but shall not be obligated to, select and appoint
one of the seven (7) members of the committee to serve as chairman of the
committee for purposes of serving as chairperson of any committee meetings. In
the event the president fails to appoint a chairperson, the committee shall
nominate and approve, by majority vote, a chairperson to serve until such time
as the president appoints a member to so serve. In the event the chairperson
selected by the village president fails to attend any meeting of the committee,
the committee shall nominate and approve, by majority vote, a chairperson pro
tem to serve until the next meeting thereof. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-2011)
2-4-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The community garden advisory committee shall have the following powers and
duties:
   A.   To serve as a steering committee to guide and oversee proposed programs
and activities related to the community garden.
   B.   To advise the village board on matters that impact the community garden
including: land selection and utilization; fencing and access control; use of
fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides and chemicals; coordination of gardening
programs with local food banks/charities; establishment of cooperative
educational programs for local students; maintenance and operation of gardens;
delineation of garden plots; methods of allocating garden plots to village
residents or others; requests for expansion or alteration of garden areas;
cooperation and interaction with village public works employees; and related
matters.
   C.   To investigate matters related to the community garden and make
recommendations to the village board on such matters.
   D.   To propose regulations for adoption by the village board, relating to
the items described in subsection B of this section.
   E.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, no member of the committee shall have
any authority to take any action on his or her own; all actions of the
committee shall be taken only by a majority vote of a quorum of the committee.
Further, the committee's role shall be advisory in nature, and the village is
not delegating any of its statutory authority to the committee. Selection or
appointment to the committee shall not authorize a member of the committee to
exercise any unique authority relative to the community gardens. (Ord. 2011-13,
6-6-2011)
2-4-4: FUNDING AND UNDERTAKINGS:
The committee shall not have the authority to execute any contract, agreement
or undertaking, nor the power to incur any debts or liabilities on behalf of
the village, except with the express, written approval of the corporate
authorities of the village or, if within the authority of the village manager
or administrator, with the express permission of the village manager or
administrator. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-2011)
2-4-5: VOLUNTEERS:
The committee is authorized to enlist the volunteer services of such other
members of the community who will assist in advancing the goals and objectives
of the community garden as described by the village board or village
administrator. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-2011)
2-4-6: MEETINGS AND RECORDS:
The committee shall comply in all respects with the open meetings act 1 . One
member of the committee shall be nominated and selected, by majority vote, as
secretary of the committee; the secretary shall keep comprehensive minutes of
all meetings which describe clearly and completely each and every subject
discussed at said meeting and any action taken by the committee. Copies of said
minutes shall be provided to the village clerk together with any support data,
documents and attachments. The committee shall meet as necessary to fulfill its
duties and responsibilities. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2-4-7: COMPENSATION:
Members shall not be compensated for their service on the committee and are not
eligible for reimbursement of any expenses except with the advance, written
consent of the village board or village manager or administrator. (Ord. 2011-
13, 6-6-2011)
2-4-8: VACANCIES:
If a vacancy occurs on the committee, said vacancy may be filled by the
appointment of a member by the village president with the advice and consent of
the village board. (Ord. 2011-13, 6-6-2011)
CHAPTER 5
BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-5-1: Board Of Police Commissioners Established
2-5-2: Membership And Terms Of Board Of Police Commissioners
2-5-3: Meetings Of Board Of Police Commissioners
2-5-4: Powers And Duties Of Board Of Police Commissioners
2-5-5: General Provisions
2-5-1: BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and protection of residents through the employment of
highly qualified and professional sworn officers of the police department, and
in accordance with Illinois state statutes, the board of police commissioners
is hereby established in the Village. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-5-2: MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS OF BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS:
   A.   Board Membership: The board of police commissioners shall consist of
three (3) members, all of whom shall reside within the corporate boundaries of
the Village of Pingree Grove. All members shall be appointed by the president
with the advice and consent of the Village Board.
   B.   Officers: Each member of the board of police commissioners shall be
considered officers of the Village and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond
in such amount as from time to time may be required by the Village Board.
   C.   Term of Office: With respect to the initial members of the board, one
of the members shall be appointed to serve until the end of the Village's
municipal year, another shall serve until the end of the year next ensuing, and
the third to serve until the end of the year second next ensuing. Thereafter,
the term of office for all members, including the chair, shall be for three (3)
years.
   D.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Village Board, but only for the
unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   E.   Chair: The chair shall be elected by the members of the board to serve
during the Village fiscal year. It shall be the duty of the chair to conduct
all meetings of the commission and to represent the board at Village Board
meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   F.   Vice Chair: The membership of the board of police commissioners shall
elect a vice chair from among its membership at the first meeting of each year.
   G.   Secretary: The administrative assistant to the chief of police or his
or her designee shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of
regular and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the Village
Board. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-5-3: MEETINGS OF BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS:
   A.   The board of police commissioners shall meet from time to time as may
be determined by the chair or, a majority, of the board.
   B.   Notice of a board of police commissioners meeting shall be given in
writing to each member of the board at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to
the time set for the meeting. Additionally, notice of the meeting shall be
posted in a conspicuous place in the police department not less than forty-
eight (48) hours prior to any board meeting. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-5-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS:
The board of police commissioners shall have the following powers and duties
pertaining to sworn members of the police department:
   A.   To make and promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of
examinations for original appointments, conduct of examinations for promotions,
and conduct of hearings on charges brought against a member of the police
department.
   B.   To conduct examinations for original appointments and promotions.
   C.   To make all original appointments to the police department and
appointments to promotions within the police department pursuant to
examinations.
   D.   To conduct hearings on charges brought against any member of the police
department.
   E.   Such other and further powers as may from time to time be authorized by
the Illinois general assembly. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-5-5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The Village shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of
police commissioners in order, to assist the board with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the chief of police for
appropriate response by the Village. Neither the board of police commissioners
nor any of its members shall give direction to any member of the Village staff.
Unless otherwise set forth herein or established by Illinois state statutes,
all recommendations of the board of police commissioners shall be referred to
the Village Board for consideration and implementation by the Village.
   B.   The board of police commissioners shall not have the authority to make
any expenditure or cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or
indirectly results in a financial liability or lien against the Village,
without the express prior approval of the Village President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Pingree Grove. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE POLICE PENSION FUND OF THE VILLAGE OF PINGREE GROVE
SECTION:
2-6-1: Board Of Trustees Of The Police Pension Fund Established
2-6-2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2-6-3: Meetings Of Board Of Trustees Of The Police Pension Fund
2-6-4: Powers And Duties
2-6-5: General Provisions
2-6-1: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE POLICE PENSION FUND ESTABLISHED:
   A.   For the benefit of Village of Pingree Grove police officers and their
surviving spouses, children, and certain other dependents, and in accordance
with Illinois state statutes, specifically Article 3 of the Illinois Pension
Code, the board of trustees of the police pension fund is hereby established by
the Village as well as a police pension fund.
   B.   For purposes of reference and financial accounting within the Village,
the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall also be known as, and
shall serve as one in the same as, the police pension board. (Ord. 2021-O-20,
12-6- 2021)
2-6-2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Board Membership: The board of trustees of the police pension fund,
a.k.a. the police pension board, shall consist of five (5) members, at least
two (2) of whom shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the Village of
Pingree Grove.
   B.   Appointment: Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Village Board. Two (2) members of
the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members
thereof. The remaining members shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries
of the police pension fund.
   C.   Election: The election for elected board members provided for in
subsection B of this section shall be held biennially on the third Monday in
April at such time or times and places in the Village as shall be prescribed by
the appointed members of the board, and under the Australian ballot system and
other such applicable regulations.
   D.   Voting: All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to
vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal
voting age shall be entitled to vote only for the member to be chosen from the
beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at any
such election. Members so elected shall be elected for a term of two (2) years
beginning the second Tuesday of the first May following such election.
   E.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members shall be for two (2)
years.
   F.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the initial
appointing authority, but only to the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   G.   Officers: The officers of the board shall be president, vice president,
secretary and assistant secretary who shall be selected from its members at the
regular July meeting. Officers shall serve for one year and until their
respective successors are elected and qualified.
   H.   President: It shall be the duty of the president to conduct all
meetings of the board and to represent the board at Village Board meetings as
from time to time may be necessary.
   I.   Vice President: The vice president shall perform the duties of the
president during any vacancy in that office, or during the president's absence
from the Village, or if he or she is by reason of illness or other causes
unable to perform the duties of the office.
   J.   Secretary: The secretary shall maintain minutes and records of regular
and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the Village Board.
   K.   Assistant Secretary: The assistant secretary shall act for the
secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office. (Ord.
2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-6-3: MEETINGS OF BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE POLICE PENSION FUND:
   A.   The board shall meet no less than quarterly in July, October, January,
and April. Additional meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the
president or a majority, of the board.
   B.   Notice of a board meeting shall be given in writing to each member of
the board at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time set for the
meeting. Additionally, notice of the meeting shall be posted in a conspicuous
place in the police department not less than twenty-four (24) hours prior to
any board meeting.
   C.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-6-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of trustees of the police pension fund, a.k.a. police pension board,
of the village shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To take any, and all action to convey to the Police Officers' Pension
Investment Fund, as established and defined in P.A. 101-0610, all monies
donated, paid, or assessed for the relief or pensioning of disabled,
superannuated, and retired members of the police department, their widows,
minor children, and dependent parents. All such monies shall be placed by the
treasurer of the Village to the credit of the fund subject to the order of the
board of trustees of the police pension fund.
   B.   To order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits provided
by Article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code, including but not limited to
adjudicating and awarding disability benefits, retirement benefits, survivor
benefits and to issue refunds in accordance with 40 ILCS 5/3-124.3, and to
issue certificates signed by its president and secretary to the persons
entitled thereto of the amount ordered paid to such persons from the fund,
which certificate shall state the purpose of the payment.
   C.   To submit annually to the Village Board of Trustees at the close of the
Village's fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to benefits from the fund,
stating the amount of the payments and their purpose, as ordered by the board.
It shall also include items of income accrued to the fund during the fiscal
year. Such lists shall be signed by the secretary and president of the board of
trustees of the police pension fund and attested under oath. No resolution or
order for the payment of money shall be valid unless approved by a majority of,
the members of the board, and any order for such payment shall be signed by the
president and secretary of the board.
   D.   To maintain an account, including an interest earning account, for the
purposes of benefit payments and other reasonable expenses as set forth in 40
ILCS 5/3-132.1.
   E.   To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it, upon all matters
connected with the administration of this chapter, in the manner provided by
law for the taking of testimony before the circuit court. The president or any
member of the board of trustees of the police pension fund may administer oaths
to such witnesses.
   F.   To accept donations by gift, grant, transfer, or bequest, any money,
real estate, or personal property. Such money and the proceeds from the sale of
or the income from such real estate or personal property shall be paid into The
Police Officers' Pension Investment Fund.
   G.   To appoint a clerk and define the duties of a clerk. No person drawing
a pension under this chapter shall be employed by the board of trustees of the
police pension fund.
   H.   To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses
including clerk hire, printing, and witness fees.
   I.   To keep a public record of all its proceedings.
   J.   To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter, which shall be published by the board of trustees
of the police pension fund and copies transmitted from time to time to all
pensioners and contributors. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-2021)
2-6-5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
The board of trustees of the police pension fund, a.k.a. the police pension
board, of the Village shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   The Village shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of
trustees of the police pension fund, a.k.a. the police pension board, in order,
to assist the board with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to
be conveyed to the director of the finance department for appropriate response
by the Village. Neither the board of trustees of the police pension fund nor
any of its members shall give direction to any member of the Village staff.
Unless otherwise set forth herein or established by Illinois state statutes,
all recommendations of the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall
be referred to the Village Board of Trustees for consideration and
implementation by the Village.
   B.   Except as specifically stated in this chapter, the board of trustees of
the police pension fund shall not have the authority to make any expenditure or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the Village, without the express prior
approval of the President and Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2021-O-20, 12-6-
2021)
TITLE 3
FINANCE AND TAXATION
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL FINANCE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Fiscal Year
3-1-2: Tax Levy Ordinance
3-1-3: Deposit And Withdrawal Of Village Funds
3-1-4: Indebtedness
3-1-5: Bills
3-1-6: Annual Audit
3-1-7: Collection Of Fines Or Charges
3-1-1: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year of the Village shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on
April 30 of the following year. (1990 Code §11.001)
3-1-2: TAX LEVY ORDINANCE 1 :
Not sooner than ten (10) days after the publication of the annual budget, a tax
levy ordinance shall be enacted, as required by law, levying such taxes as may
be needed to meet the anticipated expenses of the coming year, together with
such taxes as may be required to meet outstanding bond issues, or for purposes
payable from special taxes properly authorized. A certified copy of the tax
levy ordinance shall be filed with the County Clerk not later than the second
Tuesday in December. Such ordinance shall show the total budgeted for each
item, and the amount of tax levied therefor. (1990 Code §11.003; amd. 2011
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title for budget provisions.
3-1-3: DEPOSIT AND WITHDRAWAL OF VILLAGE FUNDS:
   A.   Depository Designated: The Village does hereby appoint and designate
Elgin State Bank, a branch of St. Charles Bank & Trust, a Wintrust Company (or
its successor), as a depository of funds, including but not limited to
investments, deposits, withdrawals and all other manner of financial
transactions as said depository may be requested to perform on behalf of the
Village.
   B.   Authorized Officials: The President and Finance Director or Clerk are
