designated as the proper parties to effectuate withdrawals and sign checks,
acting singularly. The Finance Director is authorized to establish policies
relating to such executions.
   C.   Transfers And Investment Of Funds: The Finance Director or designee
shall make transfers and direct investments of funds of the Village within and
among accounts standing in the name of the Village or hereinafter so created.
The Finance Director is further authorized to make investments with any firm,
fund or institution approved of by the Village Board through ordinance,
resolution, motion, or through inclusion in an approved investment plan or
budget. (Ord. 2018-O-21, 8-20-2018)
3-1-4: INDEBTEDNESS:
No indebtedness shall be incurred, excepting such indebtedness as may be
payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue or from a
designated specified source, unless there is a prior appropriation out of which
indebtedness could be paid as provided by statute; provided, that during the
first quarter of any fiscal year, before the enactment of the current annual
budget, the Village may operate under the annual budget of the preceding year.
(1990 Code §11.004; amd. 2011 Code)
3-1-5: BILLS:
   A.   Approval Required: All bills payable by the Village, other than for the
payment of salaries established by the Board of Trustees, shall be submitted to
the Board of Trustees for approval before payment. (1990 Code §11.006)
   B.   Payment; Warrants Required: The Finance Director shall pay out money in
payment of all bills, or for salaries, or for any other purpose only upon
warrants signed by the Village President and Village Clerk as provided by
statute. Such warrants shall designate the items to be paid and funds from
which they are to be paid.
   C.   Process for Bill and Warrant Payment in the Event of Meeting
Cancellation: In the event that the Village cancels or fails to convene one or
more meetings of the Village Board of Trustees, Village staff are authorized
and directed to continue normal Village operations and the payment of expenses
in the fashion described below, without the requirement of further prior
authorization or warrant list approval by the Village Board:
      1.   Prior to the payment of expenses, the warrant list shall be prepared
in the ordinary course and shall be circulated to the Village Board (via e-
Mail) and Village President, at least forty-eight hours in advance of issuance
of payment.
      2.   The warrant list shall only be paid with the approval of the Village
President, Village Manager and Finance Director.
      3.   Any other expenditure which requires prompt payment outside of the
normal timing of the warrant list may also be presented in this same fashion
and shall require the same approval.
      4.   Any warrant list or expenditure approved under these procedures
shall be presented to the Village Board for ratification at the first regular
Village Board meeting convened thereafter.
      5.   In the event of an expense which is subject to approval at a meeting
that is not held, if staff recommends rejection of the expense (or associated
invoice) in accordance with the Local Government Prompt Payment Act, staff can
administratively implement such rejection in accordance with these same
procedures. (1990 Code § 11.007; amd. 2011 Code; Ord. 2020-O-16, 5-18-2020)
3-1-6: ANNUAL AUDIT:
As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and not later than six
(6) months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all accounts of the Village
made by a competent person authorized to act as an auditor under the laws of
Illinois, to be designated by the Board of Trustees. Copies of such audit
report shall be filed with the Village Clerk and with the Director of the State
Department of Revenue, and in such other places as may be required by law.
(1990 Code §11.008)
3-1-7: COLLECTION OF FINES OR CHARGES:
   A.   Pursuant to the authority conferred by virtue of the Illinois
Constitution, the Illinois Municipal Code and Section 1-2-1 thereof, the
Village hereby authorizes and directs the Finance Director to determine which
fines, penalties, accounts receivable, taxes, user charges, utility charges or
other financial obligations which may be owed the Village in any form or for
any reason (collectively, "Debt") should be considered for any form of
collection. The Finance Director is authorized to submit any such Debt to any
judicial or legal proceeding for collection, or to submit the Debt to a
collection agency approved by the Village Board for any form of civil debt
recovery, or to submit the Debt to any program maintained by any other unit of
government, including but not limited to the State of Illinois, for the purpose
of Debt recovery (including but not limited to the Illinois Debt Recovery
Offset Program). The Finance Director may adopt such rules and regulations as
shall be necessary to effectuate this Section, including but not limited to
evaluating Debt on a per-class basis or case by case basis to determine its
appropriateness for submission to a recovery methodology.
   B.   Any costs incurred by the Village by virtue of such collection
activities or debt recovery program (including but not limited to collection
fees, court costs, legal fees, staff costs, notice costs or any other costs
whatsoever) shall be borne exclusively by the person(s) owing the Debt to the
Village, and shall be assessed against such person(s) as a charge due and owing
to the Village in addition to the underlying Debt. All such charges shall be
required to be fully satisfied and extinguished before the Debt shall be
released (and before any related enforcement methodology shall be released),
except as provided in subsection (C) below.
   C.   The Finance Director and/or Village Manager shall have the authority to
determine or declare that any Debt is not probable of recovery and to write-off
such Debt or discontinue collection methodology. The Finance Director and/or
Village Manager, shall also have the authority to compromise or settle any Debt
or obligation owed the Village, and to accept partial or liquidated payment in
exchange for a partial or complete release thereof. The limit of such authority
for write-off or compromise is one thousand dollars ($1,000). Any individual
Debt in excess of the aforesaid spending authority shall require the approval
of the Village Board to discharge or write-off. With regard to any case or
action implemented as an action or administrative hearing which is prosecuted
by the Village Attorney, the Village Attorney shall be authorized to settle,
resolve or compromise any fine, penalty or other Debt imposed therein, without
limitation, as a matter of prosecutorial discretion. (Ord. 2019-O-29, 8-19-
2019)
CHAPTER 2
BUDGET AND BUDGET OFFICER
SECTION:
3-2-1: State Regulations Adopted; Effect
3-2-2: Budget Officer
3-2-3: Annual Budget
3-2-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED; EFFECT:
The village does hereby adopt the procedures of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/8-2-9.1 through 5/8-2-9.9 as the method for adoption of the annual budget in
lieu of those provisions otherwise specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/8-2-9. The preparation of an annual budget in lieu of the passage of an
appropriation ordinance shall commence with the preparation of a budget for the
fiscal year 2006-2007. (Ord. 2005-40, 12-5-2005)
3-2-2: BUDGET OFFICER:
   A.   Finance Director Serve As: The village finance director shall act as
the budget officer. (Ord. 2005-40, 12-5-2005; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   Bond: The budget officer shall execute a bond to the village in such
sum as provided by law, with such sureties as the president shall approve,
conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of the office.
   C.   Compensation:
      1.   The salary of the village budget officer shall be in an amount set
by the village board.
      2.   The budget officer may hold another elective or appointive office
within the village and may receive compensation for both offices.
   D.   Powers And Duties: The village budget officer shall have such powers
and duties as provided pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.2,
including, but not limited to:
      1.   Permit, encourage and establish the use of efficient planning,
budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting, and other fiscal management
procedures in all municipal departments, commissions, and boards.
      2.   Compile an annual budget in accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-2-9.3.
      3.   Examine all books and records of all municipal departments,
commissions, and boards which relate to monies received by or paid out by the
village, debts and accounts receivable, and amounts owed by or to the village.
      4.   Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no
expenditures are made by the village except as authorized by the budget.
      5.   Pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.6, the Finance Director, with the
approval of the Village Manager, may make amendments, transfers of funding,
revisions or other similar modifications to the Village's budget, provided
that:
         a.   No such revision shall result in monies being transferred from
one Village fund to another fund (all revisions shall be completed only within
a single fund). Transfers between multiple funds shall require the express
approval of the Village Board.
         b.   Where such fund affects a Village department budget, no such
revision shall be made except with the consent and approval of all affected
department heads.
         c.   Revisions shall only be made to expenditures, and no revision or
increase in budgetary assumptions regarding revenues shall be made except with
the express approval of the Village Board.
         d.   No revisions shall be made to the budgets of any Special Service
Area (or related fund) except with the express approval of the Village Board.
(Ord. 2005-40, 12-5-2005; amd. Ord. 2019-O-39, 11-4-2019)
3-2-3: ANNUAL BUDGET:
The village shall make the tentative annual budget available for public
inspection no less than ten (10) days prior to its passage by announcement
thereof at a regular meeting of the board of trustees. The village shall hold a
public hearing on the tentative annual budget, after notice as provided by law.
(Ord. 2005-40, 12-5-2005)

SECTION:

3-3-1: VILLAGE PURCHASING POLICIES:
Purchases and contracts of the Village shall be undertaken in accordance with

CHAPTER 4
TAXES
SECTION:
3-4-1: Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax And Non-- Home Rule
Municipal Service Occupation Tax
3-4-2: Use Tax
3-4-3: Replacement Vehicle Tax
3-4-4: Utility Tax
3-4-1: NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX AND NON-HOME RULE
MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax And Non-Home Rule
Municipal Service Occupation Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all
persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other
than an item of tangible personal property titled and registered with an agency
of this State's government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one
percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such
business while this section is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all
persons engaged in this municipality in the business of making sales of
service, at the rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of all tangible
personal property transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of
service. This "Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax" and this
"Non-Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax" may not be imposed on tangible
personal property taxed at the rate of one percent (1%) under the Retailers'
Occupation Tax and the Service Occupation Tax Act. The imposition of these non-
home rule taxes is in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Sections
8-11-1.1, 8-11-1.2, 8-11-1.3 and 8-11-1.4 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65
ILCS 5/8-11-1.1, 8-11-1.2, 8-11-1.3 and 8-11-1.4).
   B.   Collection By State: The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties
that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by
the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 97-5, 9-16-1997; amd. Ord. 2024-O-07, 4-1-2024)
3-4-2: USE TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using, in the village, any item
of tangible personal property which is purchased at retail from a retailer, and
which is titled or registered with any agency of this state's government, at
the rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of such tangible personal
property, as "selling price" is defined in the Illinois use tax act 1 . Such
tax shall be collected from persons whose Illinois address for titling or
registration purposes given as being in the village and upon such property
sited within the village. (Ord. 97-5, 9-16-1997; amd. 2011 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.
3-4-3: REPLACEMENT VEHICLE TAX:
A replacement vehicle tax of fifty dollars ($50.00) is hereby imposed on any
"motor vehicle", as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-146,
purchased by or on behalf of an insurance company to replace the vehicle of an
insured person in settlement of a total loss claim in the village. (Ord. 97-5,
9-16-1997)
3-4-4: UTILITY TAX:
   A.   Definitions: For taxes imposed by subsection B of this section, the
following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them by this subsection:
   PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, limited
liability company, municipal corporation, the state or any of its political
subdivisions, any state university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee,
conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
   PERSON MAINTAINING A PLACE OF BUSINESS IN THIS STATE: Any person having or
maintaining within this state, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate,
an office, generation facility, distribution facility, transmission facility,
sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent, or other
representative operating within this state under the authority of the person or
its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of
business or agent or other representative is located in this state permanently
or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is
licensed or qualified to do business in this state.
   PURCHASE AT RETAIL: Any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for
purposes of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the
use of electricity by a "public utility", as defined in section 8-11-2 of the
Illinois municipal code, directly in the generation, production, transmission,
delivery or sale of electricity.
   PURCHASER: Any person who uses or consumes, within the corporate limits of
the village, electricity acquired in a purchase at retail.
   TAX COLLECTOR: The person delivering electricity to the purchaser.
   VILLAGE: Village of Pingree Grove, Illinois.
   B.   Tax Imposed; Rates: Pursuant to section 8-11-2 of the Illinois
municipal code and any and all other applicable authority, a tax is imposed
upon the privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at
retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the village at the
following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser:
Kilowatt Hours Used Or Consumed In A Month Cost Per Kilowatt Hour
                                           (Cents)
Kilowatt Hours Used Or Consumed In A Month Cost Per Kilowatt Hour
                                           (Cents)
For the first 2,000                        0.61
For the next 48,000                        0.40
For the next 50,000                        0.36
For the next 400,000                       0.35
For the next 500,000                       0.34
For the next 2,000,000                     0.32
For the next 2,000,000                     0.315
For the next 5,000,000                     0.31
For the next 10,000,000                    0.305
All in excess of 20,000,000                0.30
 
   C.   Tax Is Additional: The tax is in addition to all taxes, fees and other
revenue measures imposed by the village, the state or any other political
subdivision of the state.
   D.   Effective Dates Of Tax: The tax shall be imposed with respect to the
use or consumption of electricity by residential customers beginning with the
first bill issued on or after November 1, 1997; and with respect to the use or
consumption of electricity by nonresidential customers, beginning with the
first bill issued to such customers for delivery services in accordance with
section 16-104 of the public utilities act 1 , or the first bill issued to such
customers on or after January 1, 2001, whichever issuance occurs sooner.
   E.   Collection Of Tax:
      1.   Collection; Tax A Debt: Subject to the provisions of subsection G of
this section regarding the delivery of electricity to resellers, the tax
imposed under this section shall be collected from purchasers by the person
maintaining a place of business in this state who delivers electricity to such
purchasers. This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser to the person who
delivers the electricity to the purchaser and is recoverable at the same time
and in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the electricity.
      2.   Uncollectible Amounts: Any tax required to be collected by this
subsection, and any tax in fact collected, shall constitute a debt owed to the
village by the person delivering the electricity; provided, that the person
delivering the electricity shall be allowed credit for such tax related to
deliveries of electricity, the charges for which are written off as
uncollectible; and provided further, that if such charges are thereafter
collected, the delivering supplier shall be obligated to remit such tax.
      3.   Administrative Costs Added: Persons delivering electricity shall
collect the tax from the purchaser by adding such tax to the gross charge for
delivering the electricity. Persons delivering the electricity shall also be
authorized to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three percent (3%) of
the tax they collect to reimburse them for their expenses incurred in keeping
records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax and
supplying data to the village upon request. For purposes of this subsection,
any partial payment of a billed amount not specifically identified by the
purchaser shall be deemed to be for the delivery of electricity.
   F.   Tax Remittance And Return:
      1.   Tax Return Required: Every tax collector shall, on a monthly basis,
file a return in a form prescribed by the village. The return and accompanying
remittance shall be due on or before the last day of the month following the
month during which the tax is collected.
      2.   Payment Of Tax: If the person delivering electricity fails to
collect the tax from the purchaser, then the purchaser shall file a return in a
form prescribed by the village and pay the tax directly to the village on or
before the last day of the month following the month during which the
electricity is used or consumed.
   G.   Resales:
      1.   Restrictions: Electricity that is delivered to a person in the
village shall be considered to be for use and consumption by that person unless
the person receiving the electricity has an active resale number issued by the
village and furnishes that number to the person who delivers the electricity,
and certifies to that person that the sale is either entirely or partially
nontaxable as a sale for resale.
      2.   Resale Number: If a person who receives electricity in the village
claims to be an authorized reseller of electricity, that person shall apply to
the village for a resale number. The applicant shall state facts showing why it
is not liable for the tax imposed by this section on any purchases of
electricity and shall furnish such additional information as the village may
reasonably require.
      3.   Approval; Assignment Of Number: Upon approval of the application,
the village shall assign a resale number to the applicant and shall certify the
number to the applicant.
      4.   Failure To Pay Tax; Cancel Number: The village may cancel the resale
number of any person if the person fails to pay any tax payable under this
section for electricity used or consumed by the person, or if the number: a)
was obtained through misrepresentation; or b) is no longer necessary because
the person has discontinued making resales.
      5.   Reseller Conditions:
         a.   If a reseller has acquired electricity partly for use or
consumption and partly for resale, the reseller shall pay the tax imposed by
this section directly to the village pursuant to subsection B of this section
on the amount of electricity that the reseller uses or consumes, and shall
collect the tax pursuant to subsection E of this section, and remit the tax
pursuant to subsection F1 of this section on the amount of electricity
delivered by the reseller to a purchaser.
         b.   Any person who delivers electricity to a reseller having an
active resale number and complying with all other conditions of this section
shall be excused from collecting and remitting the tax on any portion of the
electricity delivered to the reseller; provided, that the person reports to the
village the total amount of electricity delivered to the reseller and such
other information that the village may reasonably require.
   H.   Books And Records: Every tax collector and every taxpayer required to
pay the tax imposed by this section shall keep accurate books and records of
its business or activity, including contemporaneous books and records denoting
the transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability
under this section. The books and records shall be subject to and available for
inspection at all times during business hours of the day.
   I.   Credits For Erroneous Payments: If it shall appear that an amount of
tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this section,
whether as result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount
shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this section
from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided, that no amount
erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim
therefor shall be so credited. If a taxpayer under this section is unable to
use a credit authorized by this section solely because the tax imposed by this
section has been replaced by the tax imposed under the kilowatt hour tax, then
the taxpayer may apply such credit against any tax due under the kilowatt hour
tax.
   J.   Statute Of Limitations: No action to recover any amount of tax due
under the provisions of this section shall be commenced after the expiration of
three (3) years after the due date of such tax.
   K.   Compliance With State And Federal Laws: Notwithstanding any other
provision of this section, the tax shall not be imposed if and to the extent
that imposition or collection of the tax would violate the constitution or
statutes of the United States or the constitution of the state.
   L.   Violation; Penalties: Any taxpayer who fails to make a return, or who
makes a fraudulent return, or who wilfully violates any of the provisions of
this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, in addition, shall be liable in a
civil action for the amount of tax due. (2011 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 220 ILCS 5/16-104.
CHAPTER 5
PROFESSIONAL FEE REIMBURSEMENT
SECTION:
3-5-1: Development Expense Reimbursement
3-5-1: DEVELOPMENT EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT:
   A.   The Village of Pingree Grove seeks to encourage the development and
redevelopment of properties within its corporate limits, and seeks to encourage
the annexation and development of properties within its boundary line
agreements or eligible areas to annex. However, the Village requires, as a
condition of development or consideration, that the applicant seeking relief
pay and incur all costs or expenses incurred by the Village in the review or
consideration of such development or consideration, without regard to whether
the consideration is approved or rejected. This section shall be interpreted to
provide for the required posting of escrow and payment/reimbursement of
Village-incurred expenses on as broad of a development-related scale as
possible.
   B.   Applications for development related projects shall be submitted to the
Village Clerk on a form acceptable to the Clerk. Development related projects
shall mean applications for consideration of annexation, zoning, rezoning,
special use, variation, plan review, planned unit development designation,
conceptual/preliminary/final plat approval, requests for the granting or
approval of an easement, requests for the sale or transfer of Village-owned
real property, or other applications for permission relating to the approval of
development or building related entitlements for real property. In addition,
applications for other considerations received by the Village Clerk or by other
Village staff, including but not limited to building permit applications, may
be submitted to the Clerk for review under this section where deemed necessary
or appropriate based upon the nature of the application or the review required
(e.g., under circumstances where a building permit is reasonably determined to
require review by a licensed civil engineer and where the building permit fee
does not include adequate funding for such review). For purposes of this
section, any submittal seeking a real property related approval or
authorization from the Village may be considered to be an application.
   C.   Upon receipt of an application identified in subsection B of this
section, the Village Clerk shall consult with the Village Engineer, Planner,
Building Code Consultant, Attorney and Finance Director to ascertain the type
and nature of fees that are likely to be incurred in the review of the request.
Fees which are eligible for consideration under this section include any fees
that the Village may incur in the review, including but not limited to:
professional review fees of engineers, architects, planners, Building Code
officials, attorneys, financial consultants or other parties; expense
reimbursement; publication, postage or printing costs; costs associated with
compensating elected or appointed officials for the conduct of any public
meeting scheduled for the sole or partial purpose of reviewing a given
consideration; costs of document preparation or recording; costs of
investigation or due diligence; third party costs not identified above;
extraordinary or overtime Village staff costs incurred in processing the
application; and any other direct cost, financial cost or penalty, or
reimbursement obligation of the Village which is attributable to the
consideration. The Village Clerk shall compile an estimate of the fees to be
incurred in review of the consideration.
   D.   The Village Clerk shall then present the applicant (party bringing
forward the consideration) with a Professional Fee Reimbursement Agreement
("agreement") in form and content acceptable to the Clerk and Village Attorney,
along with the estimate of costs to be incurred. Prior to the initiation of
consideration of the request and prior to the Village incurring such costs, the
applicant shall post with the Village a signed copy of the agreement and shall
post certified funds with the Village in an amount determined by the Village
Clerk and Finance Director as described in subsection D1 of this section. No
application shall be considered complete and no consideration shall be advanced
for review or potential approval until the agreement and escrow are posted with
the Village. No payment shall be accepted under protest. The provisions of this
section shall supersede any conflicting ordinance, code or regulation that
would otherwise constrain or create a timeline for consideration or review of
an application. In the alternative, the Village Clerk may advance the
consideration for review with a negative recommendation, based upon the
applicant's failure to comply with the provisions of this section.
      1.   In the event that the estimate of costs is less than five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00), the applicant shall post the entire cost estimate. In the
event that the estimate of costs is between five thousand dollars ($5,000.00)
and thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), the Village Clerk and Finance
Director are authorized to establish an appropriate escrow amount that shall be
posted, up to the full amount of the estimate. In the event that the estimate
of costs is in excess of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), the Village
Clerk and Finance Director shall determine an amount, not less than thirty
thousand dollars ($30,000.00), which represents adequate funding to cover any
costs which may be incurred by the Village during the first four (4) months of
review of the consideration. Because the exact amount of costs to be incurred
is incalculable at the time of application, the Clerk and Finance Director are
authorized and directed to make an estimate in their sole and absolute
discretion, inclusive of an adequate buffer for unanticipated costs.
   E.   Upon the posting of the certified funds and agreement with the Clerk,
the Clerk shall provide the funds to the Finance Director, and shall notify the
Village's consultants who shall be involved in the review of the consideration
that they may commence work.
      1.   The Finance Director shall deposit the certified funds in an account
of the Village and shall implement such accounting practices as shall be
necessary to track funds by consideration and expense. Any interest accruing on
the proceeds deposited with the Village shall be retained by the Village.
      2.   Any person hired or utilized by the Village to perform review
services on a consideration subject to development expense reimbursement under
this section shall segregate all costs and expenses relating to such
consideration and shall invoice such expenses on separate invoice to the
Village of Pingree Grove. All such invoices shall be submitted within thirty
(30) days of the date of incurring the expense, unless otherwise authorized by
the Finance Director.
      3.   Upon receipt of an invoice for reimbursement, the Finance Director
shall, after obtaining any required Village Board approval, pay such invoice
out of the escrowed funds maintained by the Village. A copy of the invoice for
the expense reimbursed out of escrow shall be provided to the applicant at the
time of reimbursement (no more frequently than monthly), along with a statement
of the current level of funding maintained in escrow.
      4.   The Finance Director shall be authorized to impose a Village
administrative fee of not more than five percent (5%) of the total of all
amounts reimbursed through escrow payments, with such fee being payable to the
Village as reimbursement for the costs of administering the escrow and the
process outlined under this section.
      5.   The Finance Director shall monitor the level of funding maintained
in escrow to ensure it is adequate to cover all fees anticipated to be
incurred. In the event additional funding is required, the Finance Director or
Clerk shall notify the applicant of the requirement to post additional funds in
an amount determined by the Finance Director or Clerk to be adequate. This
process (requiring additional escrowed funds) may be repeated multiple times.
The process for determining the additional amount to be paid into escrow shall
be based upon an abbreviated version of the consideration described in
subsection D1 of this section.
   F.   In the event that an applicant at any time fails to adhere to the
obligations of this section or the requirement to post a signed agreement, an
escrow, or to post additional funding to an escrow where required herein, the
Village Clerk shall immediately notify all parties working on behalf of the
Village in the review of the consideration, and all such parties shall cease
incurring expense or further review of the consideration. In the alternative,
the Village Clerk may advance the consideration for review with a negative
recommendation, based upon the applicant's failure to comply with the
provisions of this section.
   G.   Upon the completion of any consideration and all processes associated
therewith, the Village Clerk shall inquire with appropriate parties as to
whether the escrow should be terminated or should be maintained. In the event
that the escrow related to a preliminary process (e.g., review of a concept
plan) and there is further process contemplated in the immediate future, the
escrow shall be maintained pending those further considerations and compliance
with the terms of this section. In the alternative, should the inquiry
determine that the consideration is fully complete and all expenses associated
therewith have been fully reimbursed, any remaining proceeds held in escrow
shall be reimbursed to the applicant or a designee thereof. Prior to
reimbursement, the Clerk or Finance Director shall confirm with all parties
undertaking review of the consideration on behalf of the Village that all
invoices have been submitted and all costs have been fully reimbursed. In the
event that the applicant is a debtor to the Village on any expense, the
remaining proceeds held in escrow may be applied by the Village against such
debt, in the sole and absolute discretion of the Finance Director.
   H.   An applicant may request termination of the agreement and refund of the
escrow at any time, by submitting a written request for the same to the Village
Clerk. Such a written request shall constitute an abandonment of the
consideration and a voluntary withdrawal of the request for approval contained
therein. Upon receipt of such a request, the Clerk shall notify all parties
working on behalf of the Village in the review of the consideration, all such
parties shall cease incurring expense or further review of the consideration,
and all such parties shall submit invoices for any outstanding costs or
expenses within thirty (30) days. At that point, the escrow shall be closed out
pursuant to subsection G of this section.
   I.   The failure of the Village to require strict compliance with any
provision hereof, or the failure to require implementation of an agreement and
escrow at the inception of any given consideration, shall not constitute a
waiver of the provisions hereof. (Ord. 2017-O-20, 10-2-2017)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE SERVICE ACCOUNTS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Created
3-6-2: Order Of Application Of Payments
3-6-3: Failure To Pay; Termination And Reinstatement Of Services
3-6-4: Option Of Converting Charges To Ordinance Violation
3-6-5: Preexisting Charges
3-6-6: Billing Procedures
3-6-1: CREATED:
The finance director is hereby authorized to create individual village service
accounts for each user of village services. Said accounts shall consolidate all
commonly used village services including, but not limited to, water and sewer
use billing pursuant to this code, garbage pick up pursuant to this code or
agreement, building permit and inspection fees, ordinance violation/parking
citations and any applicable fines and penalties therefor, dog or pet
registration/fees, and any other fees, charges, surcharges, interest thereupon,
or other costs whatsoever due and owing from any user of village services to
the village. For purposes of this chapter, a single user account shall be
established for each individual property in the village, and the charges or
expenses applicable to any person who resides at such property or vehicle
registered to such property's address shall be chargeable to the property's
service account. (Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010)
3-6-2: ORDER OF APPLICATION OF PAYMENTS:
When processing payments received for a village service account, the village
shall apply all payments in the following order:
   A.   All outstanding penalties and fines for violations of village codes and
ordinances;
   B.   Garbage pick up;
   C.   Building permit or inspection fees;
   D.   Any charges associated with abating any public nuisance or mowing
weeds/grass that exceeds the height permitted under this code (regardless of
whether the village has filed for a lien and/or obtained a judgment for such
expenses);
   E.   Dog/pet registration and related fees;
   F.   Fees charged for responses to false alarms pursuant to village
ordinance;
   G.   Interest, late payment penalties, or other similar fees and surcharges;
   H.   Any outstanding amounts for other obligations to the village other than
a charge enumerated herein;
   I.   Water service reinstatement charges; and
   J.   Water/sewer service and use charges. (Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010)
3-6-3: FAILURE TO PAY; TERMINATION AND REINSTATEMENT OF SERVICES:
   A.   A failure to pay any amounts due under a village service account shall
entitle the village to cease provision of any or all village services,
including suspension or termination of water service.
   B.   Prior to ceasing all village services, the village shall comply with
the shutoff procedures established within this code, regardless of whether the
basis for the shutoff is due to a failure to pay amounts due for water/sewer
bills, or due for other expenses or charges payable to the village.
   C.   When village services are terminated for a specific property based upon
a failure to make full payment of amounts outstanding on a village service
account within the time specified under this code or applicable village
procedures, prior to the reinstatement of services to said property, the
village may demand full satisfaction of all outstanding charges on the village
service account for that property, without regard to changes in the ownership
or occupancy of such property. (Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010)
3-6-4: OPTION OF CONVERTING CHARGES TO ORDINANCE VIOLATION:
Upon request by any party charged with a parking citation or other violation of
this code, said violation shall be converted to an ordinance violation citation
prosecuted by the village in court in lieu of appearing as a charge on said
person's village service account. (Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010)
3-6-5: PREEXISTING CHARGES:
Immediately after the effective date hereof, any person with preexisting
charges that are to be applied to a village service account shall be provided
with notice of said charges and shall be given a thirty (30) day period to pay
all such charges, in full, without said charges being included in the charges
on the village service account. (Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010)
3-6-6: BILLING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Periodic Billing:
      1.   The village shall issue bi-monthly invoices for charges against
individual village service accounts for water and sewer utility services
provided over the two month period preceding the first day of the present
billing month. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event that the village
determines any charge was inaccurate or otherwise failed to be placed on an
invoice for any reason, it may thereafter be placed on a subsequent invoice,
and the failure of the charge to appear on the first invoice after the charge
was incurred shall not be a defense to payment.
      2.   Invoices for village service accounts shall be payable on the date
indicated on the face of the invoice, which shall be a business day not more
than thirty (30) nor less than fifteen (15) days from the billing date of the
invoice.
      3.   Any invoice not paid in full by the date indicated on the face of
the invoice (the “Due Date”) shall be subject to the mailing of a late notice.
A late fee of ten percent (10%) of the face value of any unpaid account balance
shall be charged after the Due Date and not later than the third business day
after the Due Date. The failure of the village to dispatch a late notice shall
not serve as waiver of the charges or late fee associated with the invoice.
      4.   Any invoice not paid in full by the date which is not less than
forty (40) days from the mailing date of the invoice, will result in the
issuance of a final disconnection notice and a delinquency fine in the amount
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) added to the balance of the affected account.
The final disconnection notice will be in the form of a hang tag/door hanger,
delivered to the affected property not less than five (5) days in advance of
discontinuance of service. Failure to make full payment within the five (5) day
period from which the final notice was posted shall be cause for the village to
shut off water supply to the affected property.
      5.   When the water supply to a property is shut off due to non- payment,
the account holder/property owner(s) shall pay a water supply service
restoration fee in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) prior to service
restoration.
         a.   Water supply service restoration is performed by the village
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and two o'clock (2:00) P.M.,
Monday through Friday. Connections performed outside of these hours will be
charged an additional seventy-five dollar ($75.00) service fee (one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) total for an after-hours restoration). The account
holder/property owner, or an adult designee, must be present in the home during
service restoration.
      6.   When the water supply to a property is turned off, it shall be
unlawful for any person other than a village employee to attempt to turn said
water supply back on, or to tamper with the water meter or water supply valve
(s). A violation of the subsection A6 is punishable by a fine of not less than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
      7.   The village may file a lien for delinquent charges on a village
service account based upon the terms of the then current village service
account billing policy. Any such lien shall include the village cost of
preparing and filing the lien, pursuant to the then current village service
account billing policy.
      8.   The village finance director shall be authorized to establish a
village service account billing policy and to amend such policy without further
notice or approval.
      9.   Any person who submits a void, false, fraudulent, postdated, stale
or otherwise invalid negotiable instrument or check for payment of a village
service account invoice, or whose check is returned as lacking sufficient
funds, shall be subject to the fees contemplated by the village service account
billing policy, which may include imposition of the maximum fine permitted
under the then current law, in addition to referral for criminal prosecution
where appropriate and in addition to payment of any fines or NSF fees that the
village incurs. The only acceptable forms of payment for a village invoice are
U.S. dollars, personal checks with the address of the property listed as the
permanent address of the payor, bank checks, money orders, valid credit cards
or certified checks. The village shall refuse to accept personal checks from
any person who has tendered a false, fraudulent or NSF check within the past
twelve (12) month rolling period.
   B.   Billing Disputes:
      1.   Any person who disputes a charge appearing on a village service
account may appeal the charge by submitting a written appeal to the village
finance director within five (5) business days of the face date of the first
invoice on which such charge appears. Any such appeals shall be reviewed by the
village, and the village shall respond to such appeals in writing.
      2.   Any person who believes that his water meter is inaccurate may
request to have the water meter tested for accuracy. A water meter operating
within a five percent (5%) margin of error shall be deemed accurate for
purposes of this chapter. Regardless of the accuracy of the meter, the party
requesting the testing shall be responsible for all costs of testing the meter.
In the event the meter is inaccurate by more than five percent (5%), the person
requesting the testing shall have the option of replacing the meter, and if the
meter is replaced, the person requesting the testing shall be responsible for
the full cost of replacement (including labor and materials).
   C.   Accountability For Invoices:
      1.   Any person who is listed as a responsible party with respect to any
property in the village shall be accountable for all such properties for which
they are listed, and each property may be cross billed in the village’s sole
and absolute discretion (i.e., if one person is the owner of multiple
properties and fails to pay the invoice associated with any one of those
properties, all of the properties may be subject to the procedures described
above for delinquent payments).
      2.   Any person listed as a responsible party with respect to a property
in the village that has delinquent charges as noted above shall be ineligible
to establish a new village service account or new village water service until
all delinquent amounts are paid in full.
      3.   In addition to the foregoing, the village shall track village
service accounts by property. Should a property be sold to a third party, prior
to the third party establishing a new village service account and/or
establishing village water service to the property, all delinquent amounts
relating to that property must be paid in full regardless of the identity of
the person under whose ownership the delinquent charges were incurred.
(Ord. 2010-12, 7-6-2010; amd. Ord. 2022-O-32, 12-19-2022; Ord. 2024-O-06, 4-1-
2024)
CHAPTER 7
SIMPLIFIED MUNICIPAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: Tax Imposed
3-7-3: Collection Of Tax By Retailers
3-7-4: Returns To Department
3-7-5: Resellers
3-7-6: Severability
3-7-7: Effective Date; Rate Change
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The definition of those terms defined at 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 636/5-7
(as such statute may be modified, amended or updated) are adopted by reference,
as if restated in full herein. Any future amendment to that section shall be
considered to have been adopted in full, by reference. "Municipality" shall
refer to the village of Pingree Grove, Kane County, Illinois. (Ord. 2011-27, 8-
15-2011)
3-7-2: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon any and all the following acts or privileges:
   A.   The act or privilege of originating in such municipality or receiving
in such municipality intrastate telecommunications by a person at a rate of
three percent (3%) of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at
retail from a retailer. To prevent actual multimunicipal taxation of the act or
privilege that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon
proof that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another municipality on that event,
shall be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by
this section to the extent of the amount of the tax properly due and paid in
the municipality that was not previously allowed as a credit against any other
municipal tax.
   B.   The act or privilege of originating in such municipality or receiving
in such municipality interstate telecommunications by a person at a rate of
three percent (3%) of the gross charge for such telecommunications purchased at
retail from a retailer. To prevent actual multistate or multimunicipal taxation
of the act or privilege that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any
taxpayer, upon proof that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another state or
municipality in this state on such event, shall be allowed a credit against any
tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this section to the extent of the
amount of such tax properly due and paid in such other state or such tax
properly due and paid in a municipality in this state which was not previously
allowed as a credit against any other state or local tax in this state.
   C.   However, such tax is not imposed on the act or privilege to the extent
such act or privilege may not, under the constitution and statutes of the
United States, be made the subject of taxation by municipalities in this state.
(Ord. 2011-36, 10-3-2011)
   D.   The telecommunications tax currently imposed by this section is done so
under the authority granted by 35 Illinois Compiled Statues 636/5-10, and all
current and future taxes levied under this section, including rate increases,
shall be in compliance with the language set forth in that statute, hereby
incorporated into this code as follows:
The corporate authorities shall have the authority to tax any and all of the
following acts or privileges:
      1.   The act or privilege of originating in such municipality or
receiving in such municipality intrastate telecommunications by a person. To
prevent actual multimunicipal taxation of the act or privilege that is subject
to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon proof that the taxpayer
has paid a tax in another municipality on that event, shall be allowed a credit
against any tax enacted pursuant to or authorized by this section to the extent
of the amount of the tax properly due and paid in the municipality that was not
previously allowed as a credit against any other municipal tax.
      2.   The act or privilege of originating in such municipality or
receiving in such municipality interstate telecommunications by a person. To
prevent actual multistate or multimunicipal taxation of the act or privilege
that is subject to taxation under this subsection, any taxpayer, upon proof
that the taxpayer has paid a tax in another state or municipality in this state
on such event, shall be allowed a credit against any tax enacted pursuant to or
authorized by this section to the extent of the amount of such tax properly due
and paid in such other state or such tax properly due and paid in a
municipality in this state which was not previously allowed as a credit against
any other state or local tax in this state. (Ord. 2012-02, 3-19-2012)
3-7-3: COLLECTION OF TAX BY RETAILERS:
   A.   The tax authorized by this chapter shall be collected from the taxpayer
by a retailer maintaining a place of business in this state and shall be
remitted by such retailer to the department. Any tax required to be collected
pursuant to or as authorized by this chapter and any such tax collected by such
retailer and required to be remitted to the department shall constitute a debt
owed by the retailer to the state. Retailers shall collect the tax from the
taxpayer by adding the tax to the gross charge for the act or privilege of
originating or receiving telecommunications when sold for use, in the manner
prescribed by the department. The tax authorized by this chapter shall
constitute a debt of the taxpayer to the retailer until paid, and, if unpaid,
is recoverable at law in the same manner as the original charge for such sale
at retail. If the retailer fails to collect the tax from the taxpayer, then the
taxpayer shall be required to pay the tax directly to the department in the
manner provided by the department.
   B.   Whenever possible, the tax authorized by this chapter shall, when
collected, be stated as a distinct item separate and apart from the gross
charge for telecommunications. (Ord. 2011-27, 8-15-2011)
3-7-4: RETURNS TO DEPARTMENT:
On or before the last day of the first month after this chapter takes effect,
and on or before the last day of every month thereafter, the tax imposed under
this chapter on telecommunication retailers shall be returned with appropriate
forms and information as required by the department pursuant to section 5-50 of
the Illinois simplified municipal telecommunications tax act 1  and any
accompanying rules and regulations created by the department to implement the
act. (Ord. 2011-27, 8-15-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 636/5-50.
3-7-5: RESELLERS:
   A.   If a person who originates or receives telecommunications claims to be
a reseller of such telecommunications, such person shall apply to the
department for a resale number. Such applicant shall state facts which will
show the department why such applicant is not liable for the tax authorized by
this chapter on any of such purchases and shall furnish such additional
information as the department may reasonably require.
   B.   Upon approval of the application, the department shall assign a resale
number to the applicant and shall certify such number to the applicant. The
department may cancel any number which is obtained through misrepresentation,
or which is used to send or receive such telecommunication tax free when such
actions in fact are not for resale, or which no longer applies because of the
person's having discontinued the making of resales.
   C.   Except as provided in this section, the act or privilege of originating
or receiving telecommunications in this state shall not be made tax free on the
grounds of being a sale for resale unless the person has an active resale
number from the department and furnishes that number to the retailer in
connection with certifying to the retailer that any sale to such person is
nontaxable because of being a sale for resale. (Ord. 2011-27, 8-15-2011)
3-7-6: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter, or the application of any provision of this
chapter, is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall
not affect other provisions of this chapter, or their application, that can be
given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its
application. Each unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such
provision, is severable, unless otherwise provided by this chapter. (Ord. 2011-
27, 8-15-2011)
3-7-7: EFFECTIVE DATE; RATE CHANGE:
   A.   Initial Rate: This chapter shall be in full force and effect on and
after its approval, passage and publication in pamphlet form as provided by
law, provided, however, that: 1) sections
3-7-2 and
3-7-3 of this chapter shall take effect for all bills issued on or after
January 1, 2012; 2) the tax provided for herein shall take effect for all bills
issued on or after January 1, 2012; and 3) any amounts due or payable to the
municipality for any tax periods ending prior to the first day of the first
month following the effective date hereof, shall nevertheless remain payable as
if this chapter had not been adopted. The board acknowledges that, by previous
action of the village, there is presently imposed a telecommunications tax at
the rate of one percent (1%); said rate shall remain in effect until January 1,
2012.
   B.   Rate Escalator: The rates imposed under section
3-7-2 of this chapter shall be initially set at three percent (3%) as
contemplated therein. Effective for all bills issued on or after July 1, 2012,
the tax rate imposed under section
3-7-2 of this chapter shall automatically increase to six percent (6%), unless
the village takes future action to amend this chapter and alter the rate
imposed. (Ord. 2011-27, 8-15-2011)
CHAPTER 8
GAS UTILITY TAX
SECTION:
3-8-1: Tax Established
3-8-2: Exemptions
3-8-3: Definitions
3-8-4: Effective Date
3-8-5: Tax Returns
3-8-6: Limitations
3-8-7: Penalties
3-8-8: Severability
3-8-9: Rate Escalator
3-8-1: TAX ESTABLISHED:
A tax is hereby established and levied by the village upon persons engaged in
the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling gas for use or
consumption within the limits of the village and not for resale, at the rate of
three percent (3%) of the gross receipts from such business. The taxes
enumerated in this chapter shall be in addition to the payment of money or
value of products or services furnished to the municipality by the taxpayer as
compensation for the use of its streets, alleys or other public places, or
installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of poles, wires,
pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's business.
(Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-2: EXEMPTIONS:
No taxes authorized by this chapter are imposed with respect to the following,
and as to any such, the provider shall not be required to collect any such
taxes:
   A.   The village and/or transactions originating from any and all village
owned property;
   B.   Any transaction in interstate commerce, or otherwise, to the extent to
which such transaction may not, under the constitution or statutes of the
United States, be made the subject of taxation by the state of Illinois, or any
political subdivision thereof;
   C.   Any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying,
furnishing or selling of gas, for any such transactions as are now or may
become in the future subject to taxation under the provisions of the municipal
retailers' occupation tax act, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1 et seq.;
and
   D.   Any person engaged in a business, or in any privilege, unless the tax
in question has been imposed in like manner and at the same rate upon all
persons engaged in businesses of the same class in the municipality, or
exercising the same privilege, within the village. (Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of the tax enumerated in this chapter the following definitions
shall apply:
GROSS RECEIPTS: The consideration received for distributing, supplying,
furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption and not for resale; and for
all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received
in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every
kind and material and for all services rendered therewith, and shall be
determined without any deduction on account of the cost of transmitting such
gas without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or
commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any
other expenses whatsoever.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, municipal corporation or
political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or
other representative appointed by order of any court. (Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-4: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter and the tax imposed hereunder shall be effective as of the first
day of the first month following passage and approval of this chapter. (Ord.
2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-5: TAX RETURNS:
   A.   Each taxpayer shall make a return to the village treasurer as provided
herein, stating the following information:
      1.   Name.
      2.   Principal place of business.
      3.   Gross receipts during the applicable period.
      4.   Amount of tax to be paid to the village for the period.
      5.   Such other related information as the village may require.
   B.   Returns shall be filed quarterly, and on or before May 31, each
taxpayer shall make said return to the village treasurer for the previous
months of January, February and March; and on or before the last day of each
third month thereafter each taxpayer shall make a like return to the village
treasurer for the corresponding three (3) month period.
   C.   The taxpayer making such return shall, at the time of making such
return, pay to the village treasurer the amount of tax herein imposed; provided
that in connection with any return the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report
and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax
during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts
previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any
differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts.
   D.   If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not
due under the provisions of this chapter, whether as the result of a mistake of
fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax
due, or to become due, under this chapter from the taxpayer who made the
erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three
(3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited. (Ord.
2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-6: LIMITATIONS:
No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this chapter
shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such amount.
(Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-7: PENALTIES:
Any taxpayer who fails to make a return or who makes a fraudulent return, or
who wilfully violates any other provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine as
otherwise provided in this code. In addition, said taxpayer may be subject to a
civil action for recovery of any tax due. (Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-8: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter, or the application of any provision of this
chapter, is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall
not affect other provisions of this chapter, or their application, that can be
given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its
application. Each unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such
provision, is severable, unless otherwise provided by this chapter. (Ord. 2011-
28, 8-15-2011)
3-8-9: RATE ESCALATOR:
The rates imposed under section
3-8-1 of this chapter shall be initially set at three percent (3%) as
contemplated therein. Effective for all bills issued on or after March 1, 2012,
the tax rate imposed under section
3-8-1 of this chapter shall automatically increase to five percent (5%), unless
the village takes future action to amend this chapter and alter the rate
imposed. (Ord. 2011-28, 8-15-2011)
CHAPTER 9
PLACES FOR EATING TAX
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: Tax Imposed
3-9-3: Registration
3-9-4: Books And Records; Inspection; Contents

3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
            The consideration received, valued in money, whether received in money or
            otherwise, including cash, credits, property and services, at a place for eating
            for prepared food furnished at the place for eating. Gross receipts do not
            include amounts paid for federal, state and local taxes, including the tax levied
            by this article, and do not include amounts paid as gratuities for the employees
            of the place for eating.
            A.   Gross receipts shall include consideration as defined herein received for
            food which is prepared by a food or catering business operated within the
            corporate limits of the Village and which is consumed at, or which is intended
            for delivery to and consumption at, a location within the Village.
            B.   Gross receipts shall include consideration as defined herein received for
GROSS       food which is prepared by a food or catering business operated outside the
RECEIPTS:   corporate limits of the Village but which is consumed at, or which is intended
            for delivery to and consumption at, a location within the Village.
            C.   Gross receipts shall not include consideration as defined herein received
            for food which is prepared by a food or catering business operated within the
            corporate limits of the Village and which is consumed at, or which is intended
            for delivery to and consumption at, a location outside the corporate limits of
            the Village.
            D.   Gross receipts shall not include consideration as defined herein for the
            sale of prepared food delivered or sold directly to consumers from automated
            vending machines.
            E.   Gross receipts shall not include consideration, as defined herein, for
            prepared food which is provided to students of cooking classes where no charge is
            made for the prepared food other than the cost of enrollment in the class.
OWNER:      Any person and each person having an ownership interest in or conducting the
            operation of a place for eating.
            Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company,
PERSON or   joint venture, public or private corporation, limited liability company or the
PERSONS:    like, club, fraternal organization, or a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator
            or its representative appointed by order of any court.
            A.   "Places for eating" or "place for eating" means all premises located within
            the corporate limits of the Village where prepared food is sold at retail for
            immediate consumption, whether consumed on the premises or not, and including but
            not limited to such a place with seating provided for consumption of said
PLACES FOR  prepared food on the premises, and whether or not such place for eating is
EATING or   conducted along with any other use in a common premise or business establishment.
PLACE FOR   B.   "Places for eating" or "place for eating" includes, but is not limited to,
EATING:     those establishments commonly called a restaurant, eating place, drive-in
            restaurant, buffet, bakery, banquet facility, cafeteria, café, lunch counter,
            fast food outlet, catering service, coffee shop, diner, sandwich shop, soda
            fountain, bar, cocktail lounge, video gaming establishment, soft drink parlor,
            ice cream parlor, tea room, delicatessen, hotel, motel, or club, or any other
            establishment which sells at retail prepared food for immediate consumption.
            Means and includes any solid, liquid (including both alcoholic and non-alcoholic
PREPARED    liquid), gel, compound, powder or item used or intended to be used for human
FOOD:       internal consumption, whether simple, compound or mixed, and which has been
            prepared for consumption or offered for sale by a place for eating.
            To sell for use or consumption in exchange for a consideration, whether in the
SOLD AT     form of money, credits, barter or any other nature, and not for resale, with said
RETAIL:     transaction being subject to either the Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax (ILCS

            35, Act 1IS §§ I et seq.).

GOVERNMENT:
