   A.   Bond: Prior to the construction of a cable system, the grantee shall
file with the village a performance bond in the amount of fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00).
   B.   Security Fund:
      1.   At the time a franchise is accepted, the grantee shall deposit into
a bank account established by the village and maintain on deposit through the
term of the franchise the sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)
as a common security fund for the faithful performance by the grantee of all
the provisions of the franchise. Interest accrued on this deposit shall be paid
to the grantee on an annual basis.
      2.   Provision shall be made to permit the village to withdraw funds from
the security fund.
      3.   The grantee shall not use the security fund for other purposes and
shall not assign, pledge or otherwise use the security fund as security for any
purpose.
      4.   Within ten (10) days after notice thereto that any amount has been
withdrawn by the village from the security fund pursuant to this subsection,
the grantee shall deposit a sum of money sufficient to restore such security
fund to the required amount. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
   C.   Subscriber Rebates: A grantee is not responsible for failure to provide
adequate service caused by acts of God or acts of nature, strikes, governmental
or military action, or other conditions beyond its control including the lack
of material or parts. Upon interruption of service, except for acts of God or
acts of nature or with express prior permission of the village, the following
shall apply: (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991; amd. 2011 Code)
      1.   Over forty eight (48) hours and up to seven (7) days, a fifty
percent (50%) rebate of one month's fees for all affected subscribers.
      2.   A full month's rebate for any month in which one week or more of the
service is interrupted. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-16: FRANCHISE FEE AND FINANCIAL REPORTING:
   A.   As compensation for permission to use the streets and public ways of
the village for the construction, operation, maintenance, modification, and
reconstruction of a cable system, and for the village costs in establishing a
regulatory program for a grantee, the grantee shall pay to the village each
year an amount equal to five percent (5%) of the grantee's gross annual
receipts, unless a higher amount is approved by federal law.
   B.   No acceptance of the village of any franchise fee shall be construed as
a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the village may have
for further or additional sums payable as a franchise fee or for the
performance of any other obligation of the grantee.
   C.   No later than April 15 of each year, the grantee shall present to the
village an annual report of system finances which shall include gross revenues
from all sources, operating expenses, net income and an end of year balance
sheet. The franchise fee amount shall be derived from this report and shall be
paid with its submission. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-17: OPEN BOOKS AND RECORDS:
Any grantee shall manage all of its operations in accordance with the policy of
totally open books and records, vis-a-vis, the village. The authorized officers
and staff of the village shall have the right to inspect, upon notice, during
normal business hours, all books, records, maps, plans, income tax returns,
financial statements, service complaint logs, performance test results, records
of request for service and other like materials of the grantee that relate to
the operation of the franchise. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-18: VILLAGE RIGHTS:
   A.   Village Rules: The right is hereby reserved to the village to adopt, in
addition to the provisions contained in this chapter and existing applicable
ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the
exercise of its police powers. Such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise,
shall be reasonable and not be in conflict with the rights granted in this
chapter and shall not be in conflict with the laws of the state.
   B.   Use Of System By Village: The village may, during the term of a
franchise, free of charge, where aerial construction exists, maintain upon the
poles of the grantee within the village limits wire and pole fixtures necessary
for a police and fire alarm system; such wires and fixtures to be constructed
and maintained to the satisfaction of the grantee and in accordance with its
specifications.
   C.   Emergency: In the case of any emergency, a grantee shall, upon request
of the village, make available its facilities to the village for emergency use
during any emergency period.
   D.   Inspection: The village may inspect all construction or installation
work during such construction or installation, or at any time after completion
thereof, in order to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter and
all other governing ordinances.
   E.   Liability: The village shall not be liable for any damage occurring to
the property of a grantee caused by employees of the village in the performance
of their duties. The village shall not be liable for the interruption of
service by actions of village employees in the performance of their duties, nor
shall the village be held liable for the failure of a grantee to be able to
perform normal services due to other factors beyond the control of the village.
   F.   No Property Right: Nothing in this chapter shall grant to a grantee any
right of property in the village owned property.
   G.   Construction Approval By Village: A grantee shall not erect any pole,
install any underground lines or conduits, run any line, or make any
attachment, nor shall any construction of any kind be commenced on public
property or within any public or utility easement without the prior approval of
the village, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld; and the village
shall have the right to inspect the construction, operation and maintenance of
the entire cable television system, or any portion thereof, constructed by the
grantee to ensure proper compliance with the terms and conditions set forth in
this chapter.
   H.   Correction Of Defects: In the event a grantee should violate any of the
terms of this regulatory chapter, the village shall immediately give to said
grantee thirty (30) days' written notice to correct such violation; and in the
event the grantee does not make such correction within thirty (30) days from
the receipt of such written notice, the village may make such correction itself
and charge the cost of same to the company, and the village may deduct the cost
thereof from the security fund, or the grantee shall otherwise pay such
charges. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-19: ACCEPTANCE BY GRANTEE:
Any franchise granted under this chapter shall be effective upon written
acceptance of the franchise, along with the proof of insurance and any other
required documents and bonds, being filed with the village clerk. The filing
shall occur within thirty (30) days of the notification of an offer of a
franchise by the village, and the franchise shall continue in force for a
period of fifteen (15) years or such other period as established by the village
from the date of acceptance. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-20: INTERFERENCE WITH OTHER SIGNALS PROHIBITED:
A grantee shall at all times keep its cables and other appurtenances used for
transmitting signals shielded in such a manner that there will be no
interference with signals received by electronic equipment not connected to the
grantee's service. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-21: GRANTEE RULES:
A grantee may promulgate such rules, regulations, terms and conditions
governing the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to
enable the grantee to exercise its rights and perform its obligations under the
franchise and to assure uninterrupted service to all its subscribers. However,
such rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall not be in conflict with the
provisions of this chapter or the laws of the state. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-22: WAIVER OF OBJECTIONS BY VILLAGE:
By the adoption of this chapter, the village expressly waives all objections it
has or may have to the legal rights of the grantee to attach its cables,
equipment and transmission lines to the poles of the village or to the poles of
the public utilities pursuant to the negotiation of an agreement and the
authority of such public utilities to grant such right to the grantee. (Ord.
1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-23: NO RECOURSE BY GRANTEE:
   A.   A grantee shall have no recourse whatsoever against the village for any
loss, cost or expense, or damage arising out of any provisions or requirements
of a franchise or because of the enforcement thereof by the village, or for the
failure of the village to have authority to grant all or any part of the
franchise.
   B.   Grantee expressly acknowledges that in accepting any franchise, it does
so relying on its own investigation and understanding of the power and
authority of the village to grant the franchise.
   C.   By accepting a franchise, a grantee acknowledges that it has not been
induced to enter into the franchise by any understanding or promise or other
statement, whether verbal or written, by or on behalf of the village or by any
other third person concerning any term or condition of the franchise not
expressed herein.
   D.   The grantee further acknowledges, by acceptance of the franchise, that
it has carefully read the terms and conditions hereof and is willing to and
does accept all the risks of the meeting of such terms and conditions and
agrees that in the event of any ambiguity therein or in the event of any
dispute over the meaning thereof, the same shall be construed strictly against
the grantee and in favor of the village. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-24: WORK PERFORMED BY OTHERS:
Grantee shall give prior notice to the village specifying the names and
addresses of any entity, other than the grantee, that performs services
pursuant to the franchise; provided, however, that all provisions of the
franchise remain the responsibility of the grantee. All provisions of any
franchise shall apply to any subcontractor or others performing any work or
services pursuant to the provisions of the franchise. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-25: PUBLICATION COSTS AND LEGAL FEES:
   A.   Grantee shall assume any and all costs of publication for the
publication of notices of any meetings or hearings as may be necessary to
comply with this chapter.
   B.   The grantee shall assume and pay and reimburse to the village all
legal, consultant, technical and auditing fees incurred by the village in
connection with the investigation, negotiation and granting of any franchise or
license to a grantee under the terms of this chapter. Grantee shall assume and
pay and reimburse to the village any and all legal, consultant, technical and
auditing fees and costs incurred by the village to enforce any terms or
provisions of this chapter, whether by institution of suit at law or in equity
in a court of competent jurisdiction or by any other methods utilized to
enforce the terms and provisions contained herein. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-26: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Grantee shall not allow its cable or other operations to interfere with
television reception of others or the operation of the various utilities
serving the village residents.
   B.   No person, whether or not a subscriber to the cable system may
intentionally or knowingly damage, or cause to be damaged, any wire, cable,
conduit, equipment or apparatus of a grantee, or commit any act with intent to
cause such damage, or to tamp, tamper with, or otherwise connect any wire or
device to a wire, cable, conduit, equipment and apparatus, or appurtenances of
a grantee with the intent to obtain a signal or impulse from the cable system
without authorization from or compensation to grantee, or to obtain cable
television or other communications service with intent to cheat or defraud
grantee of any lawful charge to which it is entitled. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-27: AMENDMENTS:
   A.   This chapter may be amended from time to time by the village through
the enactment of amendments hereto.
   B.   This franchise may be amended to incorporate all amendments to the
statutes, rules and regulations of the federal government as they are
promulgated by the federal government. Any provisions herein in conflict with
or preempted by said rules, regulations or statutes shall be superseded. (Ord.
1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-28: SEVERABILITY:
Should any word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or portion of this chapter
and/or a franchise granted hereunder be declared invalid by a court of
competent jurisdiction, such adjudication shall not affect the validity of this
chapter and the franchise as a whole, but shall only affect the portion thereof
declared to be invalid; and the village board hereby expressly states and
declares that it would nonetheless have passed this chapter and granted the
franchise had it known that any such word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph
or portion of this chapter or franchise were invalid. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-29: CONTESTING VALIDITY:
Grantee agrees by acceptance of a franchise that it will not at any time set up
against the village in a claim for proceeding any condition or term of the
franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary or void, or that the village had no power
or authority to make such term or condition, but shall be required to accept
the validity of the terms and conditions of the franchise in their entirety.
(Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-1991)
4-9-30: PENALTIES:
Any violation by a grantee, its vendor, lessee or successor, of any provision
of this chapter or of any provisions of a franchise or any material portion or
portions thereof, or the failure promptly to perform any of the provisions
thereof, shall, after prior written notice is given to the grantee, cause the
grantee to be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) a day for each such violation or offense. At
the option of the village, said fine shall be paid from the security fund until
proper correction is made. The village further reserves the right to otherwise
forfeit or terminate a franchise or to take any other remedial or corrective
action for any violation whatsoever of a franchise or the terms and provisions
of this chapter as otherwise set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 1991-1, 3-19-
1991; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 10
GARAGE SALES
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: Permit Requirements
4-10-3: Duration And Hours Of Sale
4-10-4: Prohibited Conduct
4-10-5: Exemptions
4-10-6: Penalty
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, a "garage sale" (also commonly known as a "yard
sale" or "rummage sale") shall be defined as the sale of tangible, personal or
household property at a property utilized for residential purposes, or on
property zoned at least partially under residential/heritage zoning, which sale
is open to the public, or other similar or related activities which are
commonly defined as a "garage sale". (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009)
4-10-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Fee: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a
garage sale in the village without first applying for and obtaining from the
village a permit to do so to be known as a garage sale permit. The fee for such
permit shall be five dollars ($5.00), or such other amount as the village
manager shall require from time to time.
   B.   Application For Permit: The information to be filed with the permit
application shall be as described below, or such other information as the
village manager shall require from time to time:
      1.   Name of person, association or organization conducting said sale.
      2.   Name of owner of the property on which said sale is to be conducted
if the applicant is other than the owner.
      3.   Location at which the sale is to be conducted.
      4.   Dates of the sale.
      5.   Sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing, indicating: a)
that the information therein given is full and true and known to him or her to
be so; b) that the applicant has read and is familiar with the terms and
requirements of this chapter, and shall comply herewith; and c) an
acknowledgment that, by completing the permit application, the applicant has
consented to the right of entry of village employees and officers upon the
applicant's property at any time during the conduct of the garage sale for the
purpose of verifying compliance with this chapter and any other applicable
ordinances, codes, statutes or regulations.
   C.   Number And Duration Of Permits; Display Required: Such permit can be
issued to each mailing address within the village only twice within a twelve
(12) month period, and no such permit shall be issued for more than three (3)
consecutive calendar days. Each permit issued must be prominently displayed on
the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire
period of the permitted sale.
   D.   Cancellation Of Permit: In the event of a rainout or cancellation of
the sale due to weather, the permittee can notify the village before the start
of the sale to cancel the permit. In this event, the canceled sale will not be
counted against the maximum number of sales in subsection C of this section.
The permit fee for canceled events will not be refunded. Garage sales canceled
after the scheduled start date/time for any reason will be counted against the
maximum number of events. (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009)
4-10-3: DURATION AND HOURS OF SALE:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any
person to conduct or allow the conducting of a garage sale for more than three
(3) consecutive days and only between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to
six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day. (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009)
4-10-4: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   To conduct a garage sale except in accordance with the requirements of
this chapter, and in accordance with a lawfully issued permit.
   B.   To use any sign or display except in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the village zoning ordinance/sign ordinance 1 .
   C.   To place or deposit any items, whether for sale or utilized as
advertisement (including signs), on any village right of way or other public
property.
   D.   To use loudspeakers, music, or other audible methods to advertise the
presence of a garage sale.
   E.   To sell, or to cause or permit to be sold, at a garage sale:
      1.   Any item whose sale, use or possession is prohibited within the
village, county or state.
      2.   Any item whose sale or possession is age restricted within the
village, county or state, including, but not limited to, alcoholic beverages,
tobacco products and food.
      3.   Any item whose purchase or ownership requires a local, state or
federal license, permit or application, including, but not limited to,
firearms, guns and explosive devices.
      4.   Any motor vehicle or item having a sale value in excess of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
      5.   Any new item or item acquired solely for the purpose of resale.
      6.   Any item not owned by the applicant for the garage sale permit.
      7.   Any "weapon", defined herein as including, but not limited to, any
knife, razor, ice pick, gun, BB gun or other device that shoots a projectile,
metal knuckles, explosive of any kind, or any other object normally considered
to be a "weapon". In addition, any other object not normally considered to be a
"weapon" will be classified as such when used to threaten or cause bodily harm.
This subsection E7 includes any look alike objects that may have the appearance
of a weapon or dangerous instrument. For purposes of this chapter, sporting
goods, other than goods which shoot a projectile, shall not be considered a
"weapon". (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-5-8 of this code.
4-10-5: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following
persons or sales:
   A.   Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   B.   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials.
   C.   Any persons selling or advertising for sale an item or items of
personal property which are specifically named or described in the
advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five (5) in number
(provided, that such items shall be available for sale only through the
advertisement, and not via an open display or invitation to the public at the
premises).
   D.   Not for profit organizations, provided they file with the village
manager a request for exception, together with the name of the organization,
proof of its not for profit status, a description of the purpose of the sale,
and such other information as the village manager shall require.
   E.   Community wide garage sales sponsored, sanctioned or authorized by the
village. (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009)
4-10-6: PENALTY:
Any person, association or corporation conducting any garage sale without the
proper permit therefor or who shall violate any of the other terms and
regulations of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2009-20, 7-6-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
TITLE 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL HEALTH AND SANITATION REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-1-1: Acts Endangering Public Health Prohibited
5-1-2: Dangerous Buildings And Structures
5-1-3: Drinking Cups In Public Places
5-1-4: Water Pollution
5-1-5: Stagnant Pools Of Water
5-1-6: Noxious Odors
5-1-7: Dense Smoke
5-1-8: Spitting
5-1-9: Cemeteries And Burials
5-1-10: Public Toilet Facilities
5-1-11: Penalty
5-1-12: Drainage Impediments
5-1-1: ACTS ENDANGERING PUBLIC HEALTH PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to permit or do any act which endangers the public health. (1990
Code §13.108)
5-1-2: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES 1 :
It is unlawful to permit any building, structure, or place to remain in such a
condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. Any such
structure, building, or place is declared to be a nuisance. (1990 Code §13.107)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 10, chapter 6 of this code.
5-1-3: DRINKING CUPS IN PUBLIC PLACES:
It is unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup or cups, dipper or other
similar utensil for the use of more than one person in a public hall, theater,
store, or other place frequented by the public. (1990 Code §13.109)
5-1-4: WATER POLLUTION:
It is unlawful and a nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation to obstruct
or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the village. (1990 Code
§13.103)
5-1-5: STAGNANT POOLS OF WATER:
Any stagnant pool of water in the village is declared to be a nuisance. It is
unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to permit any such nuisance to
remain or exist on any property under his or its control. (1990 Code §13.104)
5-1-6: NOXIOUS ODORS:
It is unlawful to cause or permit the emission of noxious odors from any fire,
chimney, waste disposal system, or any other agency in the village so as to
cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof. (1990 Code §13.112)
5-1-7: DENSE SMOKE:
It is unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any fire,
chimney, engine, oil burner, or any other agency in the village so as to cause
annoyance and discomfort to the residents thereof; provided, however, that upon
obtaining appropriate permission from fire district officials, burning shall be
allowed in areas designated as wetlands for the purpose of maintaining,
preserving, and improving the quality of the wetland ecology. (1990 Code
§13.113)
5-1-8: SPITTING:
It is unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or other public
place, or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public vehicle, or
place frequented by the public or to which the public is invited. (1990 Code
§13.111)
5-1-9: CEMETERIES AND BURIALS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to establish a cemetery or
to bury any person within the village limits or within three-fourths (3/4) of a
mile thereof except in an established cemetery. (1990 Code §13.106)
5-1-10: PUBLIC TOILET FACILITIES:
   A.   Conditions: Any business establishment, firm, or association providing
toilet facilities for the general public shall maintain said facilities in a
clean and sanitary condition, in good repair, and well lighted and ventilated
by means of a mechanical fan or operable screened window, and the door to such
facility shall be self-closing. Adequate hand washing facilities, including
running water, soap, and sanitary towels or drying devices, shall be provided.
(1990 Code §13.501)
   B.   Installation: Installation of such facilities shall comply with village
regulations 1  and state statutes in effect. (1990 Code §13.502; amd. 2011
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9 of this code.
5-1-11: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of this chapter
shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each and every day during or on which a violation continues or
exists. (1990 Code §§13.114,13.503; amd. 2011 Code)
5-1-12: DRAINAGE IMPEDIMENTS:
   A.   Declared Public Nuisance: The village of Pingree Grove, pursuant to its
authority under 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-60-2, 5/11-20-10, 5/11-20-
13, 5/11-30-2 and 5/11-30-8, among other authority, hereby declares "drainage
impediments" as defined herein to be prohibited, and to be a public nuisance
adversely impacting public health and safety.
   B.   Definition: "Drainage impediments" shall be defined herein as the
construction of any impediment or obstacle which obstructs, precludes, inhibits
or restricts the flow of drainage across any property within the corporate
limits of the village, or which obstructs the flow of stormwater as established
in the approved grading plans for any parcel or subdivision, without the prior
review and approval of a site plan contemplating and authorizing such
impediment. Drainage impediments shall include, but shall not be limited to,
the construction of any fence, earthen mound, wall or other impediment in a
drainageway or area that is designed, by virtue of its elevation or slope, to
serve as a drainageway.
      1.   When any fence is constructed in or over a drainageway, the bottom
of the fence shall be maintained at a minimum height approved by the public
works director, so as to maintain a clear flow of drainage water beneath the
fence. No obstruction shall be permitted or maintained beneath such minimum
height, in any fashion that obstructs the flow of drainage water. The public
works director may approve of the installation of an approved, removable
component of a fence that is installed in such a fashion as to not obstruct
drainage.
   C.   Enforcement: The village shall have the authority to enforce this
section and to abate any violation hereof.
      1.   The village may issue an ordinance violation citation for any
violation of this section, with a minimum fine as prescribed by this code for
each day or portion thereof that a violation is demonstrated to exist.
      2.   The village may seek a court order directing and authorizing the
abatement and removal of any drainage impediment. Such order may include an
order for the village to complete the removal of the drainage impediment and
the restoration of previous drainage conditions. The costs incurred herein
shall be recoverable from the owner of the real property on which the drainage
impediment is maintained, and/or lienable against the property. Such action to
abate a nuisance shall only be implemented after the village provides not less
than thirty (30) days' written notice via certified mail, return receipt
requested, to the owner of record of the property, affording an opportunity for
the owner to abate the nuisance.
      3.   The village may, in the case of a public safety emergency such as an
instance of flooding, take such action as shall be necessary to temporarily
restore drainage, including, but not limited to, removing drainage impediments,
without prior notice or due process.
   D.   Abatement Of Existing Drainage Impediments: At the time of passage
hereof, the village is aware of certain drainage impediments which were
installed without village authorization, in violation of the village's
building/fence codes, and without obtaining engineering review of proposed site
grading, as required by this code. The village shall notify any property
currently identified as being in violation of this code and shall afford such
property not less than ninety (90) days to abate the drainage impediment to the
satisfaction of the director of public works prior to initiating any court
action or imposing any fines or costs. (Ord. 2014-O-20, 11-3-2014)
CHAPTER 2
JUNK AND TRASH
SECTION:
5-2-1: Definition
5-2-2: Nuisance Declared And Prohibited
5-2-3: Violations; Notices And Investigations
5-2-4: Failure To Comply With Notice; Complaint Procedure
5-2-5: Prosecution Of Complaints
5-2-6: Violation; Penalties
5-2-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, "junk", "trash" and "refuse" are defined to
include any and all waste matter, whether reusable or not, which is offensive
to the public health, safety or aesthetics of the neighborhood and further
defined as any condition or use of any premises or building exteriors which is
detrimental to the property of others or which causes or which tends to cause
substantial diminution in the value of other properties in the neighborhood in
which said premises are located. The terms include, but are not limited to, the
keeping or depositing on or the scattering over the premises of any of the
following:
   A.   Lumber, junk, trash or debris.
   B.   Worn out, wrecked and/or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors,
machinery of any kind, any parts thereof, old iceboxes, refrigerators, stoves,
furniture, freezers, cans or containers or any other abandoned, discarded or
unused objects 1 . A motor vehicle shall be deemed to be abandoned if it does
not have a current registration plate issued in accordance with the laws of the
state of Illinois. (1990 Code §13.115)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 7, chapter 8 of this code.
5-2-2: NUISANCE DECLARED AND PROHIBITED:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: The storing of junk, trash or refuse on private
property within the village not otherwise authorized under the provisions of
this code and in any manner not otherwise permitted by any applicable zoning
ordinance is declared a nuisance. (1990 Code §13.116)
   B.   Nuisance Prohibited:
      1.   No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any
premises shall maintain or keep any junk, trash or refuse thereon or permit
said premises to be a nuisance, nor shall any person keep or maintain such
premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of the other
properties located in the neighborhood in which the premises are located.
      2.   No person in charge of or in control of any premises, whether as
owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall maintain any junk, trash or
refuse thereon or keep any nuisance thereon for longer than ten (10) days,
except this subsection shall not apply with regard to any vehicle in an
enclosed building or so located upon the premises as not to be readily visible
from any public place or from any surrounding private property. (1990 Code
§13.117)
5-2-3: VIOLATIONS; NOTICES AND INVESTIGATIONS:
   A.   Observance Of Violation By Village Officer; Issuance Of Notice: Any
village officer observing any violation of subsection
5-2-2B of this chapter shall immediately notify the village manager who shall
issue a notice directed to the owner of record of the property on which said
nuisance occurs, as shown in the records of the county recorder of deeds, or to
the occupant of said property, or to both, which said notice shall describe the
violation and shall establish a reasonable time limit for the abatement thereof
by such owner or occupant, which time shall not be less than two (2) days nor
more than ten (10) days after service of such notice. (1990 Code §13.119; amd.
2011 Code)
   B.   Citizen's Affidavit Charging Violation; Investigation Procedure: Any
citizen of the village who observes a violation of subsection
5-2-2B of this chapter may file his affidavit setting forth in detail the
violation, its location, and the name of the owner and occupant of the property
on which such nuisance is alleged, and may file said affidavit with the village
clerk who shall notify the village manager. The village manager shall
investigate such charge, and if such nuisance exists, issue a notice to the
owner or occupant of the property as provided in subsection A of this section.
(1990 Code §13.120; amd. 2011 Code)
   C.   Procedure For Serving Notices: Any individual authorized to serve the
notice provided for in subsections A and B of this section shall serve said
notice upon the owner or occupant of the property on which such nuisance exists
or upon both of them, and shall, upon his return, make a copy of such notice,
showing the time of service, the person upon whom it was served, and the manner
in which it was served. The return of service shall be verified upon oath. In
the event personal service of said notice cannot be made upon said owner or
occupant of the property after at least three (3) separate attempts to serve
said individual at said location, then such notice shall be served upon said
owner or occupant, or both, by posting two (2) copies thereof conspicuously at
two (2) locations on said premises, and the return of service shall so indicate
that such service was made. (1990 Code §13.121)
   D.   Investigation Of Nuisance Abatement: Immediately upon the termination
of the time allowed in any such notice for the abatement of such nuisance, the
individual who served such notice, or any other individual authorized by the
village manager, shall investigate to determine whether or not such nuisance
has been abated. (1990 Code §13.122; amd. 2011 Code)
5-2-4: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH NOTICE; COMPLAINT PROCEDURE:
In the event the owner or occupant of the property where such nuisance exists
has failed within the prescribed time to abate such nuisance, then the
individual who filed an affidavit with the village clerk or the individual who
investigated whether such nuisance has been abated shall file a complaint with
the circuit court for the 16th judicial circuit, charging violation of section
5-2-2 of this chapter and demanding that the owner of the property or the
occupant thereof, or both, be punished as provided in section
5-2-6 of this chapter, and seeking injunctive or other equitable relief to
abate the nuisance. The owner or occupant thereof shall be obligated to
reimburse the village for all reasonable attorney fees and cost of suit and all
other expenses incurred by the village to abate said nuisance and collect all
monetary penalties, and a monetary judgment may enter in favor of the village
against said owner or occupant for the said amounts. (1990 Code §13.123)
5-2-5: PROSECUTION OF COMPLAINTS:
The village shall prosecute all complaints of violation of section
5-2-2 of this chapter. (1990 Code §13.124)
5-2-6: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
Any property owner or occupant of property who allows such storage as provided
in section
5-2-2 of this chapter on the property owned or occupied thereby shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and any person who neglects to abate and remove such
nuisance after notice thereof shall, for each twenty four (24) hours thereafter
during which said nuisance continues, be subject to a like penalty as that
originally incurred. (1990 Code §13.118; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: Unlawful Deposits; Disposal Requirements
5-3-2-1: Household Refuse Disposal Requirements
5-3-3: Uncovered Garbage Prohibited
5-3-4: Windblown Refuse
5-3-5: Spilling Loads Prohibited
5-3-6: Combustible Refuse; Unlawful Storage And Deposit
5-3-7: Owner's Consent For Disposal
5-3-8: Penalty
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
ASHES: Residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings.
GARBAGE: Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and
consumption of food, and wastes from the handling, storage, and sale of
produce.
REFUSE: Combustible trash including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes,
barrels, wood, excelsior, yard trimmings, wood furniture, bedding;
noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks,
refrigerators, stoves, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small
quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, other mineral
waste, street rubbish including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt,
leaves, catch basin dirt, and contents of litter receptacles; provided, refuse
does not include dirt and waste from building operations, nor does it include
solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations
such as food processing waste, boiler house cinders, lumber, scraps, and
shavings. (1990 Code §13.301)
5-3-2: UNLAWFUL DEPOSITS; DISPOSAL REQUIREMENTS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to deposit anywhere in the
village any uncovered piles of refuse, garbage, offal, or carcasses of dead
animals. Such refuse must be burned in properly constructed incinerators 1  or
otherwise properly disposed of. Any uncovered pile of refuse is declared to be
nuisance. (1990 Code §13.105)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 6 of this title for burning regulations.
5-3-2-1: HOUSEHOLD REFUSE DISPOSAL REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be mandatory for the owner(s) of each single family and/or multifamily
dwelling units in the Village to be responsible for subscribing with a licensed
waste disposal firm duly appointed by the Village, for once-a-week garbage,
recycling, and yard waste collection services, and make payment for such
services directly with the appointed waste disposal firm. Where owners fail to
subscribe to refuse collection service, service will be initiated by the waste
disposal firm duly appointed by the Village with the property owner responsible
for the charges. The following rules and regulations apply:
   A.   All garbage, recycling, and yard waste shall be called for and disposed
of at least once per week, on a day assigned by a waste disposal firm duly
appointed by the Village.
   B.   The waste disposal firm shall not engage in garbage collection,
recycling, or yard waste collection services at any residence of any person
before seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
   C.   Every household shall be permitted to use a thirty five (35), sixty
five (65), or ninety five (95) gallon toter cart with lid to contain garbage,
recycling, and yard waste, separately.
   D.   Garbage, recycling, and yard waste containers shall be kept out of
sight in the interior of the garage, or within HOA-approved temporary storage
containers at the rear of the unit, to be obscured from the front of the
property until the permitted time to place such containers at curbside for pick
up.
   E.   No garbage, recycling, or yard waste containers shall be placed at
curbside, adjacent street, or sidewalk area, any sooner than six o'clock (6:00)
P.M. one day prior to the scheduled collection pick up day.
   F.   No garbage, recycling, or yard waste containers shall remain at
curbside, adjacent street, or sidewalk area any later than seven o'clock (7:00)
P.M. the day collection is completed; such containers shall be returned to
approved areas as referenced in subsection D.
   G.   At no time shall any garbage, recycling or yard waste collection
container be placed upon any street or sidewalk so as to obstruct any vehicular
or pedestrian traffic or impede Village maintenance.
   H.   Landscape waste will be collected once weekly from April 1 through
November 30, and must be placed at the curb properly bagged, or bundled, and
must not be combined with garbage or recycling.
   I.   No waste shall be dumped, scattered, or buried within the Village
limits. (Ord. 2023-O-12, 6-19-2023)
5-3-3: UNCOVERED GARBAGE PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the village any garbage
or other material subject to decay other than leaves or grass except in a
tightly sealed or covered container. (1990 Code §13.302)
5-3-4: WINDBLOWN REFUSE:
It is unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes, or trash of
such material that can be blown away by the wind anywhere in the village except
in a covered container. (1990 Code §13.303)
5-3-5: SPILLING LOADS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage,
refuse, or ashes on any public street or alley in the village; provided, that
this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse, or
ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this chapter preparatory
to having such material collected and disposed of in an orderly manner. (1990
Code §13.304)
5-3-6: COMBUSTIBLE REFUSE; UNLAWFUL STORAGE AND DEPOSIT:
It is unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse in such a way as to
create a fire hazard, or to store or throw any refuse of any kind on any alley,
street, or other public place in the village. (1990 Code §14.201)
5-3-7: OWNER'S CONSENT FOR DISPOSAL:
It is unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse, or ashes on any premises
in the village without the consent of the owner of such premises. (1990 Code
§13.305)
5-3-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of this chapter
shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1990
Code §§13.114, 13.306, 14.213; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE A. SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
5-3A-1: License Required; Term
5-3A-2: Application For License
5-3A-3: License Fee; Number Of Licenses
5-3A-4: Issuance Of License
5-3A-5: Transfer Of License
5-3A-6: Vehicle Requirements; Sunday Service Prohibited
5-3A-7: Permit Required For Storage Or Disposal
5-3A-8: Penalty
5-3A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; TERM:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to engage in the
business of scavenger, or the collection or disposal of animal, human, or
vegetable refuse or offal, or refuse of any kind, without having first secured
a license therefor. The license shall be issued for each fiscal year. (1990
Code §12.701)
5-3A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Annual application for such license shall be made to the village clerk February
1 preceding the fiscal year, and shall be referred by the village clerk to the
village manager for recommendation. Each scavenger must file with the village
clerk a list of its charges for commercial, business, residential, and
industrial establishments February 1 preceding the fiscal year. (1990 Code
§12.702; amd. 2011 Code)
5-3A-3: LICENSE FEE; NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The annual fee for the license required in section
5-3A-1 of this article shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). No more than
three (3) scavengers licenses shall be in force in the village at any one time.
(1990 Code §§12.702, 12.703)
5-3A-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
No license shall be issued except on order of the village manager. (1990 Code
§12.702; amd. 2011 Code)
5-3A-5: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license may not be assigned, transferred, or conveyed in any manner without
the consent and approval of the village manager. (1990 Code §12.701; amd. 2011
Code)
5-3A-6: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS; SUNDAY SERVICE PROHIBITED:
Any vehicles used by the scavenger in his business shall be watertight and
equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the
transportation of garbage or similar refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such
vehicle to be driven over or through any street in the village during or on
Sunday. (1990 Code §12.704)
5-3A-7: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR STORAGE OR DISPOSAL:
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any
place within the village limits or within one and one-half (11/2) miles
thereof, except with the permission of the president and board of trustees.
(1990 Code §12.705)
5-3A-8: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall,
upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1990
Code §12.706; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PLANTS AND WEEDS
SECTION:
5-4-1: Nuisances Declared
5-4-2: Abatement Procedure
5-4-3: Abatement Costs (Rep. by Ord. 2019-O-22, 7-1-2019)
5-4-4: Foreclosure Of Lien (Rep. by Ord. 2019-O-22, 7-1-2019)
5-4-5: Violation; Penalty
5-4-1: NUISANCES DECLARED:
The following are declared to be public nuisances within the village:
   A.   Grass or weeds in excess of six inches (6") in height (this limitation
on plant height shall not apply to: 1) areas designated as wetland preserves,
areas contained within forest preserves or areas delineated as required by the
Illinois environmental protection agency to receive treated wastewater as a
part of the village land treatment system; and 2) agricultural plants being
cultivated in areas of the village zoned to allow such agricultural uses [or as
a legal nonconforming use], except within the front [or corner side yard] 30
feet of the property, the side 15 feet of the property [both sides] and the
rear 30 feet of the property; and 3) agricultural plants being cultivated in
small garden plots [under 200 square feet] used in conjunction with residential
units except within the front [or corner side yard] 30 feet of the property,
the side 15 feet of the property [both sides] and the rear 30 feet of the
property. For purposes of this subsection, "agricultural plants" shall be
defined as those plants that are commonly understood to be grown for human or
animal consumption such as grains, vegetables and fruit species 1 );
   B.   Trees or bushes which: 1) create an actual or potential public safety
hazard; 2) impair access to any public right of way, utility installation, or
aboveground utility line or wire; 3) create or contribute toward a building
code violation (including, but not limited to, blocking the view of building
address markings or obstructing gutters or drainageways); 4) impair emergency
access or egress from doors or windows of buildings; or 5) are diseased, dead,
or extending beyond the lot lines of the property on which they are planted
without the permission of adjoining property owners;
   C.   Weeds, bushes or trees recognized as invasive or noxious plants by the
United States department of agriculture, the village, or a similar federal,
state or local governmental agency;
   D.   Weeds recognized herein as invasive or noxious including: jimson,
burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, or other like kind weeds, and barberry
bushes (Berberis vulgaris or varietals thereof); or
   E.   Unmaintained weeds, trees or bushes on property which has been
unoccupied for a period in excess of three (3) weeks. (Ord. 2009-17, 6-15-2009)
 
Notes
  1. See also section
1 8-1-7 and subsections
  8-2-5B and
  11-5-4B1d of this code.
5-4-2: ABATEMENT PROCEDURE:
The village police department, village manager, building department or code
enforcement officer(s) or their designees (collectively, "enforcement
personnel") are hereby authorized to abate the nuisances described in section
5-4-1 of this chapter through use of the following process:
   A.   Notice Of Nuisance Condition: The enforcement personnel shall, upon
discovery of the nuisance condition, attempt to make contact with the owner or
occupier of the property through personal contact, telephone call, or mailed or
facsimile notice to the registered owner or occupier of the property, notifying
such person of the nuisance condition. Said notice shall provide the owner/
occupier with a period of time of not less than seven (7) days to abate the
nuisance condition, unless the enforcement personnel determine that such
condition presents an imminent threat to public health, safety or welfare, in
which case, no abatement period is necessary.
   B.   Abatement By Village: If the nuisance has not been abated by the owner/
occupier by the conclusion of the abatement period determined by the
enforcement personnel, the enforcement personnel may take such steps as shall
be necessary to provide for the abatement of the nuisance by or on behalf of
the village, including cutting or trimming grass; cutting, trimming or removing
weeds; trimming trees or bushes; and the removal of nuisance bushes or trees,
along with the disposal of any materials so removed. The costs of abatement
shall be a charge due and payable from the owner or occupant of the property in
question, and costs shall be established by the Public Works Director or
designee based upon the Village’s costs incurred for personnel, equipment and/
or contractors.
   C.   Notice Of Village Abatement; Statement Of Lien: After the village has
provided for the abatement of the nuisance, the enforcement personnel shall
mail an invoice for the costs incurred in abating the nuisance to the owner of
record, in accordance with the Village’s then-current weed abatement policy. If
such costs are not promptly paid, the charges may be added to property’s
combined services account, may be submitted for collections activity, or may be
subject to the filing of a lien. If the Village files a lien, a single lien may
be used for all abatement performed within a single calendar year, and the
Village may foreclose upon such lien at any time.
   D.   Recurring Nuisances: In the event any single property has a recurring
nuisance condition occurring within a single calendar year which has not been
addressed by the owner/occupier (e.g., an ongoing failure to cut grass/weeds),
the enforcement personnel shall not be required to take those steps described
in subsection A of this section and may proceed immediately to abatement of the
nuisance on the second or any subsequent occurrences of the nuisance without
requirement of additional written notice. (Ord. 2009-17, 6-15-2009; amd. Ord.
2019-O-22, 7-1-2019)
5-4-3: ABATEMENT COSTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2019-O-22, 7-1-2019)
5-4-4: FORECLOSURE OF LIEN:
(Rep. by Ord. 2019-O-22, 7-1-2019)
5-4-5: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
The occurrence of a nuisance as described in this chapter shall be a violation
of this code. Action taken by the enforcement personnel to abate the nuisance
shall not supersede this code, and the occurrence of a nuisance condition is
subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code per day for each day the nuisance is permitted to remain in
place. Each subsequent recurrence of a nuisance condition shall be a separate
violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-17, 6-15-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 5
CONSERVATION AREAS
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definitions
5-5-2: Map Of Conservation Areas; Changes
5-5-3: Signs Posted
5-5-4: Maintenance Requirements
5-5-5: Exemptions From Provisions
5-5-6: Violation; Penalties
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
The terms listed in this section shall be defined, for purposes of this
chapter, as indicated:
CONSERVATION AREA:
   A.   Any "delineated wetland" (as defined in this section).
   B.   Any area shown on an approved final plat, plan or landscaping plan for
any portion of the village as being designated for the planting, installation
and/or maintenance of landscaping and plants designed to be maintained at a
height in excess of six inches (6").
   C.   Any area shown on an approved final plat, plan or landscaping plan for
any portion of the village that is designated to be maintained in a specified
fashion for the purpose of providing some environmental benefit (e.g.,
filtration of sedimentation, stabilization of shoreline, etc.).
   D.   Any area identified on the official village of Pingree Grove map of
conservation areas as maintained at the village hall.
DELINEATED WETLAND: Any area of property that has been identified as a wetland
by an agency having jurisdiction to make such identifications, including, but
not limited to, the army corps of engineers, the United States or Illinois
environmental protection agency or the village of Pingree Grove. (Ord. 2010-09,
5-17-2010)
5-5-2: MAP OF CONSERVATION AREAS; CHANGES:
   A.   The village shall adopt an official map of conservation areas, which
map shall be updated on an as needed basis to reflect additions to or deletions
from those areas identified as conservation areas for purposes of this chapter.
A copy of said map shall be available for public inspection at the village hall
during normal business hours, and village staff shall use reasonable effort to
make the current copy of such official map available on the official website of
the village.
   B.   No public hearing shall be necessary for changes in the official map.
Changes in the official map shall be made based upon the recommendation of the
village public works director and/or the village engineer, and shall be
approved by a majority vote of the village board. No property owner or other
party shall have any right or authorization to a hearing or other due process
prior to a change in the status of any property as being identified as a
conservation area or not, nor shall any party have a continuing expectation
that property shall or shall not be identified as a conservation area. Not less
than seven (7) days before the date that any parcel of property is proposed to
be approved by the village board identified as being a conservation area, the
village shall dispatch, via U.S. mail, postage prepaid, a notice to all owners
of property that is immediately adjacent to the identified area, along with a
copy of the proposed revisions to the official map. (Ord. 2010-09, 5-17-2010)
5-5-3: SIGNS POSTED:
The village public works director shall be authorized to obtain and install
such signs as he shall deem reasonably necessary in the areas identified as
conservation areas. (Ord. 2010-09, 5-17-2010)
5-5-4: MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Notwithstanding the contrary provisions of any other village ordinance,
maintenance of conservation areas shall only be permitted in a fashion that
maintains them in the as designed condition. That maintenance obligation may be
defined in one of two (2) ways: 1) the village board, at the time of approving
the designation of any parcel of land as a conservation area, may also approve
a maintenance plan detailing the maintenance requirements for the area; or 2)
in the absence of such an approved maintenance plan, the party responsible for
maintenance of the conservation area shall maintain the plan to keep the area
consistent with the approved landscaping plans for the area, and in accordance
with all applicable rules and regulations. It shall be unlawful to engage in
any unpermitted alteration of a conservation area, and such unlawful activity
shall include, but shall not be limited to:
      1.   Mowing of grasses or other plants utilized in conservation areas.
      2.   Grading or regrading of conservation areas.
      3.   Discharging waste, debris, trash, refuse or other materials to a
conservation area.
      4.   Applying fertilizer, herbicide, insecticide or other chemicals to a
conservation area without the permission of the village and the owner of the
conservation area.
      5.   Conversion of a conservation area to a recreational area or for any
other purpose whatsoever.
      6.   Operation of a motor vehicle or any motorized equipment, including,
but not limited to, lawn mowers, chain saws, weed whackers, or other similar
equipment within a conservation area, other than as required to perform
permitted maintenance in accordance with the requirements of the village and
the owner of the conservation area.
      7.   Installation of any improvements, buildings, structures, or other
items, whether permanent or temporary, within the conservation area.
      8.   The making or construction of any other unauthorized modification of
a conservation area.
   B.   
      1.   The owner of any conservation area shall be exempt from those
provisions of this code requiring that plants be maintained at a height of six
inches (6") or less 1 . However, all such parties shall be required to perform
any maintenance required by their applicable approved plans, village board
approved maintenance requirements, annexation agreement or development
agreement, and any maintenance reasonably required to maintain the conservation
areas in an orderly fashion and in the condition that they were contemplated to
be maintained at the time of installation.
      2.   In the event any party fails to so maintain an identified
conservation area, the village shall notify such owner in writing of the areas
of concern identified and shall attempt to schedule a meeting with the affected
property owner to attempt to develop a mutually acceptable resolution of the
issue.
      3.   In the event that the affected party fails to take action to address
the issues identified within fourteen (14) days of the date on which the
village mails a notice identifying the issues, the village may proceed to take
all such action as shall be necessary to abate the violation and shall be
permitted to treat the abatement process as abatement of a nuisance in
accordance with the provisions of this code applicable to weeds and grass
generally (i.e., with the provision of notice followed by abatement of the
nuisances at property owner's expense, with the imposition of a recorded lien
pursuant to the applicable provisions of this code 1 ).
      4.   Further, prior to the use of any chemical weed or insect control
mechanisms or the use of fire or controlled burning within a conservation area,
the party responsible for maintaining the conservation area shall be required
to give notice to the village and obtain the village's express consent for such
chemical application or controlled burn, which consent shall be subject to the
imposition of any requirements that the village deems appropriate (e.g., for
chemical application, a minimum setback from any wetlands or detention basins;
for controlled burning, coordination with and permission from the fire
protection district). (Ord. 2010-09, 5-17-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  5-4-1A of this title.
1 1. See section
  5-4-2 of this title.
5-5-5: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The following are exempt from the enforcement of this chapter:
   A.   Village employees, agents or contractors acting in the performance of
their official duties.
   B.   Authorized third parties engaging in permitted maintenance of a
conservation area. (Ord. 2010-09, 5-17-2010)
5-5-6: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: Any violation of this chapter, whether through
unauthorized modification of a conservation area or through the failure to
properly maintain a conservation area in an orderly fashion, is declared to be
a public nuisance which may be abated by the village.
   B.   Penalties:
      1.   Violations of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine as follows:
First violation: A fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
Second violation: A fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
Third or subsequent violation: A fine of not less than five hundred dollars
($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
      2.   In addition to the fines contemplated in subsection B1 of this
section, each violator shall also be liable to the village or to the owner of
the conservation area for the total cost of remediating any violations,
including removing any unauthorized construction or impediments, the costs of
replacing any plants or structures damaged as a result of the violation, or any
other costs whatsoever incurred in investigating the violation, identifying the
perpetrators, and repairing any damage done to the affected conservation area.
(Ord. 2010-09, 5-17-2010)
CHAPTER 6
BURNING REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:
5-6-1: Prohibited Burning
5-6-2: Restrictions On Burning
5-6-3: Permitted Burning
 
Notes
  1. See section
1 5-3-2 of this title for permitted burning of refuse in properly constructed
  incinerators.
5-6-1: PROHIBITED BURNING:
It shall be unlawful to burn paper, treated or untreated building materials,
cardboard, grass, rags, garbage, garden trash, rubber, tar, waste oil (except
within a waste oil furnace designed for said purpose) and/or similar materials
within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 2010-01, 1-18-2010)
5-6-2: RESTRICTIONS ON BURNING:
Any open burning conducted which is otherwise permitted pursuant to this
chapter shall be subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   1. Any such burning shall be conducted a reasonable and safe distance
from any trees, shrubs, fences, buildings or other potentially flammable
structures/substances.
      2.   Any such burning shall be conducted not less than fifteen feet (15')
from the nearest property line.
      3.   Fires in approved containers (as defined in the international fire
code) are permitted; provided, that said container must be not less than
fifteen feet (15') from a structure (and the user must have documentation
present demonstrating that said container is an approved container).
      4.   Open fires, whether recreational or otherwise, with a pile size of
less than three feet (3') in diameter and less than two feet (2') in height
shall be permitted; provided, that said fire must be not less than twenty five
feet (25') from a structure, and provisions shall be made to prevent the fire
from spreading within twenty five feet (25') of any structure.
      5.   Any other open fires, whether recreational or otherwise, shall be
conducted not less than fifty feet (50') from any structure, and provisions
shall be made to prevent the fire from spreading to within fifty feet (50') of
any structure;
   B.   Any such burning shall be conducted in a neat and orderly fashion, and
contained within an area not exceeding three feet (3') in diameter and two feet
(2') in height;
   C.   No burning shall be conducted when wind speeds exceed ten (10) miles
per hour, nor when it is otherwise unreasonably windy, nor shall any burning be
permitted to distribute ash, embers, or partially burned materials beyond the
property of the person conducting the burning;
   D.   All burning shall be supervised at all times when flames are present by
an adult not under the influence of drugs or alcohol, equipped with an adequate
means of extinguishing the fire (consisting of either a charged fire
extinguisher, a reasonable water supply, or other approved means);
   E.   No burning, including use of barbecues, open flame cooking devices or
grills, shall be permitted on outdoor wooden decks or other wooden structures,
nor on a patio/balcony/porch of any residential structure other than a ground
level, nonflammable patio (e.g., dirt, grass, stone or concrete), regardless of
whether an enclosure, barbecue, grill or fire pit is utilized. No wood or
charcoal burning grill may be utilized on or within any flammable structure
(including, but not limited to, wooden decks, balconies, within a structure,
garage or outbuilding, etc.);
   F.   No burning shall be conducted that creates a harmful or unreasonably
offensive odor;
   G.   No gasoline, diesel fuel or other accelerants shall be permitted in the
ignition of said fire (except, that a reasonable amount of lighter fluid may be
utilized to ignite charcoal for use within a grill for cooking purposes);
   H.   No burning shall occur or be permitted to occur on any public property
(including parkway areas between streets and sidewalks), nor on any property
other than property owned by the person responsible for the fire;
   I.   No buildings, sheds, fences or other structures shall be burned; and
   J.   No burning shall occur within the confines of any building or
structure, except within an approved fireplace that meets all applicable
building code or other codes and requirements. (Ord. 2010-01, 1-18-2010)
5-6-3: PERMITTED BURNING:
   A.   The open burning of tree limbs, twigs or nontreated wood building
materials for domestic fireplaces, campfires, cooking or religious purposes
shall be allowed, subject to the provisions of section
5-6-2 of this chapter.
   B.   The open burning of leaves shall be permitted, subject to the
provisions of section
5-6-2 of this chapter, between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) P.M.
   C.   Any person who has submitted for and received approval from the village
and village engineer to have and maintain a prairie grass or naturalized area
of landscaping which requires annual or semiannual burning to maintain, may
conduct such burning, but only after obtaining the written prior approval of
the village police department and the Pingree Grove/Countryside fire protection
district, and after submitting to any conditions or requirements imposed by
either entity. No area that has not been permitted and approved by the village
as a prairie grass or naturalized area shall be eligible for burning under this
subsection.
   D.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing contained herein shall prohibit
the use of an enclosed electric, propane or natural gas powered grill, used for
the cooking of food for personal consumption on the premises, at ground level;
provided, that adequate setbacks are maintained between such grill and any
surrounding structures to prevent damage by heat or flame.
   E.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the village may permit itself or any
other governmental entity (including, but not limited to, forest preserve
districts, park districts, or fire protection districts) to engage in burning
activities as deemed appropriate by the village from time to time (e.g., fire
department training, village conducted bonfire, or other conduct determined to
be appropriate by the village manager, and subject to such restrictions as he
shall impose). (Ord. 2010-01, 1-18-2010)
CHAPTER 7
FOOD SERVICE
SECTION:
5-7-1: Licenses And Inspections Required
5-7-2: Spoiled, Tainted Food Prohibited
5-7-3: Penalties
5-7-1: LICENSES AND INSPECTIONS REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to operate any establishment, machine or enterprise that serves,
prepares, or offers for sale any food, including, but not limited to,
beverages, prepared foods, snacks, or related items, which is required to
obtain any form of food service license from the county health department,
without first having obtained all requisite licenses and inspections. Any such
establishment or enterprise which is required to obtain a license or inspection
relating to the preparation or service of any food item shall prominently
display a copy of its current license(s) and inspection(s). (Ord. 2009-16, 6-
15-2009)
5-7-2: SPOILED, TAINTED FOOD PROHIBITED:
No food service establishment shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of
selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human
consumption which is spoiled, tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for human
consumption for any reason. (Ord. 2009-16, 6-15-2009)
5-7-3: PENALTIES:
Any violation of this chapter shall be a village ordinance violation,
punishable by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per occurrence, per day, for a
first offense; a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and
not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a second offense; and a
fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or
subsequent offense. For purposes of this chapter, each day on which a violation
is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense for purposes of
calculating fines. In addition, should any person be stopped and issued a
citation for a violation of this chapter, a second or successive violation
occurring more than ten (10) minutes after the first citation has been
completed shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 2009-16, 6-15-2009)
TITLE 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1-1: Definitions
6-1-2: Department Created
6-1-3: Hiring Standards; Probation; Training
6-1-4: Chief Of Police
6-1-5: Additional Officers
6-1-6: General Duties Of Police Officers
6-1-7: Compensation
6-1-8: Serving Processes
6-1-9: Conduct Of Members
6-1-10: Discharge Or Discipline Of Officers
6-1-11: Civilian Employees
6-1-12: Emergency Lights In Personal Vehicles
6-1-13: Rules And Regulations
6-1-14: Obedience To Police Required
6-1-15: Part Time Police Officers Authorized
6-1-16: Administrative Procedure To Determine Eligibility Under The Public
Safety Employee Benefit Act And Establish Definitions And Procedures For The
Maintenance Of Such Benefits After Their Award
6-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
MEMBER: Any person in the employ of the police department of the village who is
not sworn and commissioned to perform police duties.
POLICE OFFICER: Any employee of the police department of the village sworn and
commissioned to perform police duties, and includes the chief of detectives,
captains, lieutenants, sergeants, plain clothes officers and patrol officers.
The term does not include special police officers, auxiliary police officers,
night watchmen, temporary employees, clerks or other civilian employees of the
police department, traffic guards, civilian parking meter and parking
facilities personnel or so called auxiliary police officers specially appointed
to aid or direct traffic at or near schools or public functions or to aid in
civilian defense, or special police officers temporarily employed or
commissioned as police officers. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
6-1-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a police department for the village, being an executive
department of the village. The department shall consist of the chief of police,
deputy chief of police, if selected, and of such number of captains,
lieutenants, sergeants and patrol officers as may be provided from time to time
by the village board. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
6-1-3: HIRING STANDARDS; PROBATION; TRAINING:
   A.   Hiring Standards: Any person of good character who meets the
qualifications and standards for being a police officer as prescribed by state
statute, village ordinance and rules of the department as prescribed from time
to time by the village manager, chief of police or board of trustees may be
employed as a police officer for the village. No applicant for a position with
the police department of the village shall be excluded by reason of race,
creed, color, religion, sex, station in life, national origin, age, disability,
familial status or sexual orientation. The police department shall be an equal
opportunity employer and, as such, shall comply with applicable state and
federal statutes and regulations pertaining to employment practices. (Ord.
2007-42, 2-5-2007; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   Probationary Period: All persons employed as police officers shall be
probationary employees for a period of one year from the date of their
employment. The probationary period may be extended up to an additional one
hundred eighty (180) days at the discretion of the chief of police. A police
officer may be discharged without cause during said probationary period.
Thereafter, a police officer, other than the chief of police, may be discharged
in accordance with section
6-1-10 of this chapter.
   C.   Training For Part Time Officers: Any police officers other than those
officers who shall be employed on a full time basis shall be qualified to enter
and successfully complete any training mandated by the Illinois law enforcement
training standards board. (Ord. 2007-42, 2-5-2007)
6-1-4: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created: There is hereby created the office of chief of police.
(Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
   B.   Appointment: The chief of police shall be appointed by the village
president, with the advice and consent of the village board. The president may
make an interim appointment to chief of police, from time to time. The
appointment of the chief of police or an interim appointment shall not be made
by the Board of Police Commissioners. The chief of police need not be from the
lower ranking officers of the police department. (Ord. 2015-O-20, 7-6-2015)
   C.   Oath And Bond: Before entering upon the duties of office, such person
shall take the oath of office prescribed for village officers and execute a
bond to the village in such amount as determined by the board of trustees.
   D.   Compensation: The chief of police shall receive compensation as
directed by the board of trustees from time to time. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
   E.   General Duties:
      1.   Supervision: The chief of police shall be the head of the police
department, shall have supervision over all of the police officers and members
thereof and shall be held directly responsible for the conduct and efficiency
of all police officers and members of the department. All persons who are
members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of
police.
      2.   Status Reports: The chief of police shall submit a report to the
village board of trustees detailing the operations of the police department at
each regular board meeting.
      3.   Familiarity With Village: The chief of police shall familiarize
himself/herself with all sections of the village and its operation.
      4.   Hours: The chief of police shall maintain regular hours of duty.
      5.   Familiarity With Police Business From Shift To Shift: When coming on
duty, the chief of police shall immediately familiarize himself/herself with
all police business transacted since his/her last tour of duty, and it shall be
his/her duty to inform or provide for the transference of information so as to
inform each shift of police officers and members of the department going on
duty of all important matters which have occurred or which may require
attention.
      6.   Conduct Of Police Officers: The chief of police shall immediately
and diligently inquire into all complaints and charges of laxity and misconduct
by police officers or members of the police department in the performance of
their duties and shall take such steps as set forth in this chapter, or as he/
she may deem necessary when not in conflict with this chapter or state statute,
so as to properly deal with said complaints, charges and misconduct.
      7.   Custody Of Books, Records And Equipment: The chief of police shall
have custody and control of all books, records, machines, tools, apparatus and
equipment of every kind and nature necessary for use by the police department.
      8.   Records And Reports: The chief of police shall keep such records and
make such reports concerning the activities and operations of the police
department as may be required by state statute, ordinances of the village or
the board of trustees which will facilitate proper law enforcement and protect
due process requirements.
      9.   Custody Of Lost, Abandoned, Stolen Property: The chief of police
shall be the custodian of all lost and abandoned or stolen property found or
recovered in the village. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
      10.   Interdepartmental Cooperation And Agreements: The chief of police
is and shall be authorized to enter into one or more agreements or
intergovernmental agreements with other law enforcement agencies or
governmental agencies, for the shared use of available resources, shared law
enforcement or prosecutorial activities, joint operations, training operations
or initiatives, co-policing initiatives, integration of command, mutual aid
arrangements, and similar law enforcement operations including utilization of
sworn peace officers from other agencies to supplement or temporarily serve in,
with or under the village's standing complement of police officers. Said
agreements may cover any terms related to such operations, including the
indemnification or insuring of officers involved, chain of command issues, use
of village resources, or related topics. Any agreement which requires the
appropriation or use of unbudgeted funds shall require the approval of the
village board for that budgetary amendment, prior to approval by the chief of
police. (Ord. 2014-09, 4-21-2014)
      11.   Part Time Employees: The chief of police shall be authorized to
administer tests, conduct background checks, and take all steps necessary to
evaluate candidates for hire as part time police officers for the village of
Pingree Grove and, upon satisfactory conclusion of all such tests, shall have
the authority to hire such officers for the village of Pingree Grove, provided
that the costs of their employment are included within the then current budget
for the village. (Ord. 2014-O-12, 5-19-2014; amd. Ord. 2019-O-19, 12-6-2021)
6-1-5: ADDITIONAL OFFICERS:
The police department shall have such other officers, in such other ranks and
positions, as the corporate authorities of the village may approve from time to
time. (Ord. 2015-O-20, 7-6-2015)
6-1-6: GENERAL DUTIES OF POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the police officers of the police department to
see to the enforcement of all of the ordinances of the village and all statutes
applicable thereto; and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law
and arrest violators thereof. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
   B.   The chief of police and all officers of the department shall have the
power and authority of a constable at common law and such other powers as
granted to municipal police officers under the statutes of the state and as set
forth in the ordinances of the village.
   C.   It shall be the duty of the chief of police and police officers of the
department to enforce all of the ordinances of the village and state and
federal statutes applicable therein and to preserve order, prevent violation of
the law and to arrest violators thereof. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006; amd. Ord.
2015-O-20, 7-6-2015)
   D.   Every police officer and member of the department shall appear as a
witness whenever necessary for the prosecution of any violation of a village
ordinance or state or federal statute. All witness fees received by an officer
for testimony shall be delivered to the village finance director. (Ord. 2006-
25, 10-2-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
6-1-7: COMPENSATION:
Salaries and wages of the police officers and members of the police department
shall be as established and determined from time to time by the board of
trustees. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
6-1-8: SERVING PROCESSES:
The chief of police and police officers of the department shall serve processes
upon proper application or request therefor. No member of the police
department, except the chief, shall serve any process except on command or
direction of the chief of the police department. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006; amd.
Ord. 2015-O-20, 7-6-2015)
6-1-9: CONDUCT OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of every member of the police department to conduct
himself or herself in a proper and law abiding manner at all times and to avoid
the use of unnecessary force. Each member of the department shall obey the
orders and directions of his/her superior. (Ord. 2006-25, 10-2-2006)
6-1-10: DISCHARGE OR DISCIPLINE OF OFFICERS:
Officers other than probationary officers may be discharged or disciplined in
