CHAPTER 5
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-5-1: No Parking On Specific Streets
7-5-2: Restrictions On Parking
7-5-3: Municipal Parking Lots
7-5-4: School Parking Areas
7-5-5: Parking After Snowfall Or Weather Event
7-5-6: Commercial Vehicles, Commercial Equipment And Recreational Vehicles
7-5-7: Inoperable Vehicles And Trailers
7-5-8: Presumption Of Owner's Liability
7-5-9: Penalties For Unauthorized Use Of Parking Spaces Reserved For Persons
With Disabilities
7-5-10: Penalties
7-5-1: NO PARKING ON SPECIFIC STREETS:
No parking or standing shall be permitted at any time on the following streets:
   Illinois Route 72.
   Reinking.
   Richard J. Brown.
   U.S. Route 20.
   Wester.
(Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006; amd. Ord. 2024-O-01, 2-20-2024)
7-5-2: RESTRICTIONS ON PARKING:
   A.   Residential Streets:
      1.   On any residential street within the Village where the paved portion
of the street is equal to or lesser than twenty four feet (24') in width,
vehicles shall be required to park only on one side of the street in an
otherwise lawful parking area. The terms in this subsection A1 shall have the
same definitions as those provided in the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. 2006-28,
10-6-2006)
      2.   No vehicle under repair, inoperable motor vehicle, or vehicle in a
state of partial disassembly may be parked on any public street.
   B.   Sale Or Repair Of Vehicle: No person shall park a vehicle upon any
roadway for the principal purpose of displaying such vehicle for sale or
repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by emergency for a duration
of not longer than six (6) hours.
   C.   All Night Parking: No person shall park any vehicle on that part of any
street within the Village limits between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on any day.
   D.   Prohibited Parking Areas; Time Limit Parking: No person shall park a
vehicle at a prohibited location or for a period of time longer than indicated
upon signs properly posted.
   E.   Boats, Trailers And Recreational Vehicles: No person shall park a boat,
trailer or recreational vehicle on any street within the Village for more than
forty eight (48) hours at a time. No person shall park any boat or trailer on
any street within the Village at any time, unless it is properly connected to a
lawfully registered and operable Motor Vehicle capable of safety and legally
moving the boat or trailer. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a trailer may be
parked on a Village street, during daylight, during normal working hours
(permitted under Village Code), for a period of not longer than eight (8)
hours, when the trailer and/or the tow vehicle is actually and actively in the
process of being loaded or unloaded, or is otherwise necessary to be unhooked
for work purposes. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
   F.   Unimproved And Unapproved Surfaces: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle (including but not limited to cars, trucks, trailers, motorcycles,
motor-driven cycles, recreational vehicles and any other item defined as a
vehicle under the Illinois Vehicle Code) in whole or in part on any unimproved
or unapproved surface within the Village of Pingree Grove, unless such area is
approved for temporary parking during a special event, or is utilized as
parking for a recreational facility comprising more than one hundred (100)
acres in size.
 
                    Any surface that is not constructed in accordance with the
                    applicable regulations of the Village of Pingree Grove,
                    including any driveway or parking area that was installed
                    without obtaining appropriate permits or which is
                    unlawfully installed or constructed on public property or
                    any setback or right-of-way area (except pursuant to a
                    lawful permit), any driveway or parking area that is
UNAPPROVED SURFACE: installed with materials not permitted by this Code or not
                    installed in accordance with this Code (e.g., temporary
                    parking surfaces composed of paver blocks or other similar
                    materials), and other similar surfaces. Any vehicle that is
                    parked in a front or side yard setback area or the location
                    between the front building line of a residential lot and
                    the street, other than on a properly permitted and
                    installed permanent driveway surface, shall be deemed to be
                    parking on an unapproved surface.
                    Any surface comprised of grass, weed, dirt or similar
                    substances and any parkway. Unimproved surface shall also
                    mean any lawn or grass areas or landscaped areas. A surface
                    that was formerly gravel but which has not been maintained
UNIMPROVED SURFACE: with a good, current, consistent and complete coating of
                    gravel shall constitute an unimproved surface. Any vehicle
                    which is parked and maintained on blocks or stands that
                    keep the wheels of the vehicle from touching the ground
                    and/or from bearing the weight of the vehicle shall be
                    deemed to be parked on an unimproved surface.
 
   G.   Stopping, Standing And Parking:
      1.   Outside a business or residence district, no person shall stop, park
or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the roadway
when it is practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off the roadway,
but in every event an unobstructed width of the highway opposite a standing
vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a clear view
of such stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of two hundred feet
(200') in each direction upon such highway.
      2.   The Public Works or Police Department may place signs prohibiting or
restricting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on any street where
in its opinion such stopping, standing or parking is dangerous to those using
the highway or where the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would unduly
interfere with the free movement of traffic thereon. Any such regulations
adopted by either department or by any other governmental agency with
jurisdiction over streets regarding the stopping, standing or parking of
vehicles upon any specific street, streets or highways become effective at the
time of the erection of appropriate signs indicating such regulations.
      3.   Emergency Restrictions: In the event of severe weather such as
tornado, severe thunderstorm, blizzard, flooding or other severe weather
conditions, or in the event of a natural or manmade disaster such as a fire,
gas leak, hazardous materials situation or other natural or manmade calamity,
the Chief of Police or designee thereof shall be authorized to immediately
implement such temporary parking regulations or prohibitions as shall be
necessary to protect public safety and public or private property, and to
address or mitigate hazards associated with the exigent circumstances. Such
authority shall include the ability to implement such measures as shall be
necessary to address the circumstances including but not limited to creation of
temporary parking restrictions or bans, removal/towing/relocation of cars,
temporary traffic regulations or other similar actions. Notice of such
emergency regulations or restrictions shall be given as soon as possible and by
whatever means reasonably practical under the circumstances including the
provision of verbal notice, the posting of temporary signage, the provision of
notification through news outlets, the Village website or social media, or such
other medium of notification as shall be available.
      4.   Applicable Restrictions: No person shall stop or park any vehicle in
any location where prohibited under any applicable provision of the Illinois
Vehicle Code (which is adopted herein by reference as if fully restated) or any
other provision of the Village Code.
      5.   Temporary Restrictions: The Chief of Police and their designees
shall be authorized to impose temporary parking restrictions (limited hours,
limited types of vehicles, etc.) or parking prohibitions (no parking permitted)
within the Village, under the provisions of this Section.
         a.   Duration of Restrictions: Said temporary restrictions may be
imposed for a period of no more than sixty (60) days at a time.
         b.   Method of Posting/Notice: No such temporary parking restrictions
shall be enforced until at least forty eight (48) hours have passed since the
posting of temporary signs in the affected area, indicating the applicable
restrictions. Said temporary signs shall be enforceable for the time that they
remain posted. In the event of an emergency that requires less notice, the
temporary restrictions may be imposed and enforced upon the provision of
personal notice to any vehicles parked in the area of the temporary signs at
the time of their posting, and the temporary signs shall indicate the time at
which the temporary restrictions shall take effect.
         c.   Enforcement: Once forty eight (48) hours have passed after the
posting of temporary signs (or a lesser period in the event of emergency
posting), the temporary parking restrictions may be enforced in the same
fashion as any other Village parking restriction, and shall have the effect of
Village Ordinance. Because such temporary restrictions are intended to be
utilized in circumstances where the Village determines that parking presents a
public safety threat, any vehicle parked in violation of the temporary parking
restrictions shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100), and shall be subject to immediate towing.
         d.   Removal or Tampering with Temporary Parking Restriction Signs: It
shall unlawful to move, remove, alter or tamper with any temporary parking
restriction signs posted by the Village. Any such violation shall be subject to
a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500).
   H.   Stopping, Standing Or Parking Prohibited In Specified Places:
      1.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic-
control device, no person shall:
         a.   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
            (1)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the
edge or curb of a street;
            (2)   On or over a sidewalk between the hours of six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on any day;
            (3)   Within an intersection;
            (4)   On a crosswalk;
            (5)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty
feet (30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety
zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
            (6)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction
when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
            (7)   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel;
            (8)   On any railroad tracks. A violation of any part of this
subsection H1a(8) shall result in a mandatory fine of five hundred dollars
($500.00) or fifty (50) hours of community service;
            (9)   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping;
            (10)   On any controlled-access highway;
            (11)   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers;
            (12)   In a public parking area if the vehicle does not display a
current annual registration sticker or current temporary permit pending
registration, or if the vehicle is otherwise an inoperable motor vehicle as
defined by Village Code or the Illinois Vehicle Code.
            (13)   Within the confines of a roundabout intersection, nor within
thirty (30) feet of any access point thereto that comes from a public street
(i.e. any intersecting roadway). For purposes of this Ordinance, an
intersection shall be considered a roundabout if it: a) is a circular
intersection where traffic from multiple ingress points enter and travel in a
counter-clockwise direction to access any egress point; b) is designated in any
official approved plan or document as a roundabout; or, c) is signed in
accordance with the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices as a roundabout.
Any vehicle parked in a roundabout shall be eligible for immediate towing.
         b.   Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except
momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers:
            (1)   In front of a public or private driveway;
            (2)   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant;
            (3)   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection;
            (4)   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of
a roadway;
            (5)   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly sign-posted);
            (6)   At any place where official signs prohibit standing;
            (7)   On any portion of Village Right of Way which is in front of
or adjacent to a parcel improved with a residential or commercial building
without the permission of the parcel's owner or the Village. For purposes of
this subsection, "Right of Way" shall mean that portion of public land adjacent
to a roadway, "roadway" shall mean that portion of a highway improved,
designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the Right of
Way and "highway" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of
every way publicly maintained.
         c.   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for
the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or
passengers (with hazard lights illuminated and the vehicle attended at all
times):
            (1)   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing;
            (2)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
      2.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into
any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful.
   I.   Additional Parking Regulations:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this section, every vehicle stopped
or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the right-
hand wheels parallel to and within twelve inches (12") of the right-hand curb
or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder.
      2.   Except when otherwise provided by ordinance, every vehicle stopped
or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the
curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement,
with its right-hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the right-hand curb or
as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder, or with
its left-hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the left-hand curb or as
close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder.
      3.   The Public Works or Police Department with respect to streets under
its jurisdiction may place signs prohibiting, limiting, or restricting the
stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on any highway where in its opinion
such stopping, standing or parking is dangerous to those using the highway or
where the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would unduly interfere with
the free movement of traffic thereon. No person shall stop, stand or park any
vehicle in violation of the restrictions indicated by such devices.
   J.   Expired Registration And Inoperable Vehicles: No person may stop, park,
or leave standing upon a public street, highway, or roadway a vehicle without a
current license plate and registration sticker, or in any condition which
constitutes as Inoperable Motor Vehicle under the provisions of Village Code or
the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   K.   Mail Boxes: No person may stop, park or leave standing upon a public or
private street, highway or roadway a vehicle where any portion of the vehicle
is within fifteen feet (15') of a mail box.
   L.   Driveways And Garage Doors:
      1.   No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle so as to block a
driveway. When portions of the curb adjacent to a private driveway are painted
yellow and any portion of a vehicle is within the area so painted, the vehicle
shall be deemed to be stopped, standing or parked in violation of this section.
      2.   No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle so as to block a
garage or garage door on private property, other than with the consent of the
owner of the garage. In areas where multiple residences or establishments are
served by a single common driveway, it shall be unlawful to park, stand or stop
a vehicle in a location where such vehicle blocks ingress/egress or access to
any garage door (other than with the consent of the owner of such garage).
      3.   No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in an alley or in a
common driveway serving four or more residential, commercial or industrial
units: a) for a period of time longer than is necessary for the reasonable
expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle; nor, b) in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the
width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; nor, c) in
such position as to block the driveway or entrance to any abutting property.
   M.   Private Property: It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle on
private property without having first obtained the consent of the property
owner or his agent. In the case of commercial parking lots, such consent shall
be implied from the presence of parking areas open to the public, but may be
revoked upon the provision of verbal or written notice.
(Ord. 2017-O-09, 5-1-2017; amd. Ord. 2019-O-08, 3-4-2019; Ord. 2019-O-38, 11-4-
2019; Ord. 2019-O-54, 12-16-2019; Ord. 2024-O-02, 2-20-2024; Ord. 2024-O-08, 4-
15-2024)
7-5-3: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS:
   A.   No person shall park a vehicle in any Municipal parking lot for a
period longer than four (4) continuous hours between five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
to the following two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
   B.   No person shall park a vehicle in any Municipal parking lot between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-
17-2006)
7-5-4: SCHOOL PARKING AREAS:
   A.   Definition: The term "parking areas", as used in this section, shall
mean the area or areas of land near or contiguous to schools for which there is
a contract between the school district and the Village for the regulation of
parking and traffic and used as a means of access to and egress from said
schools and for the parking of motor vehicles.
   B.   Subject To Village Traffic Regulations: Parking and traffic in parking
areas of any and all schools for which there is a contract between the school
district and village for the regulation of parking and traffic shall be subject
to the regulations set forth in this title.
   C.   Prohibited Parking Areas: No person shall park any vehicle or cause any
vehicle to stop or stand in any designated safety zone or fire lane, nor shall
any person park any vehicle in any designated loading zone except as provided
herein.
   D.   Restricted Parking Areas: No person shall park any vehicle or cause any
vehicle to stop or stand in any restricted parking area unless authorized by
the school that owns or operates the subject property. Parking in said
restricted areas shall be limited to vehicles registered with the school
authorities, faculty or administration vehicles and nonstudent vehicles on
official school business.
   E.   Signs Posted: The appropriate school shall be responsible for erecting
and maintaining in the school parking areas, signs posting speed limits and
designating safety zones, loading zones, fire lanes and restricted parking
areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to exceed said posted speed limits
or to violate the restrictions or prohibitions designated by said signs. (Ord.
2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-5-5: PARKING AFTER SNOWFALL OR WEATHER EVENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle
on any public street within the corporate limits of the village at any time: 1)
after a snowfall of two inches (2") or more has occurred; 2) at any time after
the national weather service has issued a winter storm warning, ice storm
warning, or other equivalent warning for weather conditions likely to generate
a need for snow removal or deicing operations, for areas including any portion
of the village of Pingree Grove; or 3) after the Village has issued a parking
ban notification via the Village website based upon an anticipated snow or ice
event or other weather condition or emergency causing a need to have street
clear of vehicles (after the effective date and time of such notification).
Such parking prohibition shall remain in effect until twenty-four (24) hours
after the snow or weather event has ended, said street has been cleared of all
snow and snow removal operations have been fully completed. The Village may
earlier terminate the parking prohibition by issuance of official notice in the
same format used to initiate a parking prohibition. It shall further be
unlawful to park any vehicle in such a fashion as to impair, impede or prevent
safe snow removal operations from public rights of way. The village may have
removed and towed away any car or other vehicle illegally parked which prevents
or obstructs snow removal from public streets in violation of this section.
(Ord. 2014-O-30, 12-1-2014; amd. Ord. 2019-O-08, 3-4-2019)
7-5-6: COMMERCIAL VEHICLES, COMMERCIAL EQUIPMENT AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to park or stand any truck, truck- tractor, or
other vehicle equipped with or required to be equipped with a class F or higher
(i.e., class F-Z) license plate, or with a gross weight in excess of twelve
thousand (12,000) pounds, on any street or right of way within the corporate
limits of the village, except as provided in subsection G of this section.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to park or stand any trailer or semitrailer
equipped with or required to be equipped with a class TC or higher (i.e., class
TC-TN) license plate, or with a gross weight in excess of five thousand (5,000)
pounds, on any street or right of way within the corporate limits of the
village, except as provided by subsection G of this section.
   C.   Commercial vehicles may be parked in areas other than streets and
public rights of way in areas zoned as single- or multi-family residential
(areas zoned with the prefix of R, such as R-1, R-2, or R-5, including areas
zoned partially as residential through the use of a planned unit development or
PUD) as follows:
      1.   If the vehicle does not exceed the standards of state of Illinois
license plate classification of "B" (8,000 pounds).
      2.   If the vehicle does not exceed the standards of state of Illinois
license plate classification of "D" (12,000 pounds) and is parked in a
completely enclosed building and a permit is obtained as provided herein.
      3.   If the vehicle does not exceed the standards of state of Illinois
license plate classification of "D" (12,000 pounds) and is used for essential
emergency twenty four (24) hour service including, but not limited to,
electrical, mechanical and plumbing contracting when the vehicle is also the
owner's/driver's principal means of transportation to and from his or her place
of employment and a permit is obtained as provided herein. (Ord. 2007-64, 6-4-
2007)
      4.   The permit will be issued by the building commissioner or his
designee if he determines that the vehicle and owner/driver comply with the
requirements of subsections C2 and C3 of this section. (Ord. 2007-64, 6-4-2007;
amd. 2011 Code)
      5.   The permit fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), and the
permit will be valid as long as the owner/driver has the vehicle and continues
to meet the requirements of subsections C2 and C3 of this section.
      6.   Only one permit shall be issued per residence.
      7.   This prohibition does not apply to delivery vans or service vehicles
while delivering merchandise or while making service calls.
   D.   Commercial vehicles exceeding the state of Illinois license plate
classification of "N" (40,000 pounds) or trailers exceeding the state of
Illinois license plate classification of "TG" (20,000 pounds) shall not be
parked in any area of the village other than areas zoned as agricultural,
commercial or industrial, except as provided in subsection G of this section.
   E.   Construction equipment, including, but not limited to, vehicles
equipped with tracks in lieu of pneumatic or nonpneumatic tires, wheel loaders,
excavators, bulldozers or other similar equipment, and "implements of
husbandry" as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-130 shall not be
parked in any area of the village other than areas zoned as industrial or
agricultural, except when within completely enclosed buildings or when parked
on a lawfully parked trailer for a period of not more than seven (7) days at a
time.
   F.   No vehicle or trailer, other than a lawfully permitted "house trailer"
as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-128, shall be parked in any
area and utilized as temporary or permanent storage. A vehicle or trailer shall
be presumed to be in use for permanent or temporary storage if such vehicle is
used for storage and: 1) is rendered immobile through the removal of wheels or
tires, or through the placement of jacks, stands, blocks or other weight
transferring devices for a period of not less than two (2) days; or 2) remains
in place, without being moved, for a period of not less than seven (7) days.
   G.   The following vehicles are excepted from the requirements of
subsections A, B, C and D of this section during the conditions described
below. All such vehicles are nonetheless required to comply with all other
applicable ordinances and regulations and are required to be displaying
current, valid license plates.
      1.   Vehicles making local deliveries, for the time period required to
make such local delivery, with such time period not exceeding one hour.
      2.   Vehicles owned and operated by a unit of government including, but
not limited to, a municipality, county, state, school district or fire
protection district; provided, that such vehicle is parked in the course of
operation of such vehicle for a period of time necessary for the use of such
vehicle (e.g., overnight parking of such vehicles is prohibited unless the
vehicle is being presently utilized).
      3.   Commercial vehicles located in areas zoned commercial or industrial;
provided, that such vehicles are parked for a period of time not to exceed four
(4) hours, and are parked for the purpose of loading or off loading cargo,
personnel, or equipment. No overnight parking of such commercial vehicles on
any road or right of way within the corporate limits of the village shall be
permitted.
      4.   Vehicles stopped, impounded or detained by a law enforcement agency
for the period of time that they are stopped, impounded or detained.
   H.   Recreational Vehicles:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park any Recreational Vehicle on any Village
street where the vehicle would exceed the weight classifications described in
this chapter if the Recreational Vehicle were a commercial vehicle (i.e. under
subsection C(1), it shall be unlawful to park a Recreational Vehicle with a
gross weight of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds or more on any street or right
of way within the Village, and under subsection C(2), it shall be unlawful to
park a Recreational Vehicle comprised as a trailer with a gross weight of five
thousand (5,000) pounds or more on any street or right of way within the
Village.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to park any Recreational Vehicle on any Village
street for a period of more than forty eight (48) hours.
      3.   It shall be unlawful to park any Recreational Vehicle in any public
parking lot or public parking area for a period of more than eight (8) hours,
except with the permission of the Chief of Police. (Ord. 2007-64, 6-4-2007;
amd. Ord. 2019-O-38, 11-4-2019)
7-5-7: INOPERABLE VEHICLES AND TRAILERS:
Vehicles and trailers which do not display a current state license plate
registration are declared as inoperable motor vehicles and trailers. Inoperable
motor vehicles and trailers in the right of way are declared a nuisance and are
subject to fine and towing as provided herein. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-5-8: PRESUMPTION OF OWNER'S LIABILITY:
Presumption of Ownership: In the case of any parking citation or handicapped
parking violation issued by or on behalf of the Village, regardless of whether
such citation is issued in the form of a mail-in citation, or whether such
citation is prosecuted through an Administrative Hearings or through the
Circuit Court, the provisions of this Section
7-5-8 shall apply.
   A.   Citation Issued To Occupied Vehicle: In the case of any citation issued
to a vehicle which is occupied or claimed by a driver at the time of issuance
of the citation, the citation shall be issued and prosecuted in the name of the
driver or person claiming responsibility.
   B.   Citation Issued To Unoccupied Vehicle: In the case of any citation
issued to a vehicle which is unoccupied and unclaimed by a driver at the time
of issuance, the citation shall be issued to the registered owner of the
vehicle.
      1.   In all such cases, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the
registered owner of the vehicle is the party responsible and liable for the
vehicle’s parking, violation of Village or State code or ordinance, and
resulting fines, penalties and other liabilities.
      2.   For any parking citation issued to the owner of an unoccupied
vehicle, the Village may accept payment for such citation from any party or
person.
      3.   For any parking citation issued to an unoccupied vehicle, the only
party that shall be authorized or entitled to contest the parking citation and/
or to request a Circuit Court Hearing or Administrative Hearing (if applicable)
on such citation is the registered owner to whom such vehicle is registered.
      4.   In the event that the registered owner contests such a citation on
the basis that a driver or person other than the registered owner was operating
the vehicle and/or parked the vehicle unlawfully, the registered owner shall
nonetheless be liable for the parking, violation of Village or State code or
ordinance, and resulting fines, penalties and other liabilities unless:
         a.   The registered owner produces a police report and other
documentation acceptable to the party reviewing the citation, demonstrating
that at the time the citation was issued, the vehicle had been reported stolen;
or
         b.   The registered owner produces documentary or testimonial evidence
demonstrating that at the time the citation was issued, an individual,
discrete, expressly named person identified by the registered owner had actual
custody of the vehicle and had personally parked the vehicle and incurred the
parking citation.
      5.   It shall not be a defense to a citation issued to the registered
owner of an unoccupied vehicle that such vehicle was leased, rented, loaned or
otherwise utilized by a third party, in the absence of proof that the vehicle
was under such person’s actual direct operation at the time that the citation
was issued, as required above.(Ord. 2007-64, 6-4-2007; amd. Ord. 2019-O-38, 11-
4-2019)
7-5-9: PENALTIES FOR UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PARKING SPACES RESERVED FOR PERSONS
WITH DISABILITIES:
   A.   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3(a) shall be fined, at minimum, the greater of
three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) or the maximum amount the village may by
ordinance impose as a fine under the provisions of the then current version of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3(c), as amended, in addition to any
costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle
authorized under that section; provided, that the violation occurred in the
vicinity of a sign indicating the then current maximum fine imposed for such
violations.
   B.   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3(a) in an area not marked by a sign indicating the
then current maximum fine imposed for such violations shall be fined, at
minimum, the greater of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or the maximum
amount then required under the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
11-1301.3(c), as amended, in addition to any costs or charges connected with
the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under that section.
   C.   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3(a-1) shall be fined, at minimum, the greater of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or the maximum amount then required under the
provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3, as amended, in
addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any
motor vehicle authorized under that section. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-5-10: PENALTIES:
   Violations of this chapter shall be punishable by the following penalties.
In the event any violation is enforced through a court or administrative
hearing proceeding, all such penalties shall be in addition to all court or
hearing costs.

CHAPTER 6
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
SECTION:
7-6-1: Gas And Smoke Emissions
7-6-1: GAS AND SMOKE EMISSIONS:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits a dense smoke or such
amount of smoke or fumes as may be hazardous to the public health. (Ord. 2006-
08, 4-17-2006)
ARTICLE A. SEASONAL AND PERMANENT VEHICLE MAXIMUM WEIGHT LIMITS
SECTION:
7-6A-1: Weight Limits Established
7-6A-2: Exceeding Weight Limits Prohibited
7-6A-3: Signs Posted
7-6A-4: Authority To Weigh Vehicles
7-6A-5: Special Permit Requirements
7-6A-6: Exemptions
7-6A-7: Penalty
7-6A-1: WEIGHT LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Permanent Gross Weight Limits: Weight limits applicable to all streets
within the village are established pursuant to section
7-1-1 of this title. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   Temporary Gross Weight Limits: The village board may, by resolution,
place temporary seasonal gross weight operating limitations upon designated
highways in the village based upon foundation, base, materials, type of
construction, seasonal weather conditions, seasonal frost levels, groundwater
tables and general ground conditions, and other factors involved in the
construction and maintenance of streets and roadways. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-2: EXCEEDING WEIGHT LIMITS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle, whether passenger car or motor truck or
any other type of vehicle, having a gross weight of more than the applicable
seasonal or permanent maximum safe gross weight limit for any designated street
or roadway in the village, as hereinbefore determined, to come upon, traverse,
or travel over or upon any such designated street or roadway in the village.
(Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-3: SIGNS POSTED:
The village shall cause seasonal and permanent gross weight limitations to be
posted in prominent places along streets of the village. Each so designated
street and roadway shall be restricted to vehicular traffic, including
passenger cars, motor trucks, and all other types of vehicles, which shall have
a gross weight not exceeding the applicable seasonal or permanent maximum safe
gross weight limit for such designated street or roadway and posted along the
street or roadway, as hereinbefore set forth. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-4: AUTHORITY TO WEIGH VEHICLES:
Any police officer, or any authorized officer, having reason to believe that
the weight of a vehicle and load is unlawful shall require the driver to stop
and submit to a weighing of the vehicle. The vehicle shall be driven to the
nearest convenient state of Illinois certified public or private scale. (Ord.
2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-5: SPECIAL PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Authorized: The village may, upon application and on good cause
being shown therefor, issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to
operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of weight or load
exceeding the maximum specified in this article.
   B.   Application For Permit: The applicant shall furnish the following
information in the special permit application:
      1.   The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle.
      2.   Applicant's name.
      3.   Type of permit request.
      4.   Whether it be for a single trip, round trip, or multiple routing.
      5.   The description and registration of the power unit.
      6.   Description of the object or vehicle to be moved.
      7.   The number of axles of the vehicle or combination of vehicles.
      8.   The axle weights of all single, tandem or series axles.
      9.   Gross weight of the vehicle.
      10.   The width, length and height of the vehicle and load; the specific
origin of the load; copies of all county and/or state permits must be attached
to the application prior to approval and issuance of a village special permit.
      11.   Requested routing over village streets and to specific location.
   C.   Fees: The owner or owner's agent shall submit an application fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for a single routing which shall be valid for seven
(7) calendar days; one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a round trip, valid
for fourteen (14) calendar days; and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a
multiple routing, valid for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120)
calendar days. Permits are valid only for the dates specified on the permit and
for the specific vehicle, load and routing. No substitution of vehicle, load or
routing is permitted without express written permission.
   D.   Approval And Issuance Of Permit; Contents:
      1.   The village clerk is authorized to approve the application for
approved routes. Upon approval and payment of all required fees, the village
clerk shall issue a permit allowing passage of the overweight vehicles over
village streets. The permit shall be specific and contain:
         a.   Permit number.
         b.   The dates the permit is valid.
         c.   Whether the permit is for single, round trip or multiple routing.
         d.   The description of the object or vehicle to be moved.
         e.   Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length and height.
         f.   The authorized routing over village streets including the origin
and termination points within the village.
         g.   The fee paid.
         h.   The date and signature of the authorized issuing clerk.
      2.   In addition, the permit will specify any general conditions with
which the permittee must comply that are consistent and reasonable for the
protection of the general public and village streets.
   E.   Liability Of Permittee: The permittee assumes all responsibility for
injury or damage to persons or to the public streets or private property.
   F.   Possession Of Permit: The permit shall be carried in the vehicle to
which the permit applies at all times while operating on streets within the
village and shall be exhibited upon demand to any authorized enforcement
official of the village. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-6: EXEMPTIONS:
The terms of this article do not apply to the following vehicles when engaged
and being used in the ordinary course of business:
   A.   Residential furniture moving vehicles.
   B.   Nonconstruction residential delivery vehicles.
   C.   Government owned vehicles.
   D.   Emergency vehicles.
   E.   Refuse removal vehicles.
   F.   Any vehicles being used for farming purposes and displaying a farm
class license plate.
   G.   All municipal or fire district vehicles. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
7-6A-7: PENALTY:
Any driver of any vehicle which is of a gross weight in excess of the
applicable seasonal or permanent maximum safe gross weight limit permitted upon
any street and roadway, who shall drive the vehicle over and upon or shall
cause such vehicle to come upon, traverse, or travel over or upon any such
street and roadway in the village, shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine
as provided for such violations in the Illinois Compiled Statutes. Every
separate entry upon any designated street or roadway by the driver of a vehicle
having a gross weight in excess of the maximum temporary seasonal or permanent
gross weight limit permitted upon such street or roadway shall be deemed to be
a separate offense. (Ord. 2006-08, 4-17-2006)
CHAPTER 7
OTHER VEHICLE REGULATIONS

7-7-2: OPERATION OF CERTAIN CONVEYANCES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate any ATV, implement of husbandry, golf
cart, licensed vehicle or snowmobile on private property, except with the
consent of the property owner.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to operate any regulated transport on private
property after being advised by the owner of such property that operation is
prohibited after notice, or in violation of any posted regulations regarding
such operation.
   C.   Property owners may prohibit the operation of certain vehicles or
certain types of vehicles by the posting of appropriate and legible signs on
their property (e.g. "Operation of Skateboards Prohibited"), and it shall be
unlawful to operate any conveyance in violation of such sign age. (Ord. 2019-O-
36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-3: OPERATION OF LICENSED VEHICLES:
   A.   It shall be lawful to operate licensed vehicles on public roadways in
compliance with the applicable provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to operate licensed vehicles on any public
sidewalk, public pathway or other public area.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to operate licensed vehicles on any private
property after being advised by the owner of such property that operation is
prohibited after notice, or in violation of any posted regulations regarding
such operation. (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-4: OPERATION OF ATVS, SNOWMOBILES AND OTHER VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful to operate ATVs, snowmobiles and other vehicles at any
location in the Village, except upon private property and with the express,
advance consent of the owner of such property. (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-5: OPERATION OF SKATEBOARDS, SCOOTERS AND PUSH CARTS:
   A.   It shall be lawful to operate skateboards, scooters and push carts on
public sidewalks and public pathways, provided that all such riders/operators
shall yield to pedestrian traffic.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to operate skateboards, scooters and push carts on
public roadways.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to operate skateboards, scooters and push carts in
other public areas, except for areas specifically designed for such use (e.g.
parks designed for use by skateboards). (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-6: OPERATION OF BICYCLES:
   A.   It shall be lawful to operate bicycles on public sidewalks and public
pathways, provided that all such riders/operators shall yield to pedestrian
traffic.
   B.   It shall be lawful to operate bicycles on public roadways, provided
that all such operation complies with the minimum requirements of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to operate bicycles in other public areas where
the operation of the bicycle results in violation of any other law or
ordinance, or results in damage to the other public area where the bicycle is
being operated by virtue of the generation of ruts or other property damage.
   D.   Where bicycles are operated at night, they must comply with all
Illinois Vehicle Code requirements relating to operation at night with lights
and reflectors. (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-7: OPERATION OF OTHER VEHICLES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate any other vehicle on public sidewalks,
public pathways, public roadways or other public areas.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to operate any other vehicle on private property,
except with the consent of the property owner. (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-8: OPERATION OF GOLF CARTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate golf carts at any location in the
Village, except upon private property and with the express, advance consent of
the owner of such property, or as provided in subsection (B) or (C) below.
   B.   It shall be lawful to operate golf carts on private roadways owned and
maintained by a private homeowners' association (HOA), where permitted under
the rules and regulations of that HOA. Such golf carts shall comply with the
following regulations:
      1.   Golf carts shall only be operated by licensed drivers.
      2.   Golf carts may be operated in any area where permitted under the HOA
regulations, including but not limited to private roadways, private sidewalks
or private pathways. It shall be unlawful to operate golf carts in areas where
their operation is prohibited.
      3.   Golf carts shall not be operated between the hours of dusk and dawn,
except where equipped with front and rear reflectors, as well as headlights and
taillights which are illuminated when in operation between dusk and dawn, and
which are capable of being seen from not less than five hundred (500) feet in
distance.
      4.   Golf carts shall be registered with the applicable HOA, and shall
have a clearly visible and prominently displayed, HOA-issued registration
number. Any HOA providing such registration shall annually provide a list of
registered golf carts to the Village of Pingree Grove Police Department, by May
1 of each year. Such list shall be updated from time to time as reasonably
required to maintain a current record of registration with the Police
Department.
      5.   Golf carts shall yield to vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
   C.   Any golf cart registered for operation in accordance with subsection
(B)(4) above may be operated on permitted public golf cart paths, provided that
such operation is in accordance with the requirements of subsection (B)(1),
(3), (4) and (5) above. All golf carts shall yield to all vehicular traffic on
any roadway, where such golf cart intends to cross the roadway using a
permitted public golf cart path.
   D.   It shall be unlawful to operate golf carts on any other public roadway
(except within an approved crossing), or other public area. (Ord. 2019-O-36,
11-4-2019)
7-7-9: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Nothing contained herein shall restrict or limit the lawful operation
of a wheelchair or motorized wheelchair within the Village. The operator of a
wheelchair or motorized wheelchair shall be classified as a pedestrian and
shall be required to comply with all applicable rules and regulations under
Village Code or the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   B.   Nothing contained herein shall restrict or regulate the operation of
any vehicle owned or operated by any unit of government when in the performance
of official governmental operations. (Ord. 2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)
7-7-10: OTHER REGULATIONS:
   A.   Nothing contained herein shall excuse non-compliance with any other
applicable code, ordinance, regulation, statute or law, including but not
limited to regulations on vehicle size or weight, operation of vehicles while
under the influence of drugs, alcohol or any intoxicant, or other applicable
requirements.
   B.   No conveyance shall be operated on any public sidewalk, public pathway
or within any other public area at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) mph. (Ord.
2019-O-36, 11-4-2019)

7-8-1: LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS AND DETERMINATIONS:
The village board members, in keeping with the policy of the Illinois general
assembly, as found in section 5/4-301 of the Illinois vehicle code, finds and
determines that: abandoned and derelict vehicles constitute a safety hazard and
a public nuisance; are detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the
general public by harboring disease, providing breeding places for vermin,
inviting plundering, creating fire hazards and presenting physical dangers to
children and others; produce scenic blights which degrade the environment and
adversely affect land values and the proper maintenance and continuing
development of the state of Illinois and all of its subdivisions; represent a
resource out of place and an energy loss to the Illinois economy and require
state and local governmental attention, in conjunction with any federal
governmental attention, in order to assure the expeditious removal and
recycling of these abandoned and derelict vehicles. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
ABANDONED, DERELICT OR INOPERABLE VEHICLE: Any vehicle which either satisfies
the definition of any of the terms in this section, the then current provisions
of the Illinois vehicle code or any vehicle:
   A.   Which is located on private property not subject to a traffic ordinance
enforcement agreement with the village of Pingree Grove and which is incapable
of being moved under its own power, has one or more flat tires, lacks current
license plates and registration, or has parts removed from the vehicle so as to
render it incapable of being moved under its own power or unlawful to operate;
   B.   Which is located on a public street or on private property subject to a
traffic ordinance enforcement agreement with the village of Pingree Grove and
which is incapable of being moved under its own power, has one or more flat
tires, lacks current license plates and registration, or has parts removed from
the vehicle so as to render it incapable of being moved under its own power or
unlawful to operate; or
   C.   In the case of a nonmotorized vehicle, any nonmotorized vehicle,
including, but not limited to, a trailer, buggy or wagon, which is partially
disassembled, has its wheels or tires removed or flattened, or is placed on
blocks or jack stands so as to render it immobile or inoperable (other than a
properly permitted mobile home or trailer).
VEHICLE: A machine propelled by power, other than human power, designed to
travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and
transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without
limitation, automobile, truck, bicycle, trailer, motorcycle, motor driven
cycle, tractor, buggy and wagon. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-3: ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLE OR RETENTION OF DERELICT VEHICLE PROHIBITED:
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or any part thereof or the retention of a
derelict vehicle anywhere in the village, in view of the general public, is
unlawful except on the property of the owner in a lawfully constructed and
completely enclosed permanent building or other lawfully constructed and
completely enclosed permanent structure. Removal of the abandoned or derelict
vehicle or any part thereof may be authorized by order of the chief of police
after expiration of seven (7) days from the date on which notice of the
violation is mailed or posted, as provided herein. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-4: PRESUMPTIONS:
   A.   Abandonment Of Vehicle: The person to whom last was issued the
certificate of title to the vehicle by the secretary of state is presumed to be
the person to abandon that vehicle.
   B.   Derelict Vehicle On Private Property: Unless said person notifies the
police department that a derelict vehicle has been unlawfully placed upon his
or her property, the person who owns the private property on which a derelict
vehicle is retained or who occupies the private property on which the derelict
vehicle is retained, or both, is presumed to be the person responsible for
disposing of the vehicle in a safe and timely manner. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-5: REMOVAL OF VEHICLES; COSTS:
   A.   Notice To Police Of Abandoned Or Derelict Vehicle; Removal:
      1.   When an abandoned, derelict, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle
or other vehicle comes into the temporary possession of or custody of a person
in this state who is not the owner of the vehicle, such person shall
immediately notify the police department when the vehicle is within the
corporate limits of the village.
      2.   Upon receipt of such notification, the chief of police shall
authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned,
lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle.
      3.   The towing service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its
contents, maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the
owner, or any other person legally entitled to possession thereof, or until it
is disposed of as provided by this chapter.
   B.   Removal From Public Ways:
      1.   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a public right
of way in the village ten (10) hours or more, its removal by a towing service
may be authorized by order of the chief of police or his or her designee(s).
      2.   When an abandoned, derelict, unattended, wrecked, burned or
partially dismantled motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic
hazard because of its position in relation to the highway or its physical
appearance or presence is causing the impeding of traffic, a towing service may
be authorized to remove the vehicle by order of the chief of police or his or
her designee(s).
   C.   Costs Of Removal: When a vehicle is removed from either public or
private property, as authorized by order of the chief of police or his or her
designee(s), the owner of the vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs.
(Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-6: RECORDS OF TOWS:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the
police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed,
listing the color, year of the manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also
include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to,
reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. (Ord. 2009-
22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-7: RECORDS SEARCHES FOR OWNER:
   A.   When the police department does not know the identity of the registered
owner or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor vehicle
records of the state of Illinois to be searched by a directed communication to
the secretary of state for the purpose of obtaining the required ownership
information.
   B.   The police department shall cause the stolen vehicle files of the
Illinois state police to be searched by a directed communication to the
Illinois state police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the
Illinois state police files are searched with negative results, the information
contained in the national crime information center (NCIC) files will be
searched by the Illinois state police. The information determined from these
records searches will be used by the police department in sending a
notification by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising
where the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth
public sale information.
   C.   The police department may use such other databases or information
sources as may be reasonably available to the police department from time to
time. Failure of the police department to use one or more of the specified
information sources shall not constitute a failure of the police department to
adhere to its obligations under this chapter; provided, that the police
department undertakes a reasonable effort to determine the identity of the
owner of any derelict or potentially stolen motor vehicle. The village and
police department expressly disclaim any liability or responsibility for the
accurate identification of the owner of any such vehicle. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-
2009)
   D.   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the
registration files of this state or from the registration files of a foreign
state, if applicable, the police department shall notify the Illinois state
police for the purpose of identifying the vehicle owner or other person legally
entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the
Illinois state police will be immediately forwarded to the village police
department for notification of the owner. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
7-8-8: RECLAMATION OF VEHICLE:
Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided herein, the owner or other person legally entitled to
its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police department
proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. (Ord.
2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-9: SALE OF VEHICLE:
   A.   Owner Known:
      1.   Sale Authorized: Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed
motor vehicle or other vehicle, seven (7) years of age or newer, remains
unclaimed by the registered owner or other person legally entitled to its
possession for a period of thirty (30) days after notice has been given as
provided herein, the village police department shall cause it to be sold at
public sale to the highest bidder. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
      2.   Notices:
         a.   Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in a
conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the premises
where the vehicle has been impounded.
         b.   At least ten (10) days prior to the sale, the police department
shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified
mail to the registered owner or other person known by the police department and
towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle, along
with a notice to the address at which the vehicle was found (if found on
private property). Such notice shall contain a complete description of the
vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person
to reclaim the vehicle.
         c.   In those instances where the certified notification specified
herein has been returned by the postal authorities to the police department due
to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from
the registration records of this state, the sending of a second certified
notice will not be required.
   B.   Owner Unknown: When the identity of the registered owner or other
person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed
vehicle of seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means
provided in this chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or
disposed of in the manner authorized by this chapter without notice to the
registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-10: OLDER VEHICLES:
   A.   When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is
impounded as specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a
minimum of ten (10) days for the purpose of determining ownership, the
contacting of the registered owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in
person, for a determination of disposition, and an examination of the Illinois
state police stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information.
   B.   At the expiration of the ten (10) day period, without the benefit of
disposition information being received from the registered owner, the chief of
police will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk only. (Ord. 2009-22,
7-6-2009)
7-8-11: ALTERNATE PROCEDURES:
The chief of police may, based on the condition, appearance, or other facts
deemed relevant by him or her, elect to utilize either the procedure designated
by section
7-8-9 or
7-8-10 of this chapter, without regard to the age of the vehicle, and shall be
empowered to determine which procedure to utilize in his or her sole
discretion. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-12: RECORDS KEPT:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the police department
is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when
the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this
chapter, a record of the transaction shall be maintained by the police
department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.
(Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-13: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the village is authorized
to be towed away by the chief of police and disposed of as set forth in this
chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition, after the deduction of
towing, storage and processing charges, shall be deposited in the village
treasury for village use. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)
7-8-14: NONLIABILITY OF VILLAGE OR TOWING SERVICE:
Any police officer, village employee, or towing service owner or operator, or
employee thereof, shall not be held to answer or be liable for damages,
judgments or costs of any kind or to any other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the vehicle was processed
and sold or disposed of as provided by this chapter. (Ord. 2009-22, 7-6-2009)

7-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
Wherever the following words or phrases are used in this chapter, they shall,
for purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them
in this section, except when the context otherwise indicates:
 
                        The seizure, towing, and storage of a motor vehicle by
IMPOUND OR IMPOUNDMENT: or on behalf of the police department pursuant to this
                        chapter.
LESSEE:                 A person or persons who leases a vehicle under a
                        consumer lease.
LIENHOLDER OF RECORD:   A party that holds a lien on a vehicle listed on a
                        certificate of title for a vehicle.
OWNER:                  The recorded titleholder(s) of a motor vehicle. (Ord.
                        2011-22, 8-1-2011; amd. Ord. 2023-O-18, 10-2-2023)
 
7-9-2: ADMINISTRATIVE CHARGE AND PENALTY:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, in any circumstance
in which violations of this code, the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., or the Illinois Compiled Statutes authorize
or require the police department to impound a motor vehicle, or in any other
circumstance under which the police department may impound a motor vehicle
pursuant to this section, the chief of police or his or her designee is
authorized and directed to impound the motor vehicle in a location determined
by the chief of police or his or her designee. The village may order the towing
of any vehicle where authorized under the then current version of 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.7 (or any successor statute). At the time of
approval of this chapter, the list of eligible offenses includes:

   B.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the police department
may not impose an administrative fee under this Chapter if the motor vehicle
was stolen or hijacked at the time of the relevant violation and the theft or
hijacking was reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency in a timely
manner after the theft or hijacking was discovered or reasonably should have
been discovered.
   C.   The police department shall not release, or direct any person to
