      2.   To pay all costs of inspection, including resident supervision, if
deemed necessary by the village engineer. The estimated cost of inspection,
approved by the village engineer, shall be deposited with the finance director
prior to the start of work and additional funds added during the work if
required. The permittee, however, shall pay only the actual costs of such
services based on standard engineering fees. At the completion of the work, any
unused portion of the amount deposited shall be returned. No interest shall be
paid on deposited funds. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
      3.   Materials and construction methods shall be in conformance with
specifications established by the village engineer.
      4.   The engineer designing the extension shall file as built drawings at
the completion of the work with the village.
   E.   Release Of Bond: The performance bond will not be released until the
following documents are filed with the clerk and approved by the village:
      1.   As built drawings: one reproducible set and two (2) sets of prints;
      2.   Release of all permits; and
      3.   Copies of all tests required by the village engineer.
      4.   The guarantee period has expired.
   F.   Denial Of Sewer Extensions: No extension shall be allowed to the
sanitary sewer system if the village board determines that the wastewater
facilities have inadequate available capacity. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-2-7: ACCESS TO EQUIPMENT; INSPECTIONS, MEASUREMENTS AND SAMPLING:
   A.   Obstructions Prohibited:
      1.   No person shall in any manner obstruct access to any valve, hydrant,
stopcock, manhole, flow measuring equipment or any other equipment necessary to
the operation of the water or wastewater facilities which is located in any
public street, alley or easement.
      2.   No person shall in any manner obstruct access to any meter or any
flow measuring equipment located in any building.
   B.   Access And Entry Powers:
      1.   The village and its employees and the Illinois environmental
protection agency shall have ready access at all reasonable times to the
premises, places or buildings where water service is supplied for the purpose
of inspecting, examining and testing the consumption, use and flow of water,
and it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or obstruct
the village or its duly authorized agent or the Illinois environmental
protection agency in its duties hereunder. Every user of the system shall take
the same upon the conditions prescribed herein.
      2.   The duly authorized employees of the village and the Illinois
environmental protection agency, bearing proper credentials and identification,
shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection,
observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the
provisions of this title. The village or its representative shall have no
authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil
refining, ceramic, paper or other industries, beyond that point having a direct
bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or
facilities for waste treatment.
      3.   The duly authorized employees of the village or the Illinois
environmental protection agency, bearing proper credentials, shall be permitted
to enter all private properties through which the village holds a duly
negotiated or otherwise lawful easement for the purposes of, but not limited
to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of
any portion of the waterworks lying within said easement. All entry and
subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with
the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property
involved.
   C.   Discharge Monitoring:
      1.   Inspection manholes in sanitary sewers shall be capable of being
equipped with continuous twenty four (24) hour composite sampling equipment.
      2.   When property use involves handling, sale and dispensing of
petroleum products and/or automotive fluids, all sanitary sewers serving
nondomestic uses shall include such monitoring throughout the year in a manner
secured and coordinated by the village. Additionally, any property involved in
the servicing of engine powered equipment shall install a triple basin oil
separator in the sanitary line servicing the repair area of the building. This
system shall be cleaned, serviced and inspected at least twice per year.
   D.   Safety Precautions: While performing the necessary work on private
properties under this section, the duly authorized employees of the village and
the Illinois environmental protection agency shall observe all safety rules
applicable to the premises established by the company or owners of the
premises, and the company or owners of the premises shall be held harmless for
injury or death to the village employees, and the village shall indemnify the
company or owner of the premises against liability claims and demands for
personal injury or property damage asserted against the company or property
owners growing out of the gauging or sampling operation, except as such may be
caused by the negligence or failure of the company or property owner to
maintain the premises in a reasonably safe fashion. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
CHAPTER 3
FEES, RATES AND CHARGES
SECTION:
9-3-1: Combined Water And Sewer Service Charge
9-3-2: Bills For Service; Liability Of Property Owner
9-3-3: Delinquent Charges
9-3-4: Termination Procedure
9-3-5: Reinstatement Of Service
9-3-6: Disposition Of Revenues
9-3-7: Records And Reports
9-3-1: COMBINED WATER AND SEWER SERVICE CHARGE:
   A.   Charge To Be Established Periodically By The Village Board: The village
board shall, on a periodic basis, establish rates associated with the use of
the village's potable water and sanitary sewer production, distribution,
collection and treatment systems. Said rates shall be adopted by the village
board by ordinance.
   B.   Minimum Charge Required: The village of Pingree Grove constructed its
water and sewer systems through the utilization of an Illinois environmental
protection agency (IEPA) low interest loan, which loan requires the calculation
and imposition of a minimum charge per unit of water/sewer, in order to provide
for the operation of the village's public infrastructure and repayment of the
loan. That minimum charge is established on the basis of a formula that
provides for the payment of operating expenses, debt service, capital
improvements, and replacement costs for the village's infrastructure. At each
time that the village establishes a revised rate structure, it shall evaluate
the proposed structure based upon the IEPA formula, to ensure that the
village's rates are, at minimum, equal to or greater than the rate required
under the IEPA formula.
   C.   Measurement Of Flow For Charges:
      1.   Water Charges: The volume of flow used for computing basic water
user charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even
increments of one thousand (1,000) gallons. Meter and reading devices for
determining the volume of water shall be installed by the builder for new homes
at the builder's expense, and shall be owned and maintained by the village.
Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless
service is canceled, without the consent of the village.
      2.   Sewer Charges: The volume of flow used for computing basic sewer
user charges shall also be based upon metered water consumption.
         a.   Excess Sewerage: In the event that any user operates in a fashion
as to generate more sanitary sewer discharge than water utilized at its
facility, the village may either establish an additional base monthly fee for
said user, or may require the user to install and maintain, at its sole
expense, sewage flow meters. In the event such meters are installed, then the
user's water and sewer charges shall be based upon the greater of the flow
readings on either the water or sewer flow meters.
      3.   Connection To Corresponding Utility: Any user who connects to either
the village water or sewer system shall also be required to connect to the
other corresponding utility. Any discharge into the village's sewer system
shall only be from a source derived from the village's water system, unless an
excess sewerage charge is imposed under subsection C2a of this section.
      4.   Unmetered Use: The village shall not permit unmetered use of the
water or sewer systems by any user, unless such unmetered use is solely
provided for the purpose of fire protection (and in which instance, the
structure in question shall be required to have a separate, metered water
service for uses other than fire protection).
         a.   Whenever sprinkler or fire protection service is desired,
application must be made for the privilege of installing such service. Complete
plans for installation shall be attached to such petition. When said
application is approved, a contract shall be entered into with the village for
connection from village mains to the property, which connection will be made by
and the cost of same to be paid by the user. Village water will not be admitted
into any sprinkler or fire protection service unless all pipes in connection
with such system are left exposed for inspection and pressure testing. All
connections, valves and associated devices must be in compliance with the
appropriate NFPA codes. All fire suppression systems must have the appropriate
backflow protection devices as required by the NFPA, the national plumbing code
and with the approval of the village's director of public works. No connection
of any kind whatsoever, except for fire protection, shall be taken from any
fire or sprinkler service system.
      5.   Location Outside Village Limits: In the case of any user of water or
sanitary sewer who is located in whole or in part outside the corporate limits
of the village, the flow utilized/generated by such user (as reflected on the
user's meters) shall be doubled for purposes of imposing user charges.
   D.   User Rates:
      1.   Residential Base User Rates: Residential base user rates shall be
established based upon the following table of charges, as combined water and
sewer base fee and usage rates.
 
Combined Monthly Base Fee:   $45.00
Combined Consumption Charge: $7.00 per 1,000 gallons
 
      2.   Nonresidential, Industrial and Commercial User Rates: Non-
residential, industrial and commercial base user rates shall be established
based upon the following table of charges, as combined water and sewer base fee
and usage rates.
 
Combined Monthly Base Fee:   $45.00
Combined Consumption Charge: $7.00 per 1,000 gallons
 
      3.   Water Meter Charges: All use of water meters in the Village shall be
subject to the following meter charge schedule:
 
Meter Size        Monthly Charge
1 inch or smaller No additional charge
1.5 inches        $34.00
2 inches          $42.00
3 inches          $68.00
4 inches          $120.00
6 inches          $150.00
 
For water meters of any alternate size not specified above, or for sizes larger
than six inches (6") , the monthly water meter charge shall be established by
the Public Works Director.
      4.   Application Of Monthly Base Fee: Monthly base fees shall be assessed
on a per-unit basis. For all properties, where a single meter serves more than
one unit, the account associated with the meter shall have a monthly base fee
assessed for each such unit. Applicable usage charges and applicable meter fees
shall be assessed per-meter (e.g. where one meter serves three units, three
base fees shall be payable, along with one meter fee and one usage fee). For
purposes of this section, an individual “unit” shall include any separate
residential domicile (e.g. apartment, condominium or other separately
occupiable residential space meeting applicable building codes), and shall
include any separately inhabited, leased or occupied commercial or industrial
space (e.g. separately rented or inhabited office units, warehouse units or
similar divisions).
      5.   Annual Increase In Certain Charges: The consumption charge outlined
above, and the monthly meter charge outlined above, shall be automatically
increased by the greater of two percent (2%) or the consumer price index (CPI).
This adjustment shall occur automatically, each year, on November 1 of each
year, starting on November 1, 2019 and continuing thereafter until after
completion of the November 1, 2025 rate adjustment. For purposes of this
ordinance, CPI shall be determined by using the positive increase (if any) in
the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers, for all items, for the
Chicago-Naperville-Elgin, as determined by the United States Bureau of Labor
Statistics. In determining the CPI adjustment, the Village shall evaluate the
most recent ascertainable list of twelve (12)-month consumer price index
changes for the one-year lookback period (e.g. the preceding year's November to
the current year's October, if available) and shall use the greatest calculated
twelve (12)-month adjustment in that one-year lookback as that year's Cpl.
   E.   Additional Fees For All Users:
      1.   In the event that water service is shut off for any reason, other
than for repairs to the primary water valve for the service, there shall be a
seventy five dollar ($75.00) reactivation fee at the time of reactivation . A
fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) will be charged for any reactivation
outside of the normal daily operation schedule of the Public Works Department.
Reactivation shall not occur unless all past due amounts are paid in full. The
user shall also be responsible for any costs of reactivation, including any
inspection charges.
      2.   In the event that a water bill is not paid within twenty-one (21)
days after rendition of the bill, a late payment fee of ten percent (10%) shall
apply. Utility billing accounts shall be entitled to a one-time waiver of this
late payment fee, for a single utility billing period (i.e. two months). In
addition, utility billing accounts shall be entitled to a one-time waiver of
this late payment fee, for a single utility billing period (i.e. two months),
provided that they enroll in the Village's automatic payment system for utility
billing and payment.
      3.   The rates contemplated above are for users generating normal
domestic waste concentrations. For purposes of this section, that includes
waste that has a five (5) day, twenty-degree centigrade (20°C) biochemical
oxygen demand (BOD) of not more than two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/
1), and a suspended solids (SS) content of not more than two hundred forty
milligrams per liter (240 mg/1). Village approval shall be required prior to
discharge of any waste which does not fall within those parameters, and a
supplemental charge shall be established by the Public Works Director prior to
such discharge. The Public Works Director may also require the party
discharging any such waste to provide on-site pretreatment or to take other
similar steps if deemed necessary to ensure the safe and efficient operation of
the Village's wastewater system. (Ord. 2015-O-16, 6-15-2015; amd. Ord. 2019-O-
31, 9-3-2019)
9-3-2: BILLS FOR SERVICE; LIABILITY OF PROPERTY OWNER:
   A.   Bimonthly Bills: The village shall render bimonthly (once every 2
months) bills for services and for all rates and charges in connection
therewith and shall collect all monies due thereon. Notwithstanding any
contrary provision of this title, all monies paid to the village shall be
credited and applied as required under title 3, chapter 6, “Village Service
Accounts”, of this code.
   B.   Multiple Water Meters: Single users with multiple water meters or flow
meters may be rendered a single bill.
   C.   Sewer Bills: Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the village
finance director on the first day of the month succeeding the period for which
the service is billed.
   D.   Liability For Service: The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof
and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for
the service furnished such premises.
   E.   Billing to Customer: Each user of water shall be required to provide
the Village with the name and contact information for the owner of the property
served by Village water service. The Village’s default shall be to bill the
owner of the property, and the owner shall be responsible for arranging for
payments of all charges imposed. Upon the owner’s request, an account may be
established in the tenant’s name and bills sent to the tenant, but the owner
and tenant shall be jointly and severally liable pursuant to subsection (D)
above. In the event that the tenant is listed on the account, the tenant may
obtain a final read, pay the final bill and be removed from the account, all
with the owner’s consent. Alternatively, the Village reserves the right to
refuse to permit a tenant to be listed on the account, or the right to only
invoice the owner of the property, in conditions where the tenant fails to
maintain current service, pay outstanding invoices, or otherwise fails to
maintain the account in good standing.
   F.   Billing Disputes: Any dispute over a service bill must first go before
the Utility Billing Supervisor. The customer, prior to the due date of the
disputed bill, shall contact the Utility Billing Supervisor in writing stating
why all or part of the bill is being disputed and the basis for the dispute.
Within three (3) business days after receipt of the customer’s written notice,
the Village shall schedule an informal meeting with the customer. Within five
(5) business days after the meeting, the Village shall notify the customer, in
writing, of its decision. If the customer objects to the decision, a formal
hearing may be requested before the Village Manager. The request for a hearing
must be made in writing within five (5) business days of receipt of the
decision from the Village. The hearing shall be held within ten (10) business
days of receipt of the hearing request. The decision of the Village Manager
shall be final. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008; amd. 2011 Code; Ord. 2012-06, 4-16-
2012; Ord. 2015-O-16, 6-15-2015; Ord. 2019-O-15, 5-20-2019; Ord. 2022-O-09, 4-
4-2022)
9-3-3: DELINQUENT CHARGES:
In the event the charges for service are not fully paid within twenty one (21)
days after the rendering of the bill for such service, such charges shall be
deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter, such
delinquencies shall constitute liens upon the real estate for which such
service is supplied, subject to compliance with the provisions described in
this section.
   A.   Lien Provisions:
      1.   Upon or after the date at which a water bill becomes delinquent as
described above, the village clerk or a designee thereof shall send to the
owner of record of the real estate, at the address indicated on the most recent
ascertainable tax records for the property (based upon the PIN thereof): a) a
copy of each delinquency notice and/or past due bill sent to the property or
the person responsible for paying the utility bills therefor (and such other
information as may be necessary to inform the owner of record of the delinquent
bills outstanding); and b) a notice that unpaid charges or rates may become a
lien on the property.
      2.   At any time after dispatching the notice to the owner, the village
clerk or a designee thereof shall cause to be prepared and recorded with the
county recorder's office a notice of lien, which notice shall be a sworn
statement and shall include the following information: a) a description of the
real estate sufficient for its identification (e.g., legal description); b) the
amount of money due as a result of utility service; c) the date when each
amount became delinquent; and d) the authority of the village to impose a lien
pursuant to this chapter and section 5/11-139-8 of the Illinois municipal code.
The village clerk or a designee thereof may file such additional liens as may
thereafter be appropriate from time to time, after the provision of additional
notice to the owner of record. The costs described in each such lien shall
include all charges or expenses incurred by the village in delivering the
utility service and in preparing and filing the lien.
      3.   The village manager shall be authorized to direct the village
attorneys, at any time, to file suit to foreclose upon any liens filed under
this chapter, or to file a civil action against the occupant or user of the
property in question, to recover the amounts due the village. Any such action
shall also seek the award of court costs, legal fees, and other expenses
incurred by the village in prosecuting the delinquent account or otherwise in
seeking payment therefor. Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges may be
sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied
to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of
statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the
village, or by the above referenced statutory procedure.
      4.   Upon the entry of a judgment in favor of the village in an action
filed under subsection A3 of this section or upon the payment of all sums due
in satisfaction of the delinquent account and all related village expenses, the
village shall tender to the property owner, at the address described in
subsection A1 of this section, a release of lien. (Ord. 2008-45, 11-17-2008)
9-3-4: TERMINATION PROCEDURE:
In the event that utility service charges are not fully paid within twenty one
(21) days after the rendering of the bill for such service, the village shall
send a reminder notice with a ten percent (10%) penalty fee assessed. In the
event that utility service charges are not paid within ten (10) days after the
date of mailing of the reminder notice, the disconnection process shall begin.
A disconnection notice will be posted onto the residence in a prominent place
to be displayed for the attention of the occupant. The occupant will have five
(5) days from the posting of the disconnection notice to pay all amounts due to
the village or services will be disconnected. A reconnection fee of seventy
five dollars ($75.00) shall be charged in the event of disconnection. This fee
must be paid before service is restored. Reconnections are performed Monday
through Friday from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to two o'clock (2:00) P.M., or at
such time as the village director of public works shall later designate.
Connections performed outside of these hours are charged one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00). The occupant or designee must be home in order to reconnect
service.
Service shall not be reinstated until all outstanding amounts due to the
village have been paid in full, including the seventy five dollar ($75.00)
reconnection fee if applicable. The reminder notice relating to the
disconnection or reconnection of utility service shall be in a form and content
acceptable to the village finance director, and the fees associated with the
termination, reconnection or processing terminations shall be set by the
village board from time to time. The fees outlined herein may be amended by the
village board through the adoption of an update to the village's unified fee
schedule, without requirement of directly amending this section. (Ord. 2015-O-
32, 11-2-2015)
9-3-5: REINSTATEMENT OF SERVICE:
   A.   Upon payment to the village of the full delinquency, plus costs of
termination and applicable administrative or reinstatement fees (which fees
shall be subject to adjustment from time to time by the village manager or
administrator), and upon deposit with the village of an amount equal to the
estimated user charges for one billing period, the village will reinstate the
service or issue a permit for the service to be reinstated. All payments shall
be credited per title 3, chapter 6, "Village Service Accounts", of this code.
(Ord. 2012-06, 4-16-2012)
   B.   If a permit is issued to reinstate the service, the owner of the
premises or the occupant and user of the service shall pay all costs necessary
to reinstate the service, including inspection and supervision costs incurred
by the village.
   C.   The user shall continue to pay the charges assessed hereunder by the
village thereafter as billed, and after ten (10) billing periods of prompt
payment of such charges with no delinquency in excess of thirty (30) days, the
deposit shall be refunded to the person having made such deposit, without
interest thereon.
   D.   Upon payment of the fees and reinstatement of service, the red tag from
the building shall be removed, and the building shall, so far as the village is
concerned, be fit for human occupancy.
   E.   In order for the village to reinstate service, the property owner or a
representative of the property owner must be present. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009)
9-3-6: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
All revenues and monies derived from water and sewer charges shall be held by
the finance director in the water and sewerage accounts, respectively. All such
revenues shall be held separate and apart from all other funds of the village,
and all of said sum, without any deductions whatsoever, shall be delivered to
the village finance director not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the
same or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by
the village board of trustees. The village finance director shall receive all
such revenues from the water and sewerage system and all other funds and monies
incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him,
and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the "water fund
of the village of Pingree Grove" and the "sewerage fund of the village of
Pingree Grove", respectively. The finance director shall administer such fund
in every respect in the manner provided by statute in the Illinois municipal
code. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
9-3-7: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Accounts And Records: The village finance director shall also maintain
records relating to the cost of operating, maintaining and repairing the water
facilities and wastewater facilities, and pertaining to the charges or payments
associated therewith. The finance director shall establish a proper system of
accounts and shall keep books, records and accounts in which complete and
correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the water and
sewerage system and, at regular annual intervals, shall cause to be made an
audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the water and sewerage system. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008; amd.
2011 Code)
   B.   Annual Audit Report: In addition to the customary operating statements,
the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses
of the water and wastewater facilities, including a replacement cost, to
indicate that water and sewer service charges under the waste cost recovery
system do in fact meet these regulations. In this regard, the financial
information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year.
      2.   Flow data showing the total output of the combined water plants for
the current fiscal year.
      3.   Debt service for the next fiscal year.
      4.   Number of users connected to each system.
      5.   Number of nonmetered users of each system.
      6.   A list of users discharging nondomestic and industrial wastes and
volume of waste discharged. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
CHAPTER 4
WATER FACILITIES
SECTION:
9-4-1: Connection To Public Facilities; Costs
9-4-2: Private Water Supply
9-4-3: Tapping Water Mains
9-4-4: Service Pipes
9-4-5: Fire Hydrants
9-4-6: Authority To Shut Off Water
9-4-7: Conservation Measures
9-4-8: Discontinuing Service
9-4-1: CONNECTION TO PUBLIC FACILITIES; COSTS:
   A.   The owners of all houses, buildings or properties situated within the
village and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which there is now
located a public water main may make connection to the public water main within
one hundred twenty (120) days after notice that the water main is available.
The owner shall pay all costs of connection, including recapture fees, if
applicable.
   B.   The owners of all houses, buildings or properties situated within the
village and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which a public
water main is within three hundred feet (300') of the nearest property line of
the property may extend the public water main to and across the frontage of the
property and make connection as herein provided. If such water main extension
benefits other properties, the village shall make best efforts to collect and
return to the owner amounts received from benefited properties.
   C.   After connection to the public water supply, the private water supply
shall be physically disconnected from the building water piping connected to
the public water supply. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-4-2: PRIVATE WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   Whenever a public water main is not available, as provided in this
title, the building service pipe shall be connected to a private water supply
complying with the provisions of this section.
   B.   Whenever an industrial user requires water for industrial purposes and
the village determines that the village water facilities have inadequate
capacity to provide the pressure, volume or rate flow required by said
industry, the user may be required to install a private water supply. Provided,
however, the private water supply shall not be used for any purpose except for
industrial purposes, and no cross connection shall be made to the public water
supply.
   C.   A private water supply shall not be used for domestic purposes for any
building except a single-family residence. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-4-3: TAPPING WATER MAINS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall make a connection to the water
facilities of the village without first making application for the privilege of
making said connection and to have a written permit paid all applicable fees.
   B.   Conditions Of Permit Issuance: No permit will be issued until the
permittee:
      1.   Pays the tapping fee as set out in subsection C of this section.
      2.   Pays the cost of the meter and installation thereof 1 .
      3.   Secures a street opening permit, if required.
      4.   Agrees to pay all costs of the installation of said service.
      5.   Agrees to give a minimum of twenty four (24) hours' notice prior to
the start of the installation of the service and when the service shall be
ready for inspection; except, that no inspections shall be made at times other
than during regular village working hours.
      6.   Agrees that the materials used and the method of installation shall
be in conformance with specifications established by ordinance or other codes.
      7.   Agrees to pay all costs of inspection and testing if inspection in
excess of the inspection and testing normally provided by the village is deemed
necessary by the village manager or designee.
      8.   Agrees to secure and protect the village from any liability or
damage whatsoever for injury (including death) to any person or property and
files with the clerk liability insurance certificates. The amount of the
insurance shall be established by the village board. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009)
   C.   Fees 2 :
      1.   Required; Payment: Water tapping fees shall be charged for
connecting or tapping into the water facilities. Said fees shall be paid at the
time of application for building permit. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
      2.   Inside Village Limits: Water tapping fees for plats approved (unless
otherwise required under the terms of an applicable annexation/development
agreement during the term of said agreement) are as follows:
Residential         $825.00/P.E.
Commercial/industrial:
 1 inch                3,000.00
 11/2 inch             3,500.00
 2 inch                4,000.00
 21/2 inch             5,000.00
 3 inch                6,000.00
 31/2 inch             7,000.00
 4 inch                8,000.00
 41/2 inch             9,000.00
 5 inch                10,000.00
 51/2 inch             11,000.00
 6 inch                12,000.00
 
      3.   Outside Village Limits: The water tapping fee for any use not
located within the corporate limits of the village shall be three (3) times the
applicable tapping fee specified in subsection C2 of this section. (Ord. 2009-
18, 6-15-2009)

  10-4-2 of this code.

  10-4-1B of this code.
9-4-4: SERVICE PIPES:
   A.   Water Service Pipe:
      1.   The water service pipe extends from the village water main to and
includes the curb stopcock which shall be located in a street or an easement.
      2.   The pipe, valves and fittings used for the service pipe shall be as
specified by the village. The user may make the service pipe tap to the water
main, or the village may allow the user's contractor to make the connection
under the supervision of the director of public works.
      3.   The permittee shall pay all costs of installing the service
including such material and services provided by the village. The village shall
maintain only the water service pipe.
   B.   Building Service Pipe:
      1.   The building service pipe extends from the curb stopcock to the
building and shall be installed by the user at his expense. The building
service pipe shall be the same size and same material as the water service pipe
and shall be inspected by the village.
      2.   Persons taking water must do so at their own expense, and must keep
the building service pipe in good repair, protect it from frost or damage in
any other manner and prevent all unnecessary waste of water. It shall be the
duty of the user to maintain the building service pipe from the curb stopcock
to the house. If the user fails to properly maintain the building service pipe,
the village shall have the authority to enter onto the property and provide
maintenance as required and bill for the cost of said maintenance on the next
water bill or shut the water off until proper maintenance is completed.
   C.   Separate Services Required: A separate water service pipe is required
for every building or residence. Where a building contains more than one
commercial or industrial use or where the building contains a combination of
commercial or industrial and residential uses, there shall be separate services
for each use if required by the village. A single meter is allowed only in
buildings for residential use. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-4-5: FIRE HYDRANTS:
   A.   Opening Hydrants; Damage Prohibited: All hydrants constructed for the
purpose of extinguishing fires are hereby declared to be public hydrants. No
persons other than members of a fire protection district and those authorized
by the village shall open any such hydrant or attempt to draw water from same
or in any manner interfere with or injure any of such hydrants.
   B.   Obstruction Prohibited: No person shall obstruct the use of any fire
hydrant or place any material in front thereof. Any material forming such
obstruction may be removed by the village or by the fire protection district.
The cost of removal shall be borne by the property owner thereof.
   C.   Wrenches: No person shall use any water hydrant wrenches without the
permission of the village.
   D.   Temporary Use: Any person wishing to make a connection to a hydrant as
a temporary source of water for construction or other approved purposes shall
make application to the village no less than forty eight (48) hours in advance
to request a hydrant meter. The user shall make a deposit equal to the
replacement cost of the meter which shall be refunded when the meter is
returned. The meter will be read on installation and again on disconnection,
and the user will be billed at the current rate for water use. The user shall
be responsible for the meter and usage. The deposit will not be returned until
all payments have been made. Meters will be supplied as available on a week to
week basis. The village shall install and remove the meter. It will be a
violation of terms to use the meter without attached RPZ. The village reserves
the right to restrict or rescind the use of the hydrant meter or charge a usage
rate equivalent to three (3) times (300 percent) the normal usage rate whenever
water conservation rates are in effect.
   E.   Large Bulk Users: Large bulk users are required to fill at a single
designated hydrant located on the water treatment facility property. All large
bulk users are required to maintain a physical air gap between the fill hose
and tank. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009)
9-4-6: AUTHORITY TO SHUT OFF WATER:
In the case of making repairs or alterations or constructing new facilities, or
for any other reason, the village reserves the right to shut off the water as
long as may be necessary to make such repairs, alterations or the construction
of new facilities. No claim shall be made against the village by reason of the
above or by reason of the breakage or failure of any pump or other portion of
the water system. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-4-7: CONSERVATION MEASURES:
   A.   Outdoor Use Limitations: In order to promote public environmental
awareness, good husbandry, good conservation practices and to preserve potable
water supplies, the use of the village potable water for outdoor watering of
landscape and lawns is limited as follows:
      1.   Condition Green: Condition green shall allow the outside use of the
village potable water supply. Condition green shall be the normal operating
condition in the absence of a proclamation by the village in accordance with
subsection A2 of this section.
      2.   Restrictions: Whenever, in the village's judgment, it is in the
public interest to further curtail the use of potable water for landscape and
lawn watering purposes, in light of environmental exigencies or water supply
availability, the president or his designee may further restrict the use of
potable water for such purposes by proclaiming the following restrictive
conditions:
         a.   Condition Yellow: Condition yellow shall allow the outside use of
the village potable water supply for landscaping and lawn watering only on
alternate days, except between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and six
o'clock (6:00) P.M., during which time said use is prohibited. Lots with odd
numbered addresses will be permitted to use potable water outside on odd
numbered days, and lots with even numbered addresses will be permitted to use
potable water outside on even numbered days.
         b.   Condition Red: Condition red shall prohibit the use of outside
potable water for residential hand washing of motor vehicles, landscape and
lawn watering purposes entirely.
         c.   Notice Of Proclamation: Upon issuing any proclamation, the
village president shall make the contents thereof known to the public by news
release to the local newspapers and may also notify the citizens in any other
practical manner that he or she shall devise. Further, the village president
shall immediately notify all members of the village board of trustees of the
nature of the emergency and the regulations that have been imposed.
      3.   Signs Posted: The village shall cause signs to be posted in
conspicuous public places throughout the village, advising residents of the
watering conditions then in effect.
   B.   Rates During Conservation Months: During the months of June, July and
August, consumption charges may, in the discretion of the village board be
increased three (3) times the combined rate per one thousand (1,000) gallons
for all water consumed above eighteen thousand (18,000) gallons.
   C.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this
section between May 15 and September 15 of any calendar year shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation continues or
persists shall be deemed a separate offense. During condition red status, as
defined in subsection A2b of this section, a fine shall be levied at any time
during the year that a violation occurs. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-4-8: DISCONTINUING SERVICE:
Any person moving from or within the village shall give written notice to the
village for final meter reading. Otherwise, the user shall be liable for the
charge for the ensuing water billing period. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
CHAPTER 5
WASTEWATER FACILITIES
SECTION:
9-5-1: Use Of Public Facilities
9-5-2: Private Wastewater Treatment Facilities
9-5-3: Connection To Public Facilities
9-5-4: Building Sewers
9-5-5: Permitted Wastes
9-5-6: Prohibited Wastes
9-5-7: Interceptors
9-5-8: Pretreatment
9-5-9: User Charge
9-5-10: Authority To Limit Discharges
9-5-1: USE OF PUBLIC FACILITIES:
   A.   Discharge Of Human And Animal Wastes: It shall be unlawful for any
person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon
public or private property within village, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the village, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other
objectionable waste.
   B.   Discharge Into Watercourses: It shall be unlawful to discharge to any
watercourse within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the
village, any untreated sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or polluted waters.
   C.   Private Systems: It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any
privy, privy vault or cesspool intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
   D.   Connection To Public System:
      1.   The owners of all houses, buildings or properties situated within
the village and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which there is
located a public sewer may make connection to the public sewer within one
hundred twenty (120) days after notice that the public sewer is available. The
owner shall pay all costs of connection, including recapture fees, if
applicable.
      2.   The owners of all houses, buildings or properties situated within
the village and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which a public
sewer is within three hundred feet (300') of the nearest property line of the
property may extend the public sewer to and across the frontage of the property
and make connection as herein provided. If such public sewer benefits other
properties, the village may, but need not, make best efforts to collect and
return to the owners amounts received from benefited properties. (Ord. 2008-13,
4-7-2008)
9-5-2: PRIVATE WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES:
   A.   Discharging To Watercourse Prohibited: No person shall construct a
wastewater treatment facility within the village, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the village, for the purpose of treating wastewater and
discharging same to a watercourse.
   B.   Industrial Wastes: No person shall construct a wastewater treatment
facility within the corporate limits of the village for the purpose of treating
industrial wastes unless the village board determines that the existing
wastewater treatment facilities have inadequate capacity and issues a permit
for the construction and operation of a wastewater treatment facility. No
village permit shall become effective until:
      1.   An IEPA permit to construct and operate the facility has been
received.
      2.   An NPDES permit has been received.
      3.   The village engineer has approved the plans and specifications in
writing.
      4.   The guarantee period has expired.
   C.   Subsurface Disposal:
      1.   No person shall construct a private wastewater treatment facility
with subsurface disposal of the effluent if the population to be served exceeds
ten (10) persons or the system is intended to serve more than one building.
      2.   Where a public sewer is not available, a private wastewater
treatment facility employing subsurface absorption facilities may be installed,
if the wastewater to be treated is from a residence.
      3.   Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater
treatment facility employing subsurface absorption facilities, the owner shall
first obtain a written permit. The applicant shall supplement by any plans,
specifications and other information as deemed necessary. A permit and
inspection fee shall be paid at the time the application is filed, and shall be
in such amount as the village may from time to time determine. The permit shall
not be issued until applicable county permits are on file with the village.
      4.   A permit for a private wastewater treatment facility employing
subsurface absorption facilities shall not become effective until the
installation is completed to the satisfaction of the village. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-
7-2008)
9-5-3: CONNECTION TO PUBLIC FACILITIES:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct a new wastewater source and
connect same to the wastewater facilities of the village without first making
application for the privilege of making said connection and to have a written
permit and to pay all fees.
   B.   Wastewater Information Required: Persons desiring to construct a waste
source and connect to the wastewater facilities of the village shall, in
addition to making application, state the quantity, quality and rate of
discharge of the wastewater to be discharged into the sewer.
   C.   Conditions Of Permit Issuance: No permit will be issued until the
permittee: (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009)
      1.   Pays the applicable connection fee as set out in subsection D of
this section. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
      2.   Secures a street opening permit, if required.
      3.   Agrees to pay all costs of the installation including the connection
to the public sewer, if required.
      4.   Agrees to give twenty four (24) hours' notice prior to the start of
any underground piping and when the underground piping will be ready for
inspection.
      5.   Agrees that the materials used and the method of installation shall
be in conformance with specifications established by the village engineer.
      6.   Agrees to pay all costs of inspection.
      7.   Agrees to conform to all rules and regulations of the Illinois state
plumbing code.
      8.   Agrees to secure and protect the village from any liability or
damage whatsoever for injury, including death, to any person or property and
files liability insurance certificates.
      9.   Secures an IEPA permit if the wastewater:
         a.   Is domestic and the volume to be discharged is more than one
thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons per day (gpd); or
         b.   Is industrial.
      10.   Secures a building permit if the new waste source is new equipment
to be installed within an existing building.
      11.   Agrees to conform to all applicable village ordinances. (Ord. 2009-
18, 6-15-2009)
   D.   Fees 1 :
      1.   Fees shall be charged for constructing a wastewater source and
connecting it to the wastewater facilities of the village as provided by
ordinance or resolution and as follows: (Ord. 2009-18, 6-15-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
 
Residential fee           $1,500.00/P.E.
Commercial/industrial fee 1,200.00/P.E.
 
      2.   For uses involving extra strength wastewater:
         a.   For wastewater the strength of which exceeds normal residential
wastewater in any constituent, if allowed by the village board, there shall be
charged a surcharge computed at the time that connection is requested.
         b.   Where the volume and strength of the wastewater to be discharged
to the public sanitary sewers is not known at the time of the connection, the
fee shall be estimated and adjusted to reflect actual conditions during the
billing period just prior to a full year of operation.
         c.   The volume and strength of the wastewater for fee purposes shall
be the maximum daily discharge of constituents.
         d.   Where a connection is made based on the applicant's statement
that the strength of the wastewater does not exceed normal domestic wastewater
in any constituent, and at the end of the billing period just prior to a full
year of operation, it is determined that the wastewater does exceed domestic
wastewater in strength, the village board may accept or reject the wastes.
      3.   The tapping fee for any use not located within the corporate limits
of the village shall be three (3) times the applicable tapping fee specified in
subsection D1 of this section.
   E.   Restrictions And Requirements:
      1.   No connection will be allowed to the wastewater facilities if the
village board determines:
         a.   That the wastewater facilities have inadequate treatment or
delivery capacity; or
         b.   That the wastewater contains incompatible wastes in excess of
that allowed by this chapter; or
         c.   That the wastewater contains inadmissible substances; or
         d.   That the strength, volume or rate of discharge of a compatible
waste from a single source or class of users alters substantially the operation
of the wastewater facilities.
      2.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title, this chapter
hereby prohibits any connections from inflow sources into the sanitary sewer
portions of the sewer system and shall ensure that new sewers and connections
to the sewer system are properly designed and constructed. This chapter also
requires:
         a.   Pretreatment of any industrial wastes which would otherwise be
detrimental to the wastewater treatment works or its proper efficient operation
and maintenance or will otherwise prevent entry of such wastes into the
wastewater treatment works.
         b.   Compliance with 35 Illinois administrative code 310 (pretreatment
programs).
         c.   Prohibition of the introduction of industrial waste into the
sewer system until title 35, subtitle C, chapter II of the Illinois
administrative code, section 365.920 (user charges) are met. (Ord. 2009-18, 6-
15-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  10-4-1B of this code.
9-5-4: BUILDING SEWERS:
   A.   Permit Required: No addition to or alteration of any building sewer
shall be made or caused to be made by any person without a permit.
   B.   Separate Sewers Required: A separate and independent building sewer
shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the
rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be
constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard or
driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the
rear building and the whole considered as one building.
   C.   Old Sewers: Old building sewers may be used in connection with new
buildings only when they are found, on examination and test, to meet all
requirements of a new building sewer.
   D.   Location; Specifications:
      1.   Whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the
building at an elevation below the basement floor.
      2.   No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet
(3') of any bearing wall.
      3.   No building sewers shall be installed in any place where they may be
subject to freezing temperatures unless adequate provisions are made to protect
them from frost.
      4.   Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe
and fittings, or a manhole.
   E.   Lift Station: In all buildings in which any building drain is too low
to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such
drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the
building sewer.
   F.   Maintenance Of Building Sewer: Persons connected to the sanitary sewer
system through a building sewer shall maintain said building sewer in good
repair, protect it from damage in any manner and prevent the entrance of
uncontaminated waters. If the user fails to properly maintain the building
sewer, the village shall have the authority to enter onto the property to
maintain the sewer and add the cost of said maintenance on the next sewer use
bill or terminate the service until proper maintenance is completed.
   G.   Inspection Manhole: All industrial users and such other users, except
domestic users, as may be determined by the village, shall install an
inspection manhole on the building sewer. Said manhole shall be located
conveniently in the public right of way or easement. The manhole shall be a
minimum of forty eight inches (48") in diameter and shall be equipped with such
measuring and sampling equipment as may be required by the village. (Ord. 2008-
13, 4-7-2008)
9-5-5: PERMITTED WASTES:
   A.   The following wastes are admissible to the wastewater facilities of the
village:
      1.   Any compatible pollutant; except, that the strength, volume and rate
of flow of the waste may be regulated.
      2.   Any incompatible pollutant which is identified in the NPDES permit
received by the village; except, that the total from all sources may not exceed
the amount allowed under the NPDES permit.
      3.   Any incompatible pollutant for which an effluent standard has been
established by the IEPA; provided, that:
         a.   The aggregate total from all sources shall not exceed the total
allowable to the wastewater treatment facilities based on the average dry
weather flow. It is assumed that there will be no removal of the incompatible
waste in the treatment facilities.
         b.   The concentration of the incompatible waste discharged from any
source shall not exceed two (2) times the concentration allowed in the
wastewater treatment facility effluent.
         c.   The concentration of the incompatible waste in the wastewater
treatment facility shall not exceed the maximum allowed by the IEPA.
         d.   The concentration of the incompatible waste will not adversely
affect the stream standards established for the village discharge stream.
      4.   Cooling water or other uncontaminated industrial process water.
   B.   The village may from time to time establish maximum concentrations of
various pollutants in the wastewater treatment facility effluent. (Ord. 2008-
13, 4-7-2008)
9-5-6: PROHIBITED WASTES:
The following wastes shall not be introduced into the wastewater facilities of
the village:
   A.   Wastes which interfere with the operation of the wastewater facilities.
   B.   Any cyanide or cyanogen compound.
   C.   Mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 milligrams per
liter as Hg at any time.
   D.   Stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff and subsurface
drainage.
   E.   Uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters.
   F.   Wastes which may create a fire or explosion hazard in the wastewater
facilities.
   G.   Wastes which will cause corrosive structural damage to the wastewater
facilities.
   H.   Wastes with a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0.
   I.   Solid or viscous wastes in amounts which would cause obstructions to
flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the
wastewater facilities.
   J.   Wastes at a flow rate and/or pollutant discharge rate which is
excessive over relatively short time periods so there is a treatment process
upset and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency. Provided, however, that
concentration of any given constituent or quantity of flow shall not exceed
five (5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during
normal operation for any period exceeding fifteen (15) minutes.
   K.   Any compatible waste, the strength of which exceeds normal domestic
wastewater in any constituent except as permitted by the village board.
   L.   Any waste containing more than one hundred milligrams per liter (100mg/
l) of fats, oils or grease.
   M.   The discharge of garbage into the wastewater facilities by any user
(except discharge of a domestic residential user from a conventional garbage
disposal).
   N.   Any liquid having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees
Fahrenheit (150°F).
   O.   Any wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor producing
substances in such concentrations exceeding limits established by the village
board.
   P.   Any wastes which will cause discoloration such as, but not limited to,
dye wastes or printing inks.
   Q.   Any wastes which, alone or in combination with other wastes, will cause
the violation of any effluent or stream standards established by the IEPA.
(Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-5-7: INTERCEPTORS:
   A.   A grease interceptor (trap) shall be installed if the grease content of
the wastewater exceeds one hundred milligrams per liter (100mg/l). The grease
trap shall be located so it may be readily cleaned and inspected. Each grease
trap shall be sized so it will continuously produce an effluent containing less
than one hundred milligrams per liter (100mg/l) of fats, oils or grease. Each
grease trap shall be properly maintained at no cost to the village. A permit is
required for a grease interceptor.
   B.   An oil or sand interceptor shall be installed to prevent the entrance
of sand, or similar granular material, or oil into the wastewater facilities of
the village. Said interceptor shall be properly constructed and continuously
maintained by the user. A separate fee and permit may be required for each oil
or sand interceptor.
   C.   Equipment and devices installed under this section shall not be
considered to provide pretreatment to the wastewater. No special operation
permits or operating data shall be required. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-5-8: PRETREATMENT:
   A.   Any user discharging or proposing to discharge any wastewater into the
wastewater facilities of the village which contains substances or possesses the
characteristics enumerated in this chapter and/or which are in violation of the
standards established by the IEPA or USEPA shall provide pretreatment of the
wastewater to an acceptable condition for discharge to the wastewater
facilities. All required permits shall be filed with the village prior to
construction of the pretreatment facilities.
   B.   Any user discharging or proposing to discharge a compatible waste, the
strength of which exceeds normal domestic waste in any constituent, shall
install a pretreatment facility if required by the village. If pretreatment is
required, it shall apply uniformly to all users within the industry number.
   C.   Any user proposing to construct a pretreatment facility shall have the
plans and specifications approved in writing by the village engineer and an
IEPA permit prior to receiving a permit by the village.
   D.   Any user proposing to operate a pretreatment facility shall comply with
all requirements of the IEPA and shall submit such operating data as may be
required by the village. (Ord. 2008-13, 4-7-2008)
9-5-9: USER CHARGE 1 :
   A.   Policy: It is hereby declared that the policy of the village is:
      1.   The village shall adhere to the requirements of title 40,
"protection of the environment", chapter 1, "environmental protection agency",
subchapter B, "grants", part 35, "state and local assistance, final grant
regulations", and all subsequent enactments and regulations issued pursuant to
the federal water pollution control act of 1972, as amended from time to time.
      2.   No funds for the operation and maintenance of the wastewater
facilities shall be derived from the use of an ad valorem tax.
      3.   No charge will be made for any inadmissible waste.
      4.   Where the removal of any constituent is incidental to the treatment
process, no charge will be made for that constituent.
      5.   All wastes, the strength of which does not exceed normal domestic
waste in any constituent, shall, for billing purposes, be considered to be
normal domestic wastes. Use charges for normal domestic wastes shall be based
on flow alone.
      6.   Charges for extra strength wastes shall be expressed in dollars per
pound of constituent in excess of normal domestic wastewater.
   B.   Summary Of Users: Annually, concurrently with the determination of the
cost of operation and maintenance, the village shall make a summary of all
users. Said summary shall include a summary of all domestic users with a
breakdown as to whether the village or a private water supply is used, a
summary of commercial users listing all such users discharging industrial
wastes and/or subject to a surcharge, and a summary of all industries listing
all such users discharging industrial wastes and/or subject to a surcharge.
Where a user discharges industrial wastes and/or is subject to a surcharge, an
estimate of the volume and strength of said wastewater shall be made. (Ord.
2008-13, 4-7-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  9-3-1 of this title for specific amounts.
9-5-10: AUTHORITY TO LIMIT DISCHARGES:
In case of making repairs or alterations or constructing new facilities, or for
any other reason, the village board reserves the right to limit the discharge
of wastewater to the wastewater facilities for as long as may be necessary by
giving such reasonable notice thereof as shall be practical to the user. No
claim shall be made against the village by reason of the above or by reason of
the breakage or failure of any portion of the wastewater facilities. (Ord.
2008-13, 4-7-2008)
TITLE 10
BUILDING AND DEVELOPMENT
CHAPTER 1
APPLICABILITY; ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
10-1-1: Building Commissioner
10-1-2: Applicability Of Provisions
10-1-3: Ordinary Repairs
10-1-4: Service Equipment
10-1-5: Maintenance
10-1-6: Existing Uses And Structures
10-1-7: Inspections
10-1-8: Right Of Entry
10-1-9: Violations; Penalties
10-1-1: BUILDING COMMISSIONER:
   A.   Created; Appointment; Engineer May Serve As: There is hereby created
the office of building commissioner. The building commissioner shall be
appointed by the village manager 1 . In the absence of a person specifically
designated by the village manager, the village manager shall serve as the
building commissioner.
   B.   Organization And Assistance: The building commissioner shall request
employment of technical assistants, inspectors and other employees as shall be
necessary for the administration of this title and as authorized by the village
manager. The building commissioner may designate an employee or other person to
serve as his assistant who shall exercise all his powers as so directed. (1990
Code §16.207; amd. 2011 Code)
   C.   Nonliability From Personal Responsibility:
      1.   The building commissioner, or officer or employee charged with the
enforcement of this title, while acting for the village, shall not thereby
render himself liable personally, and is relieved from all personal liability
for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act
required or permitted in the discharge of his official duties. (1990 Code
§16.207)
      2.   Any suit instituted against any officer or employee because of an
act performed by him in the lawful discharge of his duties and under the
provisions of this title shall be defended by the village attorney until the
final termination of the proceedings. (1990 Code §16.207; amd. 2011 Code)
      3.   The building commissioner, or any of his subordinates, shall not be
liable for costs in any action, suit or proceeding that may be instituted in
pursuance of the provisions of this title; and any person acting as the
building commissioner, or anyone acting as his agent or employee, while acting
in good faith and without malice, shall be free from liability for acts
performed under any of the provisions of this title or by reason of any act or
omission in the performance of official duties in connection therewith.
   D.   General Duties: The building commissioner shall enforce, or cause to be
enforced, all the provisions of this title and shall act on any question
relative to the mode and manner of construction and the materials to be used in
the erection, addition to, alteration, repair, removal, demolition,
installation of service equipment, and the location, use, occupancy and
maintenance of all buildings and structures, except as may otherwise be
specifically provided for by statutory requirements.
   E.   Applications And Permits: The building commissioner shall receive
applications and issue permits for the erection and alteration of buildings and
structures, and inspect the premises for which such permits have been issued
and enforce compliance with the provisions of this title.
   F.   Notices And Orders: The building commissioner shall issue notices or
orders to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to require the necessary
safeguards during construction, to require adequate exitway facilities in
existing buildings and structures, and to ensure compliance with all
requirements for the safety, health and general welfare of the public.
   G.   Inspections: The building commissioner shall make or cause to be made
all the required inspections, or may accept reports of inspections by
authorized services or individuals; and all reports of such inspection shall be
in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such authoritative service
or by the responsible individual; or may engage such expert opinion as the
building commissioner may deem necessary to report upon unusual technical
issues that may arise. (1990 Code §16.207)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  11-3-1B of this code.
10-1-2: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   The provisions of this title and other applicable provisions of this
code shall cover all matters affecting or relating to buildings and structures.
The provisions of this title shall apply whether or not the property, as
defined in the condominium property act, 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 605/
1 et seq., is subject to the act. (1990 Code §16.201; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   A building or structure shall not be constructed, extended, repaired,
removed or altered in violation of this title, except for ordinary repairs as
defined in section
10-1-3 of this chapter.
   C.   Any requirement essential for structural, fire or sanitary safety of an
existing or proposed building or structure, or essential for the safety of the
occupants thereof and which is not specifically covered by this title, shall be
determined by the building commissioner. The building commissioner shall have
the discretion, unless otherwise directed by the board of trustees or
prohibited by law, to waive or modify any requirement or provision of this
title if, in his opinion, the circumstances so warrant and the waiver or
modification would serve the best interests of all parties concerned.
   D.   The continuation of work thereon, occupancy or use of a building or
structure, or a part thereof, contrary to the provisions of this title shall be
deemed a violation subject to the penalties prescribed in section
10-1-9 of this chapter. (1990 Code §16.201)
10-1-3: ORDINARY REPAIRS:
Ordinary repairs to structures not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) in
any one calendar year may be made without application or notice to the building
commissioner, but such repairs shall not include the cutting away of any wall,
partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or
bearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress or
rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the exitway requirements; nor
shall ordinary repairs include addition to, alteration of, replacement or
relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas,
soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or mechanical or other
work affecting public health or general safety. (1990 Code §16.202)
10-1-4: SERVICE EQUIPMENT:
When the installation, extension, alteration or repair of an elevator, moving
stairway, mechanical equipment, refrigeration, air conditioning or ventilating
apparatus, plumbing, gas piping, electric wiring, heating system or any other
equipment is specifically controlled by the provisions of this title or the
approved rules, it is unlawful to use such equipment until a certificate of
approval has been issued therefor by the building commissioner. (1990 Code
§16.203)
10-1-5: MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Required:
      1.   All buildings and structures, and all parts thereof, both existing
and new, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition.
      2.   All service equipment, means of egress, devices and safeguards which
are required by this title in a building or structure, or which were required
by a previous ordinance in a building or structure when erected, altered or
repaired, shall be maintained in good working order.
   B.   Responsibility Of Owner: The owner and his designated agent shall be
responsible for the safe and sanitary maintenance of the building or structure
and its exitway facilities at all times.
   C.   Maintenance And Use: It is unlawful to maintain, occupy or use a
building or structure, or part thereof, that has been erected, altered or added
to in violation of the provisions of this title, and no building or structure
shall be occupied unless it is in a safe, inhabitable condition as prescribed
in this title. (1990 Code §16.204)
10-1-6: EXISTING USES AND STRUCTURES:
   A.   Existing Uses:
      1.   Continuation: The legal use and occupancy of any structure existing
on June 19, 1990, or for which it had been heretofore approved, may be
continued without change, except as may be specifically covered in this title
or in this code or as may be deemed necessary by the building commissioner for
the general safety and welfare of the occupants and the public.
      2.   Change In Use: It is unlawful to make any change in the use or
occupancy of any structure which would subject said structure to any provision
of this title without approval of the building commissioner and his
certification that such structure meets the intent of the provisions of law
governing building construction for the proposed new use and occupancy, and
that such change does not result in any greater hazard to public safety or
welfare. (1990 Code §16.205)
   B.   Existing Structures: Existing structures, when altered or required as
specified in this subsection, shall be made to conform to the full requirements
of this title for new structures. (1990 Code §16.206)
10-1-7: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Preliminary Inspection: Before issuing a permit, the building
commissioner may examine or cause to be examined all buildings, structures, and
sites for which an application has been filed for a permit to construct,
enlarge, alter, repair, remove, demolish, or change the use thereof.
   B.   Required Inspection: After issuing a building permit, the building
commissioner shall conduct such inspections from time to time during and upon
completion of the work for which he has issued a permit, and he shall maintain
a record of all such examinations and inspections and of all violations of this
title.
   C.   Accredited Inspection Services: The building commissioner may engage
the services of the county building development or health department or such
other professional or accredited inspection agencies to perform inspections
hereunder. The building commissioner may accept reports of approved inspection
services which satisfy his requirements as to qualifications and reliability.
   D.   Reports: All inspection reports shall be in writing and shall be
certified by the licensed authority or responsible officer of the service, or
the individual when expert inspection services are accepted. (1990 Code
§16.208)
   E.   Request For Inspection: At least twenty four (24) hours' notice shall
be given to the building commissioner for required inspection by an applicant 1
. (1990 Code §16.208; amd. 2011 Code)
   F.   Final Inspection: Upon completion of the building or structure, and
before issuance of a certificate of use and occupancy, a final inspection shall
be made. All violations of the approved plans, permits and applicable code
shall be noted, and the holder of the permit shall be notified of the
discrepancies. No certificate of use and occupancy shall be issued until all
discrepancies have been resolved to the satisfaction of the building
commissioner. (1990 Code §16.208)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-2-2-1 (§ 113.3) of this title.
10-1-8: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
With the consent of the owner or occupant, or his or her representative, or a
court order in the discharge of his duties, the building commissioner or his
authorized representative shall have the authority to enter, at any reasonable
hour, any building, structure or premises in the village to enforce the
provisions of this title. (1990 Code §16.209)
10-1-9: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Unlawful Acts: It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, demolish, use or occupy any
building or structure or equipment regulated by this title, or cause same to be
done, contrary to or in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions
of this title.
   B.   Notice Of Violation: The building commissioner shall serve a notice of
violation or order on the person responsible for the erection, construction,
alteration, extension, repair, removal, demolition, use or occupancy of a
building or structure in violation of the provisions of this title or in
violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this title,
and such order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or
condition and the abatement of the violation. (1990 Code §16.214)
   C.   Prosecution Of Violation: If the notice of violation is not rectified
within the specified time as determined by the building commissioner, the
building commissioner shall require the village attorney to institute
proceeding at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation or
to require the removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or
structure in violation of the provisions of this title or of the order or
direction made pursuant thereto.
   D.   Penalties: Any person who violates a provision of this title or fails
to comply with any of the requirements hereof or who erects, constructs, alters
or repairs a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or
directive of the building commissioner, or of a permit or certificate issued
under the provisions of this title, a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code shall be imposed. Each day that a violation continues shall
be deemed a separate offense.
   E.   Abatement Of Violation: The imposition of the penalties prescribed in
this section shall not preclude the village attorney from instituting
appropriate action to prevent unlawful construction; or to restrain, correct or
abate a violation; or to prevent illegal occupancy of a building, structure or
premises; or to stop an illegal act, conduct, business or use of a building or
structure in or about any premises. (1990 Code §16.214; amd. 2011 Code)
   F.   Stop Work Order: Upon notice from the building commissioner that work
on any building or structure is being prosecuted contrary to the provisions of
this title, or in an unsafe and dangerous manner, such work shall be
immediately stopped. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given
to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the
person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which the work may
be resumed. (1990 Code §16.215)
