1 1. See also section
  5-1-2 of this code.
10-6-1: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:
10-6-1-1: DEFINITION:
The term "dangerous building", as used in this section
10-6-1, is defined to mean and include:
   A.   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which is dangerous
to the public health because of its construction or condition, or which may
cause or aid in the spread of disease or cause injury to the health of the
occupants thereof or of neighboring structures.
   B.   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of
faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard.
   C.   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, by reason
of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any
part of said structure.
   D.   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of
its condition or because of lack of doors or windows, is available to and
frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of
such structure. (1990 Code §13.133)
10-6-1-2: NUISANCE DECLARED; DANGEROUS BUILDINGS PROHIBITED:
Any dangerous building in the village is declared to be a nuisance. It is
unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the
village, and it is unlawful for the owner, occupant, or person in custody of
any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition,
or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains
in a dangerous condition. (1990 Code §§13.133, 13.134)
10-6-1-3: ABATEMENT PROCEDURE:
   A.   Written Statement By Village: Whenever the village engineer, village
president or local fire chief or any county or local building inspector or
other agent authorized by the village finds that any building or structure in
the village is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to this
effect with the village clerk. (1990 Code §13.135)
   B.   Notice Requirements: The village clerk or village building commissioner
shall thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and
upon the occupants thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service.
Such notice shall state that the building has been declared to be in dangerous
condition and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by
repairing or altering the building or demolishing it, and that the condition
must be remedied at once. (1990 Code §13.135; amd. 2011 Code)
   C.   Abatement By Village: If the person receiving such notice has not
complied therewith within thirty (30) days from the time when said notice is
served upon such person by personal service or by registered mail, the village
may, upon orders of the village president, proceed to remedy the condition or
demolish the dangerous building. (1990 Code §13.135)
10-6-1-4: REMOVAL AND REBUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Removal Or Rebuilding Required: Any building or structure within the
village which has or may be damaged by fire, decay or other cause to the extent
of at least fifty percent (50%) of its fair market value, shall be torn down
and removed, or rebuilt in accordance with all existing applicable building and
fire codes.
   B.   Written Statement By Village: Whenever the village engineer, village
president, local fire chief or any county or local building inspector,
sanitarian or other agent authorized by the village finds that any building or
structure has been so damaged, destroyed or decayed requiring its removal, he
shall file a written statement to this effect with the village clerk.
   C.   Notice Requirements: The village clerk or village president shall,
thereupon, cause a written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and upon
the occupants thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such
notice shall state that the building has been declared to have been damaged or
decayed to the extent of at least fifty percent (50%) of its fair market value
and that such building or structure must be removed or rebuilt and that the
condition be remedied at once.
   D.   Remedy Of Conditions By Village: If the person receiving such notice
has not complied therewith within thirty (30) days from the time when said
notice is served upon such person by personal service or by registered mail,
the village may, upon orders of the village building commissioner, proceed to
remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. (1990 Code §13.136;
amd. 2011 Code)
10-6-1-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this section
10-6-1 shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1990
Code §13.137; amd. 2011 Code)
10-6-2: UNSAFE STRUCTURES:
10-6-2-1: RIGHT OF CONDEMNATION:
All buildings or structures that are or hereafter become unsafe, unsanitary or
deficient in regard to adequate exitway facilities, or which constitute a fire
hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life or to the public welfare, or
which, by reason of illegal or improper use, occupancy or maintenance, shall be
deemed unsafe buildings or structures. All unsafe structures shall be taken
down and removed or made safe and secure, as the building commissioner may deem
necessary and as provided in this section
10-6-2. A vacant building, unguarded or open at door or window, shall be deemed
a fire hazard and unsafe within the meaning of this section
10-6-2. (1990 Code §16.216; amd. 2011 Code)
10-6-2-2: EXAMINATION AND RECORD OF UNSAFE STRUCTURE:
The building commissioner shall examine every building or structure reported as
dangerous, unsafe structurally or constituting a fire hazard, and he shall
cause the report to be filed in a docket of unsafe structures and premises,
stating the use of the structure, the nature and estimated amount of damages,
if any, caused by collapse or failure. (1990 Code §16.216; amd. 2011 Code)
10-6-2-3: NOTICE TO ABATE:
   A.   If an unsafe condition is found in a building or structure, the
building commissioner shall serve on the owner, agent, or person in control of
the building or structure a written notice describing the building or structure
deemed unsafe and specifying the required repairs or improvements to be made to
render the building or structure safe and secure, or requiring the unsafe
building or structure or portion thereof to be demolished within a stipulated
time. Such notice shall require the person thus notified to immediately declare
to the building commissioner his acceptance or rejection of the terms of the
order. (1990 Code §16.216; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   If the person addressed with an unsafe notice cannot be found within
the village after diligent search, then such notice shall be sent by registered
or certified mail to the last known address of such person, and a copy of the
unsafe notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises, and such
procedure shall be deemed the equivalent of personal notice. (1990 Code
§16.216)
10-6-2-4: FAILURE TO ABATE:
Upon refusal or neglect of the person served with an unsafe notice to comply
with the requirements of the order to abate the unsafe conditions, the village
attorney of the jurisdiction shall be advised of all the facts, and he shall
institute the appropriate action to compel compliance. (1990 Code §16.216; amd.
2011 Code)
10-6-2-5: RESTORATION OF UNSAFE STRUCTURE:
A building or structure condemned by the building commissioner may be restored
to a safe condition, provided change of use or occupancy is not contemplated or
compelled by reason of such reconstruction; or if restoration is in excess of
fifty percent (50%) of its replacement value, exclusive of foundation, such
structure shall be made to comply in all respects with the requirements for
materials and methods of construction of structures hereafter erected. (1990
Code §16.216; amd. 2011 Code)
CHAPTER 7
NUMBERING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
10-7-1: Numbering Plan; Compliance Required
10-7-2: Street Numbering Chart
10-7-3: Duty To Post Numbers; Specifications
10-7-1: NUMBERING PLAN; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
All lots, buildings and structures in the village shall be numbered in
accordance with a plan as approved by the village board of trustees. (1990 Code
§15.301)
10-7-2: STREET NUMBERING CHART:
The village clerk shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of every
lot in the village, which chart shall be open for inspection by anyone
interested therein. (1990 Code §15.302)
10-7-3: DUTY TO POST NUMBERS; SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Duties Of Owners And Occupants:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the owner and occupant of every single-
family and multiple-family dwelling structure in the village to cause every
principal building or structure to have posted thereon figures showing the
number of that building or structure.
      2.   It shall further be the duty of the owner and respective occupants
of all structures or portions thereof in the village for which an address has
been assigned, other than one-family and two-family dwelling structures, to
have posted thereon, within ten feet (10') of all exterior doors, figures
showing the number assigned to that structure or portion thereof.
   B.   Specifications:
      1.   Said figures shall be in Arabic numbers which shall be a minimum of
three inches (3") in height and of proportionate width, of contrasting color to
the mounting surface, and be affixed in such a place to be easily and
distinctly read and in plain view from the street.
      2.   All such numbers shall be placed within ten feet (10') of the front
door and shall be visible from the street abutting the front yard. In the event
the front door is not on the side of the building or structure facing the
street, the requirement of being within ten feet (10') of the front door shall
not apply.
   C.   Temporary Numbers: During construction, buildings shall have temporary
numbers affixed to or painted on the structure.
   D.   Application Of Provisions: This section shall not apply to existing
buildings and structures already numbered in a place visible from the street,
but shall apply if such numbers are replaced.
   E.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation failing to so number any
principal building or structure owned or occupied thereby, after receiving
notice to do so from the village clerk, shall be fined one dollar ($1.00) for
each day on which the failure to so number continues, and each day shall be
considered a separate violation. (1990 Code §15.303)
CHAPTER 8
DEVELOPMENT IN WETLANDS AND NEAR WATER BODIES 1
SECTION:
10-8-1: Setback Requirements
10-8-2: Limitations On Development
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  12-4D-5 of this code.
10-8-1: SETBACK REQUIREMENTS:
Minimum setback requirements between development and the edge of identified
wetlands and bodies of water shall be in compliance with the setback
contemplated by an approved final plat or plan for a given development. Where
applicable, setbacks shall also comply with the requirements of any superior
governmental mandate, such as Kane County ordinance requirements. In the
absence of an approved plan or applicable superior governmental mandate,
minimum setbacks from identified wetlands and bodies of water shall be fifty
feet (50'), provided that the provisions of section
10-8-2 of this chapter shall permit limited development within the setback
area, and further provided that the village board may waive compliance with
this setback standard by approval of a nonconforming plan, without requirement
of any zoning variation. (Ord. 2016-O-30, 12-5-2016)
10-8-2: LIMITATIONS ON DEVELOPMENT:
Development in the setback zone established in section
10-8-1 of this chapter shall be limited to the following activities: minor
improvements like walkways and signs, maintenance of highways and utilities,
and park and recreational area development. (Ord. 2008-02, 2-19-2008)

10-9-1: FEMA MAPS AND COUNTY REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
   A.   The village acknowledges its sole responsibility for its standing in
the national flood insurance program (NFIP) including the notification of the
director, FEMA, IDNR-OWR, COE, NRCS, the soil and water conservation district,
the United States fish and wildlife service, the Illinois environmental
protection agency, and the United States environmental protection agency of any
changes or deviations which the village makes from the Kane County stormwater
ordinance (KCSO), and further resolves to adopt, pursuant to section 404(a) of
the KCSO, the most current version of any maps adopted and published by FEMA
for regulation under the NFIP. The village further resolves to automatically
adopt any amendments, additions, revisions or substitutions thereto or therefor
on an ongoing basis until such point in time as the corporate authorities of
the village shall rescind this policy of automatic adoption of updates.
   B.   As indicated in subsection A of this section, the village resolves and
declares its intent to automatically adopt by reference all amendments to the
KCSO as may be adopted by the county at any time in the future, and
specifically to automatically adopt by reference the most current version of
the FIRM and other maps adopted and published by FEMA for regulation under the
NFIP. (Res. 19-2008, 10-6-2008)
   C.   At the time of most recent amendment, the village adopts the flood
insurance rate map with an effective date of June 2, 2015. Further, the village
prospectively adopts any future revisions thereto. (Ord. 2015-O-02, 2-2-2015)

10-9-3: AMENDMENTS:
Article 7: The following is substituted for article 7 of the county ordinance:
Article 7. Enforcement And Penalties
9-151. Inspection And Maintenance Authority. The village may, upon 30 days'
notice to the owner or occupant, enter upon any lands or waters within the
village for the purpose of inspecting and/or maintaining any storm water
facilities or causing the removal of any obstruction of an affected
watercourse.
9-152. Required Inspections. Any development constructed pursuant to a storm
water management permit may be periodically inspected by the administrator to
ensure its conformity with this ordinance and the terms and conditions of its
permit.
9-153. Offenses.
   (a)   Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, refuses to comply
with or resists the enforcement of any provision of this ordinance (ordinance
violation), or any requirement or condition in any permit issued pursuant to
this ordinance (permit violation), and, in the case of a permit violation,
fails to correct such violation, omission or neglect, or cease such
disobedience, refusal or resistance after notice and reinspection as provided
below, shall be guilty of an offense under this ordinance.
   (b)   Whenever the administrator determines that a permit violation exists,
he shall serve notice of the violation in the manner prescribed in this
ordinance to the permittee. Such notice shall state the nature and violation
and fix a date not less than 10 days after the date of the notice when the site
will be reinspected.
9-154. Offenses - Penalties; Remedies.
   (a)   Any person found guilty of an offense under this ordinance shall pay a
civil fine in an amount not less than $25.00 and not more than $750.00. Each
calendar day during which such violation continues to exist shall constitute a
separate offense.
   (b)   In addition to any fine imposed under this section, the administrator
may revoke any storm water management permit issued to such person.
   (c)   In addition to any fine imposed or permit revocation undertaken
pursuant to this section, the administrator may issue an order requiring the
suspension of any further work on the site. Such stop-work order shall be in
writing, shall indicate the reason for its issuance, and shall specify the
action, if any, required to be taken in order to resume work. One copy of the
stop-work order shall be posted on the site in a conspicuous place and one copy
shall be served in the same manner above prescribed upon the permittee, if any,
or if none, upon the person in whose name the site was last assessed for taxes
as disclosed by the records of the county supervisor of assessments.
   (d)   In the enforcement of this ordinance, the administrator may bring any
action, legal or equitable, including an action for injunctive relief, as he
may deem necessary.
(Ord. 2001-04, 5-21-2001, eff. 12-15-2001)

acres.
      7.   $1,000.00 plus $5.00 per acre for review of tracts greater than five
acres.
   B.   Fee-In-Lieu Of Site Runoff Storage.
      (a)   The administrator may require, or in the limited circumstances
prescribed in article 2 of the Pingree Grove storm water management ordinance,
an applicant may request approval of, the payment of a fee-in- lieu of site
runoff storage to fulfill all or part of the site runoff storage requirement
for a development. The fee to be paid in lieu of site runoff storage shall be
the lesser of:
         (1)   The fee for each acre-foot or part thereof of storage otherwise
required computed under a schedule adopted for such purpose by the permitting
authority; or
         (2)   The verifiable cost of otherwise providing the required storage,
including the value of the land required and all construction costs. For this
purpose, the land required shall be valued according to the use to which it
will ultimately be put if not used to provide the required storage.
      (b)   An applicant's requirement for approval of the payment of a fee-in-
lieu of site runoff storage shall be submitted to the administrator. The
administrator shall grant or deny the request within 45 days, unless the
applicant agrees to an extension.
(Ord. 2001-04, 5-21-2001, eff. 12-15-2001)
      (c)   Fees paid pursuant to this article shall be deposited by the clerk
or finance director in a separate fund created for such purpose. Provisions
shall be made so that all receipts and disbursements of such funds may be
accounted for according to the individual watershed in which the development
for which they were paid was located.
(Ord. 2001-04, 5-21-2001, eff. 12-15-2001; amd. 2011 Code)
      (d)   Fees paid pursuant to this article may be expended to plan, design,
construct or improve storm water management systems within the watershed in
which the development for which they were paid was located if such expenditure
is consistent with a watershed or interim watershed plan or floodplain study.
(Ord. 2001-04, 5-21-2001, eff. 12-15-2001)

Article 17. Administration And Oversight
   1.   The village president shall be the administrator of this ordinance.

10-9-4: POLICY AND PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the health, safety, and general
welfare of the citizens of the Village through the regulation of non-stormwater
discharges to the storm drainage system to the maximum extent practicable as
required by federal and state law. This article establishes methods for
controlling the introduction of pollutants into the municipal separate storm
sewer system (MS4) in order to comply with requirements of the National
Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit process.
The objectives of these sections are:
   A.   To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the municipal separate
storm sewer system (MS4) by stormwater discharges by any user;
   B.   To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the municipal
separate storm sewer system;
   C.   To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance,
and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this article.
(Ord. 2020-O-23, 6-15-2020)
