      3.   Reinforced concrete pipe (RCP) shall conform to ASTM C76, minimum
class III.
      4.   Culvert slope and invert elevations shall match the ditch slope and
invert elevations.
      5.   Minimum cover at driveways shall be six inches (6").
   C.   Swales/Ditches: Ditches and culverts may be used in lieu of storm
sewers if curbs and gutters are not required. Ditches shall meet the following
minimum standards.
      1.   Minimum grade of one and one-half percent (1.5%).
      2.   Maximum grade of ten percent (10%).
      3.   Minimum depth of twenty four inches (24") below the shoulder of the
street.
      4.   Maximum bank slope of four to one (4:1) under normal conditions.
      5.   The bottom and banks of ditches with grades between four percent
(4%) and eight percent (8%) shall be sodded and equipped with permanent ditch
checks.
      6.   The bottom and banks of ditches with grades between eight percent
(8%) and ten percent (10%) shall be paved or otherwise stabilized as approved
by the village engineer.
      7.   Whenever practicable, all areas of the property must be provided an
overland flow path that will pass the one hundred (100) year flow at a stage at
least one foot (1') below a building's lowest opening in the vicinity of the
flow path. Overland flow paths designed for flows in excess of the minor
drainage system capacity shall be provided in drainage easements. Street
ponding and flow depths shall not exceed curb heights. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-
2004)
12-4D-5: WETLANDS AND FLOODPLAIN AREAS:
   A.   Detention In Wetlands:
      1.   Existing "wetlands", as defined in section
12-1-3 of this title, shall not be modified for the purposes of stormwater
detention. The village board may waive this restriction if it can be
demonstrated that the wetland is highly degraded and would benefit from
detention related improvements.
      2.   Existing depressional storage in wetlands shall be maintained or
compensated on a one to one (1:1) basis. The volume of detention storage
required to meet the requirements of this section shall be in addition to any
existing depressional storage.
      3.   Prior to discharge, all stormwater runoff shall be routed through a
detention/sedimentation basin designed to capture the two (2) year, twenty four
(24) hour event and hold it for an average of twenty four (24) hours before
release.
      4.   The provisions of article B of this chapter shall apply to all work
in or adjacent to existing "wetlands" as defined in section
12-1-3 of this title.
   B.   Construction In Wetlands 1 :
      1.   If jurisdictional wetlands are part of a stormwater management
system that proposes topographic change activities involving excavation and/or
deposition within the wetlands, a permit will be required from the U.S. army
corps of engineers (COE).
      2.   As a condition of village approval of any stormwater management
system, including all detention areas, swales, sewers, berms, etc., which
involve jurisdictional wetlands and prior to submission of the final plat of
the subdivision to the planning and zoning commission, a permit shall be
obtained from the COE, or if a permit is not required, a sign off letter from
the COE must be provided.
   C.   Construction In Floodplain: If construction activities are necessary in
the regulatory floodplain, all requirements of the county stormwater ordinance
shall be met 1 .
   D.   Endangered Species:
      1.   In conformance with the endangered species protection act, effective
December 3, 1990, the village is required to consult with the Illinois
department of natural resources, office of conservation (IDNR/OC), prior to
preliminary platting of certain land developments.
      2.   As a condition of village approval of such plats, a determination
must be obtained from IDNR/OC, either stating that no further consultation is
required or stating recommendations for minimizing or avoiding impacts on
endangered species.
      3.   Although the application for an IDNR/OC determination will be filed
by the village, the subdivider will be required to prepare the application and
to provide any subsequent documentation which may be requested to conform with
the intent of the act. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 10, chapter 8 of this code.
1 1. See title 10, chapter 9 of this code.
ARTICLE E. WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM
SECTION:
12-4E-1: Introduction
12-4E-2: General Design Considerations
12-4E-3: Capacity Of Mains
12-4E-4: Fire Hydrants
12-4E-5: Valves
12-4E-6: General Design Details For Mains (6 To 24 Inch Diameter)
12-4E-7: Connections To Existing Mains
12-4E-8: Service Lines
12-4E-9: Protection Requirements
12-4E-10: Testing And Disinfection
12-4E-11: Workmanship
12-4E-1: INTRODUCTION:
   A.   All developments within the corporate limits and any development under
village jurisdiction which is greater than five (5) acres in size or consists
of ten (10) lots or more shall include provisions for a complete water supply
system and the construction of water distribution facilities, complete with
valves, fire hydrants and other appurtenances designed in accordance with this
article. As a minimum, the distribution system shall include a system of water
mains and service lines between a connection or connections to the existing
distribution system at approved locations, as well as continuation of
distribution mains to the extremities of a development to facilitate future
extensions of the village water main system to adjacent areas.
   B.   The design of all water distribution system facilities proposed for
construction as independent projects under the village jurisdiction shall also
meet the technical requirements of this article.
   C.   No private water wells shall be allowed on property within the village
corporate limits if a public water main exists within two hundred fifty feet
(250') of the nearest point of the property in question.
   D.   The requirements of articles A and B of this chapter are also
applicable to water distribution system construction. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-2: GENERAL DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS:
   A.   Extensions to the distribution system shall include feeder mains and
distribution mains.
   B.   All water mains shall be located in the parkway, opposite that of the
sanitary sewer, approximately ten feet (10') from the property line.
   C.   There shall be required to be constructed dual water mains hairpin
within a cul-de-sac to conform with the village requirement to provide a looped
water main system except in the event a lot at the end of the cul-de-sac, a
minimum of forty feet (40') in width, is dedicated to the village for water
main looping purposes. When a hairpin water main is constructed, the following
center to center spacing between mains will be required:
      1.   Four feet (4') c-c for main eight inches (8") in diameter and
smaller.
      2.   Five feet (5') c-c for main ten inches (10") in diameter and larger.
   D.   Fire service mains shall be no less than six inches (6") in diameter or
the diameter of the smallest riser, whichever is greater. Fire service mains
also shall be "looped", having two (2) points of connection to the water
distribution main when either a building exceeds fifty two thousand (52,000)
square feet in area, or when a single feed fire service main will exceed three
hundred feet (300') in length. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-3: CAPACITY OF MAINS:
Feeders and distribution mains shall be sized to provide sufficient capacity to
deliver the required fire flow to all areas served by the proposed construction
with consumption at the maximum daily rate.
   A.   Required Fire Flow:
Type Of Development Fire Flow (gpm)
Type Of Development            Fire Flow (gpm)
Single-family residential      1,000
Multiple-family residential    2,500
Commercial/business (general)  2,400
Office/research                2,500
General manufacturing          3,000
Commercial/business (downtown) 3,500
Institutional                  3,500
High risk manufacturing        3,500
 
These rates are based on the latest "Fire Suppression Rating Schedule" of the
ISO (insurance service office) and must be available while maintaining a twenty
(20) psi residual pressure.
   B.   Maximum Day Consumption:
      1.   For purposes of water main design, maximum day consumption in
residential areas shall be based on a minimum of two hundred (200) gallons per
capita per day, with population estimated in accordance with subsection
12-4C-3B of this chapter.
      2.   In other than residential areas, maximum day consumption shall be
based on the following:
Establishment Unit Gallons/Day/Unit
Establishment   Unit               Gallons/Day/Unit
Shopping center Employee (1 shift) 105
Store           Employee (1 shift) 65
Office          Employee (1 shift) 50
Industrial      Employee (1 shift) 75
Restaurant      Meal served        15
Theater         Per seat           10
Hotel           Per guest          210
 
      3.   To the above shall be added all process water requirements.
      4.   For other than residential developments, when the details of the
development are not known, the design engineer, subject to the approval of the
village engineer, shall estimate maximum day consumption and fire flow. Such
approval shall not relieve the subdivider of the responsibility of providing
adequate main capacity for any and all future developments within the
development. In such cases, minimum main size shall be twelve inches (12").
   C.   Storage: Sufficient storage shall be designed and constructed to
provide sufficient water to the distribution system (1,000 gallons per minute
residential or 2,500 gallons per minute industrial/commercial) for a six (6)
hour period. Water supply facilities with excess capacity may be used to offset
up to fifty percent (50%) of the required storage volume. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-
2004)
12-4E-4: FIRE HYDRANTS:
   A.   Spacing: Each subdivision, at the subdivider's cost, shall be served by
fire hydrants which shall be installed by the subdivider at the subdivider's
cost along all water mains with such fire hydrants being constructed at a
maximum spacing of four hundred feet (400'). However, notwithstanding such
spacing requirement, under no circumstance shall the most remote part of the
buildable portion of any lot in the subdivision be more than three hundred feet
(300') from any fire hydrant with the most remote part of any lot within the
subdivision no farther than three hundred feet (300') from a hydrant. Such
hydrants shall be constructed within public rights of way if the subdivision
contains public rights of way.
      1.   Fire hydrants are required to be located a minimum of three feet
(3') clear distance from the closest point to any paved vehicular traffic
surface and a minimum of two feet (2') from any paved pedestrian traffic
surface.
      2.   Fire hydrants shall be no closer than eight feet (8') from any
streetlight installations.
   B.   Distance: The maximum distance from a hydrant to a fire department
connection shall not exceed one hundred fifty feet (150').
      If there is any conflict between the spacing requirements set forth in
this section 12-4E-4, the most restrictive shall control.
   C.   Materials And Installation: Fire hydrants shall meet AWWA C-502
standards and shall satisfy the criteria of waterous pacer model WB 67-2 50 or
equal, as determined by the Village's public works director, with a five and
one- fourth inch (5¼") valve opening, two (2) 2½-inch hose nozzles and one
pumper nozzle. Threads shall conform with the National Hose Thread
specifications. Construction shall conform to that indicated on the fire
hydrant standard detail submitted by the subdivider and which shall be approved
by the Village. Each hydrant shall be equipped with an auxiliary gate vale
complete with roadway box, fitted with adapter II or equal, Tyler 6645 valve
box and valve box adaptor II or equal. Hydrants shall be installed no closer
than three feet (3') to the face of the hydrant steamer port (pumper nozzle),
nor further than eight feet (8') from the back curb. No hydrant shall be
installed within forty eight inches (48") of any obstruction, nor shall any
obstruction be placed within forty eight inches (48") of a hydrant.
   D.   Hydrant Flags: The subdivider, at the subdivider's cost, will be
responsile for installing one hydrant flag for each hydrant installed in such
subdivision. Each flag will be spring type, four feet by three-eighths inch
(4'x3/8") and applicable to a 2.5 inch hydrant port.
   E.   Painting: All hydrants shall be color coded according to the National
Fire Protection Association (NFPA) publication 291, "Fire Flow Testing And
Marking Of Hydrants".
(Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004; amd. Ord. 2024-O-19, 9-16-2024)
12-4E-5: VALVES:
   A.   Spacing: For multi-family zoning construction, water main valves shall
be spaced at a minimum of six hundred feet (600'), or at a distance such that
in the event of a required shut down of the public main, no more than twenty
four (24) units shall be out of water service, whichever results in the
shortest valve spacing.
   B.   Vaults: All valves proposed to be placed under pavement shall be
installed in four foot (4') diameter precast concrete vaults conforming to ASTM
C-478 as detailed in the valve vault detail. Vaults shall be constructed with
an external chimney seal, such as Infi-Shield or equal. All other valves and
auxiliary valves at fire hydrants shall be installed in cast iron valve boxes
fitted with adaptor II or equal. Butterfly valves shall be installed in
specially designed vaults similar in general design to that shown in the valve
vault detail, but modified as necessary to provide for the proper operation of
the valve. Vaults and boxes shall not be allowed under driveways. Prior to
acceptance of the installation, the top two (2) steps shall be removed for the
valve vaults. Grating shall be required on precast concrete flared end sections
for pipe sizes with diameters of twelve inches (12") or greater.
   C.   Valve Box: All valves fitted with a valve box shall have a valve box
adapter II or equal.
   D.   Types:
      1.   All valves smaller than twelve inches (12") shall be AWWA C-509,
cast iron body, bronze fitted, modified wedge disc, resilient seat type with
nonrising stem and O-ring packing designed for two hundred (200) pound working
pressure, Mueller A2360-20.
      2.   All valves twelve inches (12") and larger shall be butterfly valves
Mueller B-3211-20 iron body rubber seat type conforming to AWWA C-504, latest
edition, class 150-B. All valves shall open counter clockwise with nonrising
stem (except hand valves). (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-6: GENERAL DESIGN DETAILS FOR MAINS (6 TO 24 INCH DIAMETER):
   A.   Ductile Iron Pipe, Fittings And Joint Type:
      1.   Provide ductile iron pipe complying with ANSI A21.51, thickness
special class 52, with joints complying with ANSI A21.11. External coating
shall be standard, as specified for general use in ASA specification A21.51.
      2.   Use internal cement lining complying with ANSI A21.4 or AWWA C-205,
standard thickness.
      3.   Whenever river crossing pipe is required, provide restrained joint,
or ball and socket type joints allowing fifteen degrees' (15°) maximum
deflection.
      4.   Use ductile iron fittings with mechanical joint complying with ANSI
A21.10 or A21.53. Use internal cement lining complying with ANSI A21.4,
standard thickness.
   B.   Polyethylene Encasement: All ductile iron pipe water main shall be
wrapped with polyethylene material conforming to AWWA C-105-77 or ANSI 21.5,
with a minimum thickness of eight (8) mils. This specification may be waived
based on a report by the Ductile Iron Pipe Research Association or other
approved testing laboratory which would declare the soil for the subject
installation noncorrosive.
   C.   PVC Plastic Pipe And Joints:
      1.   Provide polyvinyl chloride pipe complying with AWWA C-900 for class
150-pressure pipe with a standard dimension ratio of 18.
      2.   Pipe fourteen inch (14") through eighteen inch (18"), use pipe with
a pressure rating of two hundred thirty five (235) psi and a standard dimension
ratio of 18.
      3.   Pipe twenty inch (20") and twenty four inch (24"), use pipe with a
pressure rating of one hundred sixty five (165) psi and a standard dimension
ratio of 25.
      4.   All plastic water mains shall be installed with a minimum 10-gauge
solid copper tracer wire. The wire shall be continuous through valve vaults and
boxes and shall be accessible at the vault frame or box cover.
   D.   Depth Of Cover: The depth between the finished grade and the top of the
water main shall be not less than six feet (6') nor more than seven feet (7').
Where conflicts arise with other underground improvements, greater depths will
be allowed.
   E.   Thrust Blocks: Blocking to prevent movement of mains under pressure at
bends and fittings shall be portland cement concrete, a minimum of twelve
inches (12") thick, placed between solid ground and the fittings in such a
manner that pipe fittings and joints will be accessible for repairs. All bends
of twenty two and one-half degrees (221/2°) or greater, and all tees and plugs
shall be thrust protected to prevent movement of the line under pressure.
Thrust protection may also be attained by the use of a combination of retaining
glands and threaded rods.
   F.   Trench: Minimum trench width shall be ample for proper jointing, but in
no case less than one foot six inches (1'6"). Bedding and backfill shall be as
specified in section
12-4B-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-7: CONNECTIONS TO EXISTING MAINS:
   A.   All connections to the village water distribution system shall be made
under full water service pressure. The following specifications shall apply
when pressure connections are made to the existing village distribution system:
      1.   Tapping sleeves:
         a.   Use two (2) piece stainless steel bolted sleeve type with
mechanical joint, Mueller H615 or Smith Blair 665 stainless steel sleeve.
         b.   Provide joint accessories.
      2.   Tapping valves:
         a.   Use fully ported gate valves complying with AWWA C-500.
         b.   Use mechanical joints type, Mueller A2360-20.
   B.   Installation Provisions: Tapping valves shall be placed in precast
concrete vaults as specified in subsection
12-4E-5B of this article in accordance with the "pressure connection" detail.
(Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-8: SERVICE LINES:
   A.   Description: A water service line is designed to deliver water from a
public water distribution main, and extended from the main to a single
building, and includes corporation stop, curb stop and service box. Service
lines shall be approximately at right angles to the centerline of the right of
way whenever possible, and enter the site within five feet (5') of the side lot
line. Service lines shall be continuous with no splices between either the
corporation and the curb stop or the curb stop and the house meter.
   B.   The following meter installation provisions are required by this title:
      1.   Meters:
         a.   No more than three feet (3') of any type K copper service line
shall be visible before the meter connection.
         b.   Meters shall be no more than five feet (5') above the floor.
Meters located in crawl spaces shall have an access hatch no more than three
feet (3') from the meter location.
c. Conduit to the meter shall be continuous. If more than three hundred sixty
degrees (360°) in bends is anticipated, three-fourths inch (3/4") minimum
diameter conduit is required. Junction boxes are not acceptable.
         d.   Wire installation shall be by the contractor (not public works)
for meter connections where more than twenty five feet (25') of wire is
required. Wire type must be approved by the village engineer.
      2.   Service Lines: Type K soft temper seamless copper water tubing
complying with ASTM 3-88.
      3.   Service Saddles For Connecting To PVC Pipes:
         a.   Service lines connected to PVC water main shall be by means of a
number 317 Blair double strap, epoxy coated saddle or approved equal.
         b.   McDonald series no. 3805 or Mueller series no. H16000, or equal.
      4.   Corporation Stops: Mueller no. H15000 flared, or equal.
      5.   Curb Stops: Mueller no. H15204CMark II Oriseal flared or equal.
      6.   Service Boxes: Water service valves (B-box) shall be located as
close to the center of a lot as possible, but said location shall result in a
valve location no closer than two feet (2') from paved surface. B-box extension
rods shall be within two feet (2') of finished grade.
      7.   Service Taps: All service taps shall be either with a manufactured
tap coupling or double strap bronze saddle for one and one-half inches (11/2")
and larger diameter.
      8.   Water Service Lines: Water service lines shall not be connected to
fire service mains or other process lines.
      9.   Multi-Family Construction: For multi-family construction when
multiple water services are proposed, no more than three (3) individual lines
may branch from a single service tap on the public water main.
   C.   Minimum Diameter: No water service line shall be less than one inch
(1") internal diameter.
   D.   Commercial Meters: All commercial water meters must have bypass valves
which do not interfere with access to the water meter for purposes of removing
the meter for testing and/or repair. The bypass line shall also have a meter
and backflow preventer.
   E.   Residential Meters: The type and size of residential water meters shall
be as determined by the village engineer. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-9: PROTECTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Mains: All water main, storm sewer and sanitary sewer construction
shall meet the requirements of this subsection.
      1.   Horizontal Separation:
         a.   Whenever possible, a water main shall be laid at least ten feet
(10') horizontally from any existing or proposed sewer. A clear distance of ten
feet (10') (minimum) horizontally shall be maintained between water main and
any manhole, valve vault, catch basin or stormwater inlet structure. (See
following standard drawing.)
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4946fd43bb2f8dbc5218e5bd25ea5318a6e0fb88/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1955.gif]
         b.   Should local conditions prevail which would prevent a horizontal
separation of ten feet (10'), a water main may be laid closer to or in the same
trench as a storm or sanitary sewer, provided the main is laid on an
undisturbed earth shelf located to one side of the sewer and at such an
elevation that the bottom of the water main is at least eighteen inches (18")
above the top of the sewer.
         c.   If it is impossible to obtain proper horizontal and vertical
separation as stipulated in subsection A1a or A1b of this section, both the
water main and sewer shall be constructed of slip on or mechanical joint
ductile iron pipe, and be pressure tested to assure watertightness before
backfilling.
      2.   Vertical Separation:
         a.   Whenever water mains must cross house sewers, storm drains, or
sanitary sewers, the water main shall be laid at such an elevation that the
bottom of the water main is eighteen inches (18") above the top of the drain or
sewer. This vertical separation shall be maintained for that portion of the
water main located within ten feet (10') horizontally of any sewer or drain
crossed, said ten feet (10') to be measured as the normal distance from the
water main to the drain or sewer.
         b.   Where conditions exist that the minimum vertical separation set
forth in subsection A2a of this section cannot be maintained, or it is
necessary for the water main to pass under a sanitary sewer, then, within a
distance of ten feet (10') either side of the water main, the sewer or drain
shall be constructed of pressure pipe conforming to the specification for water
main materials. For storm sewer, ASTM C-361 pipe shall satisfy this
requirement. The sewer or drain line shall be supported to prevent settling and
breaking of the water main.
   B.   Service Lines: The horizontal and vertical separation between water
service lines and all sanitary sewers, storm sewers, or any drain shall be the
same as for water mains, as detailed in subsection A of this section. (Ord.
2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-10: TESTING AND DISINFECTION:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   The following procedures are to be strictly followed by all persons
engaged in the pressure testing and/or disinfection of public water
distribution mains and private water services three inches (3") and larger in
diameter. The requirements of these design standards and the requirements of
the Illinois environmental protection agency water permit shall be strictly
enforced.
      2.   The contractor is required to provide any and all equipment
necessary to complete the pressure testing and/or disinfection of the water
mains and services. Prior to any test, the contractor shall arrange with the
village public works department to have the required tests witnessed, and shall
give a minimum of forty eight (48) hours' advance notice.
      3.   The contractor shall not operate any valves in the existing public
water supply system. Requests for valve operations are to be made through the
public works department. Requests for valve operations shall be made twenty
four (24) hours prior to any scheduled operations or tests.
   B.   Pressure And Leakage Tests: The contractor shall pressure test all new
water mains. The contractor shall perform a preliminary test to ensure that all
segments of the system meet the leakage rates as set forth herein. When the
contractor has assured himself that the system will meet the required leakage
rates, he will arrange for witnessing of the pressure test by the village
engineer. Forty eight (48) hours' advance notice shall be given. The tests
shall be conducted as follows:
      1.   Hydrostatic Tests:
         a.   Where any section of a water line is provided with concrete
thrust blocking for fittings, the hydrostatic tests shall not be made until at
least five (5) days after installation of the concrete thrust blocking.
         b.   Disposal of wastewater from hydrostatic tests and for
disinfection shall be approved in advance by the village. Full bore flushing
shall be witnessed by the Pingree Grove fire protection district (PGFPD).
         c.   The new water mains and service lines, including valves and
hydrants, shall be subjected to a hydrostatic pressure of one hundred twenty
five (125) psi.
         d.   The test pressure shall be held for a duration of one hour
without pressure loss or further pressure application.
         e.   Each valve shall be opened and closed several times during the
test.
         f.   Careful examination of exposed pipe, joints, fittings, and valves
is required.
         g.   Joints showing visible leakage shall be remade or replaced.
         h.   Cracked pipe, defective pipe, and cracked or defective joints,
fittings, and valves shall be replaced with sound material and the test
repeated until results are satisfactory.
      2.   Leakage Test:
         a.   A metered leakage test shall be conducted after the pressure test
has been satisfactorily completed.
         b.   Duration of each leakage test shall be at least twenty four (24)
hours.
         c.   During the test, water lines shall be subjected to the normal
water pressure of the village water system.
         d.   Maximum allowable leakage shall be four (4) gallons per inch of
pipe diameter per one thousand feet (1,000') of pipe per twenty four (24) hours
as recorded by a meter approved and witnessed by the village and PGFPD.
         e.   Should any test of pipe disclose leakage greater than the maximum
allowable amount, the defective joint or joints shall be located and repaired
and the twenty four (24) hour metered leakage test repeated until the leakage
is within the specified allowance.
      3.   Service Mains: Service mains shall be considered private once they
cross over a property line, even if the main is in an easement.
   C.   Disinfection:
      1.   After all mains have been pressure tested and accepted by the
village, the contractor shall proceed to disinfect the main in accordance with
AWWA standard C-651. A chlorine concentration during disinfection shall be
maintained at a minimum fifty milligrams per liter (50 mg/l) available
chlorine. The chlorinated water shall be retained in the main for a period of
at least twenty four (24) hours. At the end of the twenty four (24) hour
period, the treated water shall contain no less than twenty five milligrams per
liter (25mg/l) chlorine throughout the main. The contractor will sample the
chlorinated disinfecting solution to assure that these minimums are maintained.
      2.   After an applicable retention period, the heavily chlorinated water
shall be flushed from the main until the chlorine concentration in the water
leaving the main is not higher than that generally prevailing in the system.
After final flushing, and as witnessed by the village public works department,
two (2) samples of water shall be obtained from the main for bacteriological
testing. The village water department shall be responsible for obtaining and
delivery of the samples for testing purposes. For major water main
installation, the number of samples may be increased as determined by the
village public works department. A second series of samples shall be collected
no less than twenty four (24) hours after the first set of samples has been
collected. The individual sets of samples shall be bacteriologically tested to
show the absence of coliform organisms.
      3.   If both sets of samples are satisfactory, all valves on the system
shall be opened with permission of the village public works department. The
contractor and the village will be furnished with copies of the bacteriological
report for their records.
      4.   If either, or both, sets of samples do not pass the bacteriological
examination, the contractor shall again disinfect the main in accordance with
procedures described in this subsection until such time that satisfactory
samples are collected. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4E-11: WORKMANSHIP:
As a minimum requirement, the specification for the construction of water
distribution facilities shall not be less stringent than the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois", adopted by a
joint committee of the Illinois Society Of Professional Engineers, Consulting
Engineers Council Of Illinois, Illinois chapter of the American Public Works
Association, Illinois Municipal League and the Associated General Contractors
Of Illinois. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
ARTICLE F. ROADWAYS, SIDEWALKS AND STREET LIGHTING
SECTION:
12-4F-1: Introduction
12-4F-2: Street Classification
12-4F-3: Geometrics
12-4F-4: Combination Concrete Curb And Gutter
12-4F-5: Driveways And Approaches
12-4F-6: Pavement Types
12-4F-7: Pavement Standard Design Method
12-4F-8: Subgrade Support Strength
12-4F-9: Special Requirements
12-4F-10: Sidewalks
12-4F-11: Street Lighting
12-4F-12: Signs
12-4F-13: Addressing
12-4F-1: INTRODUCTION:
   A.   All developments within the corporate limits or under the village
jurisdiction, regardless of size, shall include provisions for the construction
of roadways and appurtenant construction to serve each parcel of property
within the development. Where more than one building, other than an accessory
building, is located or planned on one parcel of property, the proposed
construction shall also include access roadways as required to serve each such
building.
   B.   The design of all roadways proposed for construction as independent
projects under the control of the village shall also meet the technical
requirements of this article.
   C.   The requirements of articles A, B and D of this chapter are also
applicable to roadway construction. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-2: STREET CLASSIFICATION:
   A.   Certain variables in geometric and structural design discussed in this
section are dependent on the functional classification of the street in
question. For the purposes of these standards, all streets will be classified
as shown in sections
12-6-1 and
12-6-2 of this title.
   B.   In developments where more than one building is located or planned on
one parcel of property and a roadway is provided to serve such buildings, that
roadway shall be classified as residential unless otherwise established by the
village engineer. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-3: GEOMETRICS:
Roadway geometrics shall be as approved by the village engineer. (Ord. 2004-06,
4-19-2004)
12-4F-4: COMBINATION CONCRETE CURB AND GUTTER:
   A.   Combination concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed along the
edge of all pavement except as otherwise approved by the public works director
and village engineer. Cross section, details, materials and construction shall
conform to the requirements of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction" of the Illinois department of transportation for combination
concrete curb and gutter for barrier curb type B6.12 unless otherwise approved
by the public works director and village engineer.
   B.   The curb and gutter shall be stamped with a "w" indicating the location
of a water service, and an "s" indicating the location of a sanitary sewer
service. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-5: DRIVEWAYS AND APPROACHES 1 :
   A.   1. Driveways meeting the requirements of this article shall be provided
at all locations where vehicular traffic is intended to leave the roadway and
move onto private property. The requirements of this article shall also apply
to driveways to be constructed in developed areas where the roadway is already
in place. The limits of driveway approaches to be constructed in compliance
with this section shall be between the roadway itself (back of curb) and the
roadway side of the sidewalk. Driveways extending through previously
constructed curbs shall be installed using a curb cutting machine approved by
the village engineer or public works director. The slope of driveways and drive
approaches shall be no less than one and one-half percent (1.5%) and no more
than ten percent (10%). Replacement of existing driveways and/or drive
approaches are exempt from this requirement. Minimum driveway widths outside
the public right of way shall be as follows:
         a.   Single car driveway: Ten feet (10').
         b.   Two (2) car driveway: Eighteen feet (18').
         c.   Three (3) car driveway: Twenty seven feet (27').
      2.   The driveway approach shall be constructed with a flare from the
public sidewalk to the roadway at a ratio of twelve to three (12:3)
(longitudinal to lateral). See the following standard driveway details.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4946fd43bb2f8dbc5218e5bd25ea5318a6e0fb88/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1957.gif]
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4946fd43bb2f8dbc5218e5bd25ea5318a6e0fb88/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1959.gif]
   B.   1.   Driveways/approaches for single-family zoning lots shall be of
portland cement concrete (PCC) or bituminous concrete. PCC shall be a minimum
of six inches (6") thick on a minimum of four inches (4") of compacted CA-6 or
grade 9 compactible crushed stone for residential driveways. Bituminous
concrete pavement shall be a minimum of two and one-half inches (21/2") of
class I surface mix on a minimum of six inches (6") compacted CA-6 or grade 9
crushed stone.
      2.   Multi-family and nonresidential driveways shall be constructed on
PCC or bituminous concrete as specified above. The PCC shall be eight inches
(8") thick minimum on a minimum of six inches (6") of compacted CA-6 or grade 9
crushed stone. One-half inch (1/2") thick preformed expansion joints shall be
provided between the back of the curb and concrete driveway pavement and
between the driveway and sidewalks. The use of pea gravel, loose gravel, or
sand is not permitted.
   C.   No manholes, inlets, valve vaults or other types of structures shall be
allowed to be constructed in a driveway.
   D.   Material and construction shall conform with the requirements of the
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" of the Illinois
department of transportation for portland cement concrete driveway pavement and
the village ordinances regulating the construction of driveways and approaches.
   E.   The portland cement concrete driveway approach shall be constructed
with air entrained portland cement four percent (4%) to six percent (6%) as
specified by the state department of transportation specifications. The
concrete mix shall be a minimum of six (6) bags of portland cement per cubic
yard of concrete. All concrete driveways and approaches shall use fiberglass
reinforcement additives. The final surface of all concrete driveway approaches
shall have an appropriate sealant applied as per the state specifications. All
driveway and approach surfaces shall have a light brush finish. No chloride or
chemical additive to accelerate the curing process shall be added to the mix
that is being applied to public property or improvements. During the repair or
construction of a driveway approach, if the village engineer, building
commissioner or public works director is of the opinion that the curb on either
side of the approach is damaged beyond repair, upon notification, the owner or
contractor shall replace said curb for a distance of one foot (1') beyond the
boundaries of the approach in either or both directions.
   F.   1.   Subdivisions platted after the effective date hereof shall select
either portland cement concrete or bituminous concrete pavement for driveways
and drive approaches. The selected construction shall be consistent throughout
the platted development.
      2.   Maintenance of said approaches shall be performed by a homeowners'
association and sealed on an annual basis after the first year.
      3.   All such approaches shall be constructed with a minimum of a six
inch (6") base of compacted CA-6, grade 9 or other engineering department
approved materials and a two and one- half inch (21/2") layer of bituminous
concrete.
      4.   All qualified developers shall seek and achieve approval from the
village board to allow the use of the above specified asphalt approaches prior
to any building permits being issued for the production of the single-family
units.
   G.   Expansion joints one-half inch (1/2") thick shall be placed at
intervals of fifty feet (50') in the driveway, driveway approaches, and curbs.
These expansion joints shall consist of premolded bituminous joint filler.
Control joints shall be on five foot (5') centers within the sidewalk.
   H.   When the subgrade has been prepared and no sooner than twenty four (24)
hours prior to placing concrete, the contractor shall notify the village
engineer that forms are in place and the subgrade is ready for inspection.
Subgrade compaction tests, at the subdivider's expense, may be required where
deemed appropriate by the village engineer. No concrete shall be placed until
the subgrade has been inspected and approved. Any concrete poured prior to the
inspection of the subgrade shall, at the direction of the building
commissioner, be removed at the owner's/contractor's expense.
      1.   Residential Driveways:
         a.   Residential driveway widths shall be as follows:
            (1)   Single car: Ten feet (10').
            (2)   Two (2) car: Twenty feet (20').
            (3)   Three (3) car: Twenty seven feet (27').
         b.   Widths shall be measured at the property line. Driveway
approaches (within public right of way) shall have a flare along each side of
the approach beginning at the curb side of the public sidewalk, extending to
the back of curb at a ratio of four to one (4:1), length to width, in
accordance with the standard residential driveway detail.
      2.   Nonresidential Driveways: Nonresidential driveways shall be designed
to accommodate truck and semitruck vehicles up to and including WB 65. Minimum
lane width shall be twelve feet (12'). Minimum driveway and approach shall be
two (2) lanes (24 feet) in width. Width of approach at the back of curb, or
edge of pavement for rural sections, shall be the total lane width plus a curb
return radii to accommodate the traffic for which the development site is
designed as approved by the village engineer. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 8, chapter 1, article B of this code.
12-4F-6: PAVEMENT TYPES:
   A.   Pavement construction required under this section shall be portland
cement or bituminous concrete pavement in accordance with section
12-6-1 of this title.
   B.   In all cases, material and construction shall comply with the
requirements of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
prepared by the Illinois department of transportation, as modified by these
standards.
   C.   In areas where vehicular access is needed by the village, Pingree Grove
fire protection district or other emergency services for the purpose of
maintenance or emergency response, but said access will be infrequent as
determined by those entities, alternative paving methods previous to rainfall
may be considered. The paving material shall be cellular polyethylene
"geoblock" type or approved equal. The geoblock installation shall be capable
of supporting a seventy five thousand (75,000) load and be in accordance with
manufacturer's specifications. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-7: PAVEMENT STANDARD DESIGN METHOD:
When, in the opinion of the village engineer, the volume and composition of the
traffic anticipated to be carried by the pavement can be estimated within
reasonable limits and, in all cases, where the roadway is designed as a four
(4) or more lane facility, the structural design for bituminous pavements and
portland cement concrete pavement shall be based on the latest revision of the
"Federal-Aid Procedures For Local Highway Improvements". However, in no case
shall the design result in a pavement of lesser strength than those shown in
section
12-6-1 of this title. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-8: SUBGRADE SUPPORT STRENGTH:
Structural design procedures acceptable under this article require the
determination of the subgrade support strength. Regardless of the design method
used, a soils report shall be submitted by a soils testing laboratory, approved
by the village engineer, in which subgrade support strength is recommended.
Such recommendation shall be based on an Illinois bearing ratio no less than
3.0. Field compaction tests, where required by the village engineer to verify
conformance with the soils report recommendations, shall be provided at the
subdivider's expense. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-9: SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Bituminous Pavement: The following qualifications and requirements
shall apply to bituminous pavements regardless of design method used:
      1.   No construction required by this article shall be permitted after
November 1 without written authorization of the village engineer.
      2.   In new construction, surface course shall be placed no earlier than
twelve (12) months from the placement of the binder course unless otherwise
approved by the village engineer in writing.
      3.   Minimum acceptable IBR for subgrade is 3.0.
      4.   Where IBR for underlying soil is less than 3.0, it shall be removed
or otherwise modified as required to meet this minimum.
      5.   Minimum subbase thickness, if used, shall be four inches (4").
Minimum base course thickness shall be six inches (6"); ten inches (10") if no
subbase is used.
      6.   Minimum thickness for combined surface and binder course shall be
three inches (3").
   B.   Concrete Pavement: The following qualifications and requirements shall
apply to portland cement concrete pavement, regardless of design method used:
      1.   No portland cement concrete pavement shall be constructed in any
year after November 1 without the written approval of the village engineer and,
in no case, when frost is present in the subgrade.
      2.   All roadway medians shall have tapered approaches at both ends of
the median so as not to create an obstruction to snowplowing operations. The
tapers shall be constructed in accordance with the IDOT standard for PC
concrete islands and medians, number 606301-02.
      3.   Subbase shall be a minimum of four inches (4") thick, constructed of
granular material; except, that for major streets, stabilized granular material
shall be used.
   C.   Underground Utilities:
      1.   Structure Adjustment:
         a.   Where finished grade or alignment for existing underground
structures, such as inlet basins, catch basins, manholes or valve vaults is
affected by proposed work, the project drawings shall provide for the
adjustment of such structures as required.
         b.   Where a project is to be constructed under two (2) or more
construction contracts, one or more of which includes the construction of
pavement, the contract documents for those contracts including paving work
shall provide for the adjustment of underground structures that may be
constructed under other contracts as may be required to fit the proposed
pavement.
      2.   Utility Crossing Protection: For new construction or when required
by the village building commissioner, all sidewalks, curbs, gutters and
driveways over excavated areas or utility trenches shall be reinforced with a
minimum of two (2) no. 4 bars, twelve inches (12") on center, for a length of
twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-10: SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Geometrics: All sidewalks shall be a minimum of four inches (4") thick.
Sidewalks shall be continuous through residential driveways with a minimum
thickness of six inches (6") through the driveway section. Sidewalks in
nonresidential areas shall be a minimum of eight inches (8") thick through
nonresidential driveways. Sidewalk width shall be as specified in section
12-6-2 of this title, or as determined by the village building commissioner
and/or public works director when a greater width is justified on the basis of
anticipated traffic. All public walks shall be a minimum of one foot (1')
outside the property line. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
   B.   Minimum Specifications: As a minimum requirement, the specifications
for the construction of sidewalk facilities shall be at least as stringent as
the requirements set out in the following standards. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004;
amd. 2011 Code)
   C.   Materials: All materials shall meet the requirements of the "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" of the Illinois department of
transportation. All sidewalks shall be constructed of portland cement concrete.
Concrete shall be at least a 6-bag mix, four percent (4%) to six percent (6%)
air entrained, and shall have a slump of not less than two inches (2") nor more
than four inches (4"). Fiberglass reinforced additives shall be used on all
sidewalks extending through driveways. Sidewalks shall be placed on a minimum
of four inches (4") of CA-6 crushed stone or grade 9 compatible crushed stone.
The use of pea gravel, loose gravel or sand is expressly prohibited. Absolutely
no chloride or chemical additives shall be added to the concrete mix used to
construct public improvements to accelerate the curing process.
   D.   Excavation: If, in the opinion of the building commissioner, organic
material is present at the proposed subgrade, the organic material shall be
removed to a minimum of five inches (5") below the subgrade and replaced with
compacted CA-6 crushed stone or grade 9 compacted crushed stone.
   E.   Embankment: When necessary to construct the sidewalk on fill, fill
shall be placed in six inch (6") lifts and thoroughly compacted. Embankment
shall extend one foot (1') beyond the edge of the walk. Side slopes shall not
be steeper than four to one (4:1), except as approved by the village engineer.
   F.   Subgrade Preparation: When the subgrade has been prepared and no sooner
than twenty four (24) hours prior to placing the concrete, the contractor shall
notify the village building commissioner and/or public works director that
forms are in place and the subgrade is ready for inspection. Subgrade
compaction tests, at the subdivider's expense, may be required where deemed
appropriate by the village building commissioner and/or public works director.
No concrete shall be placed until the subgrade has been inspected and approved.
   G.   Cold Weather Requirements: No concrete shall be placed when the air
temperature is below forty degrees Fahrenheit (40°F) or is between forty
degrees (40°) and forty five degrees Fahrenheit (45°F) and falling unless
approved by the village engineer, building commissioner or public works
director. The temperature of the concrete, when placed, as well as ambient air
shall not be less than fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F). In no case shall
concrete be placed on frozen subgrade.
   H.   Requirements For Handicapped Persons: All sidewalk construction
intersecting public or private roadways shall be ramped to meet a depressed
curb and gutter section in conformance with state of Illinois handicap
standards.
   I.   Placing And Finishing: The subgrade shall be adequately moistened
before placement. The concrete shall be thoroughly spaded along the edges,
struck off at the true grade, and finished to a true and even surface. The
surface shall be divided by grooves constructed at right angles to the
centerline of the sidewalk and shall have rounded edges. No slab shall be
longer than six feet (6') nor less than four feet (4') unless otherwise
approved by the village building commissioner. The side edges of the walk shall
also have rounded edges. The surface shall be "broom" finished.
   J.   Expansion Joints/Control Joints:
      1.   Premolded bituminous expansion joints one-half inch (1/2") thick
shall be placed every fifty feet (50') minimum and one- half inch (1/2") thick
between the sidewalk and all structures such as light standards, traffic light
standards, and traffic poles which extend through the sidewalk. Control joints
shall be on five foot (5') centers.
      2.   No manholes, inlets, valve vaults or other types of structures shall
be allowed to be constructed in a sidewalk.
   K.   Protection And Curing:
      1.   All exposed surfaces of concrete shall be protected against rain.
      2.   The concrete shall be cured for a minimum period of three (3) days
after placing by one of the following methods: wet burlap, impervious paper, or
membrane curing compound.
      3.   When the temperature of the air is expected to drop below forty
degrees Fahrenheit (40°F) within twenty four (24) hours after placing, the
concrete shall be protected with nine inches (9") of loose, dry straw and a
layer of burlap, or other acceptable material, for a period of at least five
(5) days.
      4.   All sidewalks shall be stamped with a "w" indicating the location of
a water service, and an "s" indicating the location of a sanitary sewer
service.
   L.   Sidewalk/Path Endings:
      1.   Where any sidewalk or pathway requires a tactile warning, truncated
dome or other similar conspicuity notice in order to comply with the Americans
with Disabilities Act, Illinois Accessibility Act or any similar federal, state
or local ordinance, such tactile warning shall be installed as a permanent,
cast-iron installation. Dyed and imprinted concrete, plastic plates and other
similar construction methods shall not be acceptable for tactile warnings. The
Public Works Director shall be authorized to approve of other proposed tactile
warning methodology by approving of an alternate in a specific writing limited
to that topic, with the recommendation of the Village Engineer. (Ord. 2004-06,
4-19-2004; amd. Ord. 2019-O-34, 9-16-2019)
12-4F-11: STREET LIGHTING:
   A.   Generally: All development shall include the design and construction of
street lighting facilities for the illumination of all roadways which lie in or
border the development. Street lighting shall be in conformance with the
standards and requirements established by the village engineer, in accordance
with the provisions of this code, and subject to the approval of the village
president and board of trustees. It shall be the responsibility of the
developer or subdivider to pay the installation cost of all such lighting.
Street lighting systems shall be guaranteed from date of acceptance for a
period of one year, except streetlight poles shall be guaranteed for five (5)
years. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   Specifications: Street lighting improvements shall be designed and
installed in accordance with:
      1.   "American National Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting" (ANSI/IES
RP-8, 1983).
      2.   "An Information Guide For Roadway Lighting" (by AASHTO, 1984).
      3.   "The National Electrical Code" (NEC, NFPA 70, current edition).
      4.   "District One Recurring Special Provisions For Highway Lighting" (by
IDOT, latest edition).
      5.   Local codes, ordinances, and development standards of the village.
   C.   Submittals: Prior to the installation of any street lighting system,
the following submittals are required for review and approval by the village:
      1.   Layout of proposed street lighting system showing pole locations,
rights of way and any easements, cable routing, controller location, mast arm
orientation, mast arm length, and source of power.
      2.   Manufacturer's information on poles, luminaries, mast arms, cable,
conduit, controller, and appurtenances.
      3.   Voltage drop calculations and electrical characteristics.
      4.   Circuit diagrams and schematics.
   D.   Streetlight Locations In Residential, Commercial And Industrial
Districts:
      1.   Streetlights shall be no closer than eight feet (8') away from any
fire hydrant.
      2.   Unless otherwise directed by the village engineer, the direction of
the support arm shall be at right angles to the centerlines of the intersecting
streets at a four (4) legged intersection. At "T" intersections, a pole shall
be provided on the centerline extended of the terminating street at the top of
the "T" with the support arm extending toward the center of the intersection.
Between intersections, mast arms shall be orientated at right angles to the
centerline.
   E.   Light Pole Requirements:
      1.   Poles shall be in accordance with the standard details included in
this section or as approved by the village engineer and public works director.
      2.   Bracket arms shall be truss tapered elliptical arms manufactured
from aluminum alloy 6063.T6. Bracket arm shall taper to two and three-eighths
inches (23/8") at the luminaire end.
      3.   Poles shall be designed and fabricated to withstand eighty (80) mile
per hour winds and associated wind gusts and vibrations. The light poles shall
be able to support a luminaire panel up to 1.7 square feet. All poles shall be
designed in conformance with AASHTO "Standard Specifications For Structural
Supports For Highway And Traffic Signals".
      4.   Screw in type foundations may be substituted for cast in place
concrete foundations of the size appropriate for the streetlight installation
as approved by the public works department. Design calculations signed and
sealed by a licensed professional engineer must be submitted for the type of
pole/mast arm proposed. Screw in type foundations shall be manufactured by
Dixie Anchoring Systems or approved equal. Minimum material specifications for
screw in type foundations shall be as follows:
         a.   Mounting plate is standard one inch (1") thick and meets ASTM no.
A-36;
         b.   Schedule 20 pipe 0.25 wall thickness (size 8 inches and 10
inches);
         c.   Schedule 40 pipe 0.28 wall thickness (size 6 inches);
         d.   Schedules 20 and 40 meet ASTM no. A-501;
         e.   Standard wiring slot size is two inches by twelve inches (2"x12")
long and is located twelve inches (12") from the bottom of the mounting plate;
         f.   Hot dip galvanizing per ASTM no. A-153 after fabrication;
         g.   Standard inches helix meets ASTM no. A-29. Sizes are as follows:
six inches (6") pipe twelve inches (12") helix, eight inches (8") pipe fourteen
inches (14") helix, and ten inches (10") pipe fifteen inches (15") helix;
         h.   Stinger (pilot) meets ASTM no. A-575; and
         i.   Ultimate torque strength as follows:
            (1)   Six inches (6") shaft ten thousand (10,000) ft./lbs.;
            (2)   Eight inches (8") shaft fifteen thousand (15,000) ft./lbs.;
or
            (3)   Ten inches (10") shaft twenty thousand (20,000) ft./lbs.
   F.   Luminaries And Lamps:
      1.   The luminaries shall consist of a housing, reflector, reflector
holder, lamp socket, slipfitter and a three (3) terminal photoelectric cell
when required. The luminaries and lamps shall be high pressure sodium.
      2.   All fixture components shall be designed to operate under all
environmental conditions. All luminaries shall be designed and wired to operate
on sixty (60) hertz alternating current with a multiple tap high power factor
(95+%PF) regulator type ballast. All fixtures shall be designed to operate at
minus twenty degrees Fahrenheit (-20°F) (28°C) minimum starting temperature.
      3.   The type and style of luminaries shall be approved by the village.
      4.   All wire and cable installed for street lighting systems from the
power source to the lighting poles shall be contained in either three (3)
conductor thirteen inch (13") minimum diameter uniduct manufactured from high
density smooth wall polyethylene electrical plastic duct or heavywalled
galvanized steel conduit required under all pavement and driveways. Direct
burial of all wire and cable under this section is prohibited.
      5.   All wire and cable installed for street lighting systems shall be
heat and moisture resistant, type XHHW, copper wire, and be suitable for use at
seventy five degrees Celsius (75°C) (167°F) and shall have insulation rated at
600V.
      6.   The bare ground wire shall be no. 8 AWG stranded copper wire.
      7.   All wire shall be subject to an insulation test to ground after
installation. The minimum acceptable resistance to ground shall be twenty (20)
megaohms. Any section of wiring failing to pass the minimum insulation test for
any reason or showing an obvious short circuit shall be rejected. All wire,
cable and uniduct to be furnished shall be buried not less than thirty inches
(30") below finished grade. All circuits shall be tested in the presence of the
village electrical inspector.
      8.   All runs shall be continuous without splice in cable or uniduct from
pole handhole to pole handhole or to control cabinet.
      9.   Cable slack shall be provided such that there is a minimum of three
feet (3') of slack at the base of all light poles.
      10.   Adequate slack shall be provided such that the service connection
can be made without splices other than at the power source. In the case of
aerial service, rigid steel conduit for service pole riser including insulated
bushing shall be provided for a service pole riser.
      11.   When passing under concrete or asphalt surfaces, rigid galvanized
steel conduit not less than two inches (2") in diameter shall be used for
raceways for uniduct. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-12: SIGNS:
   A.   Traffic Control: Traffic control and regulatory signs shall be required
on the primary access roads to all subdivisions. The type, number and location
of signs shall be in accordance with the direction of the village engineer.
   B.   Street Names: The developer shall be responsible for the installation
and payment for all street name signs. Street name signs shall be in accordance
with the following:
      1.   Signs: All street name signs shall be double bladed. Local and
collector residential streets shall have four inch (4"), B, white engineer
grade reflective lettering on a six inch (6") sign blade. Major and secondary
arterial streets and all classification of industrial and commercial streets
shall have six inch (6"), B, white engineer grade reflective lettering on a
nine inch (9") street sign blade. All signs shall have green engineer grade
reflective background.
      2.   Posts And Brackets: All posts for street name signs shall be made of
galvanized steel and shall be two and three-eighths inches (23/8") in diameter
(OD). All post brackets shall be Lyle E-series bracket assembly, E-450 (or
acceptable equal) applicable for a sign blade height of six inches (6"). Street
name brackets mounted on streetlight poles shall be Lyle E-series bracket
assembly, black OLP cantilever bracket (or equal) with decorative design. Each
bracket will require a channel mounting bracket for installation. All banding
required shall be stainless steel. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
12-4F-13: ADDRESSING:
Any party seeking approval of a plat which results in the creation of any new
public or private rights of way which are proposed to have a street name and/or
the listing of any address which has not previously been approved by the
Village shall be required to submit a map of the area showing the proposed
street names and address numbers to the Village Engineer. Such map shall extend
to depict surrounding areas to the extent required by the Village Engineer. The
Village Engineer shall review such proposed map and shall comment upon it, and
shall also circulate the same to the Police Department and Pingree Grove Fire
Protection District for their review and approval. All comments from the
Engineer, Police Department and Fire Department shall be addressed and the plan
shall be revised to comply therewith. A revised plan shall be submitted for
review and approval by the Village Engineer. Upon the issuance of unconditional
approval, in writing, the party may submit the revised plan to the United
States Postal Service, with copy to the Village Engineer. The Engineer shall be
included in any discussions with the Postal Service, and if any plan revisions
are recommended, the revised plans shall be subject to a secondary review by
the Engineer, Police Department and Fire Protection District. In no event shall
any addressing plans be submitted to any party for final approval without the
Village's consent. Once a final addressing plan is approved by all parties, it
shall be provided to the Village Engineer in an electronic format designated by
the Engineer, and the Engineer shall provide the same to Kane County and to the
Village's emergency telecommunications dispatch provider. All costs incurred by
the Village during the course of such review shall be subject to reimbursement
by the party seeking approval pursuant to a Professional Fee Reimbursement
Agreement. (Ord. 2018-O-33, 12-17-2018)
CHAPTER 5
DEDICATION OF PARK LANDS AND SCHOOL SITES; FEES IN LIEU
SECTION:
12-5-1: Dedication, Cash Contribution Or Combination Required
12-5-2: Criteria For Park And Recreation Land Dedication
12-5-3: Criteria For School Site Dedication
12-5-4: Criteria For Contribution In Lieu Of Park And School Sites
12-5-5: Density Formula
12-5-6: Reservation Of Additional Land
12-5-7: Combining With Adjoining Developments
12-5-8: Topography And Grading
12-5-9: Improved Sites
12-5-10: Additional Requirements For Land Donations
12-5-11: Application To Annexed Land
12-5-12: Where And When Payments And Dedications Required
12-5-1: DEDICATION, CASH CONTRIBUTION OR COMBINATION REQUIRED:
As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, or of a final plat
of a planned unit development 1 , each subdivider or developer will be required
to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes and land for school sites
to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development, or
cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both,
at the option of the village and in accordance with the criteria and formula
set out in this chapter. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 11, chapter 9 of this code.
12-5-2: CRITERIA FOR PARK AND RECREATION LAND DEDICATION:
   A.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate density of a proposed
development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for
dedication. The total requirement shall be 10.00 acres of land per one thousand
(1,000) of ultimate population in accordance with the following
classifications:
 
Types Of Recreation Area Size Range                Minimum Acres Per 1,000
                                                   People
Play lot                 Minimum 8,000 square feet Not applicable
School-park neighborhood Minimum park of 5 acres   2.5
Neighborhood park        Minimum 3.5 acres         2.0
Districtwide park        Minimum 4 acres up to 30  2.5
                         acres
Community wide park      Minimum 12 acres          3.0
                                                   Total: 10.00 acres of land
                                                   per 1,000 people
 
   B.   Location: The comprehensive park and recreation plan and/or the
"Standards By Types Of Recreation And Park Areas", as adopted by the park
district and the village comprehensive plan, shall be used as guidelines in
locating sites. A park site adjoining all elementary school sites of not less
than five (5) acres shall be considered a requirement. A central location which
will serve equally the entire development is most desirable. In large
developments, these sites can be located throughout the development according
to established standards for park area distances.
   C.   Credit For Private Open Spaces And Recreation Areas:
      1.   When subdividers or developers provide their own open space for
recreation areas and facilities, it has the effect of reducing the demand for
local public recreational services. Depending on the size of the development, a
portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned unit
developments may, at the option of the village board, be provided in the form
of "private" open space in lieu of dedicated "public" open space. The extent of
same shall be determined by the village board, based upon the needs of the
projected residents and in conformance to the total park and recreation land
for the general area.
      2.   In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks
will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of
recreational facilities, including equipment, by the developer as part of his
obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of
facilities to be installed, must be approved by the village, and before any
credit is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider or developer must
guarantee that these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained
for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. Private
"swimming clubs" are included in this provision. When an adjustment for private
recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park
land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned
unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-
2006)
12-5-3: CRITERIA FOR SCHOOL SITE DEDICATION:
   A.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate number of students to be
generated by a subdivision or planned unit development shall bear directly upon
the amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites. The land
dedication requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: 1)
estimated children to be served in each such school classification over the 2)
maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such school
classification as stated herein, and then applying such ratio to the 3) said
minimum recommended number of acres for a school site of each such school
classification as stated herein. The product thereof shall be the acres of land
deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the estimated
increased children in each such school classification.
   B.   School Classification And Size Of School Site: School classification
and size of school sites within the village shall be determined in accordance
with the following criteria:
 
School Classification By   Maximum Number Of Students Minimum Number Acres Of
Grades                     For Each Such School       Land For Each School Site
                           Classification             Of Such Classification
Elementary schools, grades 670                        15
kindergarten through 5
Junior high schools,       850                        25
grades 6 through 8
High schools, grades 9     1,500                      70
through 12
 
   C.   Location: The comprehensive school plan and/or the standards adopted by
the affected school district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites.
(Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006; amd. Ord. 2021-O-21, 12-20-2021)
12-5-4: CRITERIA FOR CONTRIBUTION IN LIEU OF PARK AND SCHOOL SITES:
Where the development is small and the resulting site is too small to be
practical or when the available land is inappropriate for park and recreational
purposes or a school site, the village shall require the subdivider or
developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication required.
The cash contribution in lieu of park and recreation land dedication shall be
held in trust by the village, solely for the acquisition of park and recreation
land as hereinbefore classified, which will be available to serve the immediate
or future needs of the residents of that subdivision or development or for the
improvement of other existing local park and recreation land which already
serves such needs. The cash contribution in lieu of school sites shall be held
in trust by the village or other public body designated by the village solely
for use in the acquisition of land for a school site to serve the immediate or
future needs of children from that subdivision or development, or for the
improvements to any existing school site which already serves such needs, or
for the construction of any school buildings or additions thereto. If any
portion of a cash contribution in lieu of park and recreation land dedication
or cash contribution in lieu of school site is not expended for the purposes
set forth herein within ten (10) years from the date of receipt, it shall be
refunded to the developer who made such contribution, upon receipt of a written
demand by said developer.
   A.   Fair Market Value: The cash contribution in lieu of land shall be based
on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the area improved, as
specified herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and
recreation and school sites. It has been determined that the present "fair
market value" of such improved land in and surrounding the village is
$          per acre and such figure shall be used in making any calculation
herein, except as provided in subsection B of this section or unless the
subdivider or developer files a written objection thereto. In the event of any
such written objection, the subdivider or developer shall submit an appraisal
showing the "fair market value" of such improved land in the area of his
development or other evidence thereof, and final determination of said "fair
market value" per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village board
based upon such information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from
other sources which may be submitted to the village board by village staff, the
park district, school district or others.
   B.   Criteria For Requiring Dedication And A Fee: There will be situations
in subdivisions or planned unit developments when a combination of land
dedication and a contribution in lieu of land are both necessary. These
occasions will arise when:
      1.   Only a portion of the land to be developed is proposed as the
location for a park or school site. That portion of land within the subdivision
falling within the park or school location shall be dedicated as a site as
aforesaid, and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required for any
additional land that would have been required to be dedicated.
      2.   A major part of the local park or recreation site or school site has
already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the
development to complete the site. The remaining portions shall be required by
dedication, and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required. (Ord.
2006-17, 7-17-2006)

and shall be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres of
land or the cash contributions in lieu thereof unless a written objection is
filed thereto by the subdivider or developer. Statistical data obtained from
the United States census bureau and/or other sources approved by the village
shall be deemed as acceptable sources of demographic data.

   B.   In the event a subdivider or developer files a written objection to the
table of estimated ultimate population listed herein, he shall submit his own
demographic study showing the estimated additional population to be generated
from the subdivision or planned unit development, and in that event, final
determination of the density formula to be used in such calculations shall be
made by the village board based upon such demographic information submitted by
the subdivider or developer and from other sources which may be submitted to
the village board by the park district, school district, or others. It is
recognized that population density, age distribution and local conditions
change over the years, and the specific formula for the dedication of land, or
the payment of fees in lieu thereof, as stated herein, is subject to periodic
review and amendment if necessary. (Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004; amd. Ord. 2021-O-
21, 12-20-2021)
12-5-6: RESERVATION OF ADDITIONAL LAND:
Where the comprehensive plan or the standards of the village call for a larger
amount of park and recreational land or school sites in a particular
subdivision or planned unit development than the developer is required to
dedicate, the land needed beyond the developer's contribution shall be reserved
for subsequent purchase by the village or other public body designated by the
village; provided, that such acquisition is made within one year from the date
of approval of the final plat. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
12-5-7: COMBINING WITH ADJOINING DEVELOPMENTS:
Where the subdivision or planned unit development is less than forty (40)
acres, public open space or a school site which is to be dedicated should,
where possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining developments in
order to produce usable recreation areas or school sites without hardship on a
particular developer. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
12-5-8: TOPOGRAPHY AND GRADING:
The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site as well as its
surroundings must be suitable for its intended purposes. Grading on sites
dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not differ greatly from the
surrounding land. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
12-5-9: IMPROVED SITES:
All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of
electrical, water, sewer and streets (including enclosed drainage and curb and
gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provision made
therefor. The sidewalk and trees normally included with the definition of
"improved" sites may be deleted due to the delay time between dedication of any
such school site and construction of school facilities thereon. (Ord. 2006-17,
7-17-2006)
12-5-10: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR LAND DONATIONS:
   A.   All land donations required by this chapter shall be contiguous in one
location.
   B.   All land donations shall be in addition to any detention or retention
facilities and shall be measured in acres of land above the high water level.
No stormwater management areas shall be accepted as part or in whole of the
land donation requirement. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
12-5-11: APPLICATION TO ANNEXED LAND:
The dedication of land or cash contributions in lieu thereof required by this
chapter shall also be required as a condition to the annexation of any land to
the village, and provisions therefor shall be incorporated in any preannexation
agreement governing such land. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-2006)
12-5-12: WHERE AND WHEN PAYMENTS AND DEDICATIONS REQUIRED:
   A.   All dedication of lands herein will be to the village of Pingree Grove,
a municipal corporation, in a form approved by the village attorney.
   B.   All cash contributions will be payable to the village of Pingree Grove,
Illinois, and delivered to the village clerk.
   C.   All required dedications and payments required herein will be made
prior to the issuance of building permits by the village. (Ord. 2006-17, 7-17-
2006)
CHAPTER 6
FIGURES
SECTION:
12-6-1: Figure 1, Minimum Pavement Requirements

Notes:
   1.   Cul-de-sac ROW radius shall be 75 feet for commercial and industrial
streets and 60 feet for all others.
   2.   A tangent of at least 100 feet shall be introduced between reverse
curves on arterials.
   3.   Sidewalk shall be placed in public ROW 1 foot from the property line
unless otherwise approved by the director of public works.
   4.   Sidewalk designated as bike path shall be a minimum of 8 feet wide.
   5.   Unless otherwise indicated in an Illinois department of transportation
strategic regional arterial SRA report.
   6.   40 foot ROW required for frontage roads.
(Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
12-6-3: FIGURE 3, LETTER OF CREDIT:
Village of Pingree Grove
14N042 Reinking Road
Hampshire, IL 60140-8801
Date:
Number:
Account:
Expiration Date: (2 Years Minimum)
We hereby establish our Irrevocable Letter of Credit in your favor for the
account of (Developer), (Address), in the aggregate amount of $ available by
your draft drawn on sight and marked "Drawn Under (Financial Institution)",
dated and accompanied by the following document:
A signed statement by the Village or any other duly authorized official of the
Village of Pingree Grove, certifying that any portion of the improvements on
the Project, as specified in the plans and specifications for the Project known
as approved by the Village Engineer, have not been complied with in accordance
with said plans and specifications.
The improvements in the above-described Project shall be completed on or before
            . If said improvements have not been installed on or before that
date and approved by the Village Engineer, the Village is hereby granted
authority to draw on this Irrevocable Letter of Credit for the purpose of
completing said improvements, in accordance with the provisions herein and
above set forth. This Irrevocable Letter of Credit shall be utilized to secure
the installation of all improvements required under the Subdivision Control
Ordinance of the Village of Pingree Grove. This Irrevocable Letter of Credit
shall not operate as a limitation on the obligation of (Developer) to install
all improvements required by the Village of Pingree Grove.
The principal amount of this Irrevocable Letter of Credit shall not be reduced
for any improvements installed unless such reduction is approved by the Village
Engineer. The Village may submit its sight drafts as herein and above provided
without the consent of (Developer) or any other party. If within ten (10) days
of the date such draft is presented in conformance with the terms of this
Irrevocable Letter of Credit, we fail to honor same, we agree to pay all
attorneys' fees, court costs and other expenses incurred by the Village
enforcing the terms hereof.
We hereby agree that this Irrevocable Letter of Credit shall expire on       as
stated herein above: provided, however, that we shall notify the Village and
Village Engineer by certified mail, return receipt requested, at least ninety
(90) days prior to said expiration date that said Letter of Credit is about to
expire. In no event shall this Irrevocable Letter of Credit or the obligations
contained herein expire except upon prior written notice, it being expressly
agreed that the above expiration date shall be extended as shall be required to
comply with this notice provision.
Said drafts may be submitted for payment for a period of ninety (90) days
following the expiration date of this Irrevocable Letter of Credit, and said
draft shall be honored during the ninety (90) days, in accordance with the
terms and provisions herein contained.
(Signature of Bank Officer)
(Officer's Title)
SEAL
Subscribed and Sworn to before me this            day of      , 200    .
Notary Public.
This Irrevocable Letter of Credit is subject to the "Uniform Custom and
Practice for Documentary Credit, the International Chamber of Commerce
Publication #400 (Latest Revision)", except as herein and above modified.
(Ord. 2004-06, 4-19-2004)
